reviewText:
Thief 2014 is a stealth based game developed by Edios Montreal and published by Square Enix. The game was released in 2014 as one of the entry titles on the next gen consoles while also being released on PS3, 360 and of course, Steam. This is the fourth instalment in the Thief series.

You take control of a thief named Garrett, and play in a first person perspective. Having only previously placed the other games in the series sparsely, I was going into this game with no real feelings about the franchise, other than I had heard great things.  The main aim of the game is to complete objectives in a stealthy manner. Each of the chapters has more than one route that you can take. Each level is also full with guards patrolling the grounds in order to try and catch you out. You are able to distract the guards in many ways, such as throwing bottles to grab their attention, blowing out candles, opening doors etc. On top of a heavy amount of guards, you also have to deal with another kind of enemy, dogs and birds. I have never seen so many birds in cages in a game before; but the idea behind it is, you have to be extra sneaky around the bird cage, or else you will startle the bird and it will start squawking – this bringing attention to yourself. I thought this was a really original idea that adds that extra level of depth to the game play.

Whilst you are sneaking around, you will find plenty of opportunities to steal items, these items are instantly converted to an amount of gold, which you can then buy extra supplies with, such as different arrows, or passive stat increases such as health. Whilst the game is a stealth based game, there may still be moments where you have to use combat; the bow and arrow aspect of the combat system works really well, with an abundance of different types of arrows to choose from, you will always have something for the specific moment. Where the game’s combat lets it down, is the melee; the controls seem really off and it essentially turns into a button mashing competition with anyone you are in a fight with. I know that combat isn’t supposed to be used in this game, but why it is there, and it should be of a decent standard if it is going to be used.  Like I said, the majority of the game play is stealth based, but a good portion of the game also uses the a parkour system; it felt like a poor man’s version of Assassin’s Creed when this was forced on me, there is actually an entire level based on this system which grew really boring very quickly.  Where this game does well though, is the really in depth stealth mechanics, making use of light and sound perfectly.

Thief was one of the first big titles to be released in the next gen market, so as expected; the graphics are of a high standard. I couldn’t quite push out a 4k resolution, but I was playing at 1440p and the is awesome. The lighting in the game is done perfectly, and as it is such a key part of the gameplay, it should be! As PC gamers will probably face more commonly now, the gameplay actually looks better than cut scenes.  Water is also a key element of the game, and that too looks really good. Animation of all characters is done superbly as well.

The game has varying levels of difficulty, the settings are chosen at the start of the game, with no option to change mid-way through your story mode, so you should choose wisely. The difficulty does take a rather high curve towards the latter stages of the game, but nothing that cannot be outweighed by the skills you have learned up to that point. The higher difficulty you pick, you will also be impaired with certain flaws too; such as enemies being more aware, and your energy bars now regenerating in between chapters.  I would have liked the option to change the difficulty on an adhoc basis, as doing it this way may encourage players to just play on the lowest difficulty and not really have any problems completing the game.

Whilst this can is often referred to as an open world, it isn’t as open world as some games such as Skyrim or Fallout. Yes there is a city in which your hide out is located in, and you are able to explore it to your hearts content in between levels, but once you explore it once, there isn’t any real need to go digging again. The base city is small, so even that doesn’t take long to look around. The game does have a couple of side quests which you can do in between chapters to, these are a good way to earn a little extra gold and to squeeze a couple more hours of content out of the story mode. As you can probably guess though, a lot of the side missions are simply fetch quests, since you are their hired thief.

The single player story mode took me just over ten hours to complete on a medium difficulty, I only did a handful of the side missions, as they did start to become very repetitive after a while, but I did take every opportunity to explore levels up and down trying to find collectables.  I felt the length of the game to be satisfying without ever feeling like I was being cut short of content at any point.  This is one of the few single player only games that I will say has a fair bit of reply ability, you can replay missions to complete challenges in them, such as finding all of the loot, or not being discovered by guards, and you could also simply replay the game on a higher difficulty and trying to finish it with the self-imposed handicaps from the start. So you can probably get roughly 20-25 hours out of Thief if you really get into it.

No major technical issues were found whilst playing; the game was running at a smooth 60 fps the entire time, with the resolution high and graphics cranked all the way up to full.  The game has full controller support, but I don’t know why you’d want to use it when the controls fit keyboard and mouse perfectly.

My conclusion is that if you go into this game just expecting a modern day stealth game, you will get a lot of enjoyment out of it. The only reviews I have seen that have put this game down, are ones which have the nostalgic connection to the series, whilst this isn’t a bad thing, it just doesn’t do this game any favours. This is just a modern day version of the game, and in my opinion, is a thrilling experience. The regular price of £19, 99 is OK, if you plan on replaying the game at least once to try out challenges or different difficulties, if you just want to see the story through, then you may just want to wait for it to drop below the £10 mark.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/

Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

reviewText:
You know, Yahtzee Croshaw joked that you could probably beat this game by just running through all the guards to between checkpoints, slamming the door in their faces without much hassle. And no ♥♥♥♥, that's actually what I ended up doing.
It's hard to describe why the game isn't very good. It's got a very compitent stealth system and its mechanics work extremely well. It's just a shame you're never using them to do anything interesting.

The main character's motivation for doing anything is never really given.

The city is pretty open ended but divided painfully into small areas that all look pretty much the same. It's a nice aesthetic, but not for an entire game.

Your only motivation for exploring is to steal stuff, but your only motivation for stealing stuff is for more money, but you don't need money! The basic mechanical system is more than enough to get through the whole game, you don't really need any of the items.

It's just a very lifeless experience. Well done, you made a very nice stealth engine. Next time, use it to make a game that's the least bit engaging!

reviewText:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7HnAPyoOGdI

Thief places players in a sprawling steampunk metropolis known as The City, which after a mysterious ritual is interrupted by Garrett and his protege Erin, is ravaged by a plague known as The Gloom. When Garrett comes to, he finds that Erin perished and the city is at it's knees with the citizens united under a man named Orion who is trying to rid the city of The Baron who oversees it and eliminate The Gloom. It's a bit of a remix of the elements that made up the narratives of previous games with corrupt politicians, shadowy occult orders and, of course, plenty of shiny stuff for Garret to get his hands on. The problem is that Garret himself isn't exactly a silver tongued swindler, instead he dryly pontificates on the city's woes and his predisposition to lift anything with a luster. The plot itself unfolds in an uneven manner with the final act unfolding quickly and clumsily; making it similar to watching a racing thoroughbred breaking a leg and tumbling fifty feet from the finish line throwing up clouds of dust and leaving it's jockey a bloody, crumpled mess. There is never a satisfying build to the major plot points in Thief, they are just thrown out without much in the way of foreshadowing dramatic flair. Ultimately, both fans and newcomers will likely not list the plot of Thief among it's strong points.

Like the previous entry, Deadly Shadows, this installment allows players to explore the city between story missions as well as tackle side missions and steal anything of value that isn't bolted down. From the clocktower that Garret calls home, the city is split between districts that unlock as players progress. A jaunt around the city quickly shows players that Garret's kleptomania isn't his only character fault as he is also prone to eves dropping. Loose lipped denizens give players clues to secret loot as well as adding a few narrative flourishes. The City is also host to a number of secrets and keen players will find themselves stumbling across hidden passages, bookshelf switches, wall safes behind paintings, tunnels and traps to boot. Maps can be located that point players in the direction of some cleverly concealed spoils. All of this makes early exploration of The City a real treat but it only takes a mission or two for the luster to fade. Many secret areas don't really seem to lead to any kind of exceptional reward. The game makes a point of letting you know that you have discovered something intentionally tucked away with an audio cue but the rewards are often the same stupid trinkets that populate every other area in the game. Also, over the course of the game navigating the same streets, dodging or bludgeoning the same guards and visiting the same landmarks becomes tiring and tedious. Many players will pick over each and every home before receiving a specific job from Basso, Garrett's contact, necessitating a return trip. More vexing is how lifeless the city feels. Thief makes a point of trying to explain it's empty streets away with the Gloom and a city wide lockdown but nearly every home that Garret finds his way into is unoccupied. Those who are in the streets often stand in one place or follow a very short path. Many of them don't even speak making your time wandering the streets seem like you are taking part in a steampunk parody of Westworld.

Missions are generally a bit more engaging, offering greater challenges and more intriguing environments. Missions are linear, at best offering a few paths to the next objective. Series fans will mourn the more open areas of past titles but there are a few sections which evoke someof the older game's design like one late game mission that has you infiltrating a huge estate and making your way to it's study. It's here that another disappointing flaw rears it's ugly head, while guards can be dangerous, they never feel cunning or autonomous. Guards can be three feet away staring in Garrett's direction but so long as he looms among the shadows, he will remain undetected. Likewise, the simple patrol paths that guards follow makes stalking them and discreetly taking them out really simple. Being discovered in Thief is usually the result of not seeing a pet bird of dog that draws attention to your presence or bumbling on a surface littered with broken glass. If you happen to be detected while in an elevated position, guards will founder around in the area below in a flustered alert state. Levels are designed around this unsatisfactory AI, so there are still some challenges while playing Thief but they are anything but satisfying. Thankfully, Garret's toolbox is better suited for stealing than fighting, so combat should be avoided at all cost. While players can easily pummel a single guard with Garret's Blackjack, facing more than one foe is usually a death sentence. Garret's bow is also a better tool than a weapon with it's long draw time and limited supply of lethal arrows, that is until he get's his grubby hands on exploding blast arrows...

Thief does make some major strides forward when it comes to giving players control over their game experience, and the importance of this innovation for the stealth game genre cannot be overstated. The menu features a number of UI and difficulty options that can be toggled to provide players with and unprecedented amount of control over how much or how little information they have concerning their surroundings. An icon that tells players whether or not they are completely concealed in the dark can be toggled, the mini map can be turned on and off, how health is displayed can be altered, objective markers can be turned off and even the glint given off by trinkets can be turned off. Also, the new focus feature can be turned off as well. Focus helps highlight traps, collectables, switches, breakables and obstacles. With a few upgrades it will also allow you to deliver punishing blows with the backjack, hasten you lockpicking, move silently and even slow time. It's a handy tool for newcomers and even those familiar with the series will find it useful for things like disarming traps. Also, easing newcomers in is the swoops ability which lets Garrett move swiftly and silently for a short distance. In addition to upgrading the focus ability, Garrett can buy upgrades for his bow and clothing as well as perk bestowing trinkets from a Walter White-esque merchant.

Thief isn't exactly the reboot fans had hoped for but there are some flashes of brilliance among the stupid AI, performance hiccups, lame narrative and repetive trips through the city to your next mission. There is plenty here to suggest that a sequel could provide stealth game fans with what they are looking for. Make your decision to purchase accordingly.

reviewText:
By no means is the game as bad as people say.
But by no means will it ever be worth more than 5 bucks in turn, and at most an hour or two of your time.

Even assuming you set all the options to the exact experience you want, the story is bland and forgettable, the kind of thing that looks good only when you compare it to something as safe as, say, Watch_Dogs, and the gameplay is insanely bland and meaningless in light of numerous games that do everything this game has, and more.
Even assuming you can look past all this and accept a bland game, however, the game as a whole is loaded with bugs and was visibly rushed out the door to meet a release date, despite almost five years in development.
For something with so much time and budget put into it, this game came out of the oven way too soon, and it shows in the sound design and overall glitchy status of the game.

If you're looking for a far more interesting experience like this one, go for Splinter Cell (Chaos Theory in particular), ANY of the classic Thief games, and if you don't have any cash on you at this moment in time? You can always download the Dark Mod for free and improved experience of what this game could've been.

reviewText:
Thief is a troubled reboot of an excellent stealth franchise. Garrett explores claustrophobic, circuitous city hubs that are linked together with frequent loading screens. Side quests are exercises in tedium as you search for the indirect route into treasure rooms. Once inside you’ll comb through empty drawers and watch Garrett grab every item. Missions take you outside hubs into more focused situations. The Northcrest Manor mission is one of few highlights, with numerous routes of infiltration and flames that encourage the use of water arrows.

When creeping around you’ll be disheartened to learn how the ground surface has little impact on stealth. Moss is gone too; so you have to crawl over endless puddles of broken glass that you can’t jump over because Thief only allows contextual mantle. Don’t try to grab anything when on glass because Garrett will crunch the shards and you’ll be heard. Luckily you can hear guards from far away, but they sound like they are inside your ear canal and will never call you taffer. The sound systems are worse than the original and this is compounded when guards repeat quips or copy each other’s lines.

Stealing loot and sneaking around guards can still be satisfying. The swoop mechanic has some merit and the focus blue hue is actually useful in the dull, foggy interiors. Unfortunately the story brushes over themes from the previous games as though the Trickster himself wrote it. It ends with an unresolved finale that does no favours to the jumbled story. This was not the way things were supposed to go. 6/10

reviewText:
Thief is an Action/Adventure/Role-Playing/FPS (First Person Sneaker) game, set in a Victorian Gothic world but, with primitive electric lights and machinery typical of the early 20th century, as well as some unique and very imaginative devices.  The characters are a blend of aristocracy, soldiers, commoners and beggers, some with British accents and, some who sound like they came from the streets of  Brooklyn.  The theme casts a hint of paranormal hope in a disease-ridden city of despair.  The player is a thief named Garrett, who lost his female counterpart, Erin, in an accident which resulted in Garrett's near death.  After his recovery, amnesia swallowed most of his memories of the past year.  So begins his search to find out what happened to him and, to learn Erin's fate.

Much of the city hub is hidden in darkness.  Dark alleys and dimly lit streets dominate Stonemarket. There are paths above ground level that take you past flats, through balconies and over rooftops, providing alternate routes across town.  But, many of the ground-level streets and alleys shown on the game map may look like a clear path with no walls or doors but, they sometimes bring you to a dead-end.  Trying to follow the map is confusing, until you get to know your way around town.

To get to the upper areas, you climb crates, walls, ladders or ropes but, only as the game permits. The game restricts where you can climb, e.g. you can climb one set of crates but not a nearby identicle set of crates.  Most climbable spots are identified by a faint blueish-white glow, which is a big help, when in a hurry.

Thief is comprised of 8 main chapters that will each take from a half hour to as much as 2 hours, depending on how much exploring you do.  Plus, there are 6 optional client jobs with specific items you must retrieve, and are somewhat smaller in scope than the main chapters.  Additionally, there are 25 side jobs that usually involve only one or two rooms and also have a specific item that you're after.

The promise of a fully stealthy play style prompted me to try Thief.  If you want the frontal assault gameplay of a good, old fashioned First-Person-Shooter game, Thief is not for you.  The main character is not a skilled CQB fighter and will often lose in hand-to-hand combat.

To play exclusively with a stealthy approach will require a great deal of time and patience.  However, a mixture of stealth, non-lethal takedowns and kills from a distance is common and a more fun way to play.  Remaining undetected will often depend on how you move and where you hide.  Swoop past a caged bird it becomes agitated by your sudden movement and will alert hostiles.  Dogs have keen senses and will see you when you get too close and give away your presence by barking.  Staying in the shadows and moving low and slow is your best practice for a stealthy approach.

There are a few DLC's that often come with Thief or, are available for a buck or two each.  They are very much worth the small price.  One is an added mission called, The Bank Hiest".  Not as large as a normal chapter but
date: introduces a new component to the challenge.  Three others are "Ghost"
recommended: "Opportunist" and "Predator".  These provide scoring of the three different play styles you can choose from.  You can play them exclusively or in any combination you like.  You decide as you progress.  There is no penalty for using one over another or
hoursPlayed: all three for that matter.  At the end of a mission

- Opportunist:  Interacting with or exploiting the environment

reviewText:
They clearly have no clue what made the Thief series special. I understand the necessity to streamline for a broader audience in order to finance the development of a AAA reboot. I do not understand however, how you'd plan out the reboot of a series and simply forfeit the key things that made it unique.

A typical Thief experience in the first 3 titles:

- player agency is king
- Garrett is a master thief, as in the kind of person who pulls off difficult and challenging heists
- the world is mysterious but largely consistent
- the various factions' beliefs determine the world's institutions, shape, and nature of places Garret visits
- Garrett is intelligent, witty, and cynical
- sound is the primary means of conveying stealth information to Garrett (direction and distance of footsteps, voices, etc.)

In this new Thief:

- player agency is severely hampered (contextual jumping, pre-determined spots for rope arrow, mostly linear map design)
- Garrett does not come across as a professional thief, more like an emo-batman, and the missions are way to easy and linear to require any thought or plan at all
- the world is generic, inconsistent, not plausible, and therefore boring (loot placement, decorations, outdoor design, interior design)
- there are no factions representing any kind of beliefs, the little struggle there is between factions is not shaping the world, it's just alternating who's running it
- Garrett's writing and voice acting has declined sharply from previous titles
- sound is not important at all, there is no robust sound propagation in this game, thus... Garret has a radar map

I could have enjoyed the game with all the other things that water down the experience for the sake of a broader audience: takedown mechanics, focus time, radar map instead of rough sketches, shallow side-quests, shallow character pseudo-progression, whatever rocks your AAA boat...

But a set of features does not make a good game, especially not one that needs you to feel like you're there, in a dangerous place, pulling off a heist or rescuing a friend. For that you need depth, and that has gone out the window in this game.

reviewText:
Worst thief game. I've played them all, own them all.

Pros:
Great graphics, easy to find loot (shimmers), large cityscapes, darting between shadows, new items (screwdriver, wire-cutters, etc.), semi-non-linear maps, Good remake of Thief 3's Asylum, new inventory/arrow selection menu, a few good twists in the plot.

Cons:
Worst plot to date, loss of wall cling for hiding (closets are only hiding spots), rope arrows only work in suggessted spots, other arrows are weaker-usless, blackjack knockdown system is pointless, Nudity (a BIG Con for me),

Overall, I give it a 3/10

reviewText: This is one of the worst games I have played recently. Graphically, it looks good but that's where it ends. The gameplay is very weak and it's unbelievably boring. I dragged on through this game hoping it will pick up at some point but nope. When you look at the gameplay on a video, it seems to be similar to Dishonored, as in, a stealth sandbox. How wrong I was! NOT EVEN CLOSE. While it tries to evoke such an illusion, this game is extremely linear for a game which focuses on stealth. You are very limited by the number of paths you can take. What's super illogical is that the Master Thief can climb up and jump to difficult places while he can't climb up to the easy ones. See a low rooftop which you should be able to climb up directly? Sorry, the game won't allow you because it has specifically set out a series of spots through which you must go if you are to take the rooftops. Yeah, those spots happen to be conveniently placed for the Thief to use. And, don't even get me started on the story. It could have been much more but it ended up being pretty lame.

reviewText:
This game has nothing of the original Thief, which I dearly loved and still do as the best stealth games ever made.

The gameplay basics are there, but the excessive linearity of most levels and the consequent lack of freedom left to the player prevents them from reaching the excellence of its venerable predecessors.

Finally, the story is in itself asbolutely, cringeworthy terrible - it is poorly written, it is replete with the most shallow tropes of the genre and doesn't fit the character of Garrett at all - without mentioning Garrett's character design itself, which I find completely anachronistic, ill-fitting and poorly motivated.

What an incredible let-down, and how much good programming and art wasted.

reviewText:
Having played all the previous games, I couldn’t pass on an opportunity to try out the latest in the Thief series. This one in particular seems to have also gathered a rather bad reputation, but that didn’t really deter me from trying it out for myself. I did manage to play it all the way through the end and came to the conclusion that this game is basically a weak upgrade to Thief: Deadly Shadows with a bit of Dishonored thrown in.

Gameplay is altered a bit by the new ‘swoop’ mechanic, which allows garret to zip across short distances similar to the blink ability in Dishonored. At first this seems almost like cheating but it is counterbalanced a bit by noisy surfaces and broken glass, which give the sound effect as if you had sprinted over them.

You get the usual myriad of special arrows including the new choking and blunt arrows used for stunning opponents and remotely triggering devices and switches respectively. The rope arrow makes a return, but it’s pretty gimped and can only be used as a “key” to get to certain highlighted areas. You also get a few purchasable tools usable for unlocking areas and disabling traps. Finally there are a bunch of passive and active focus abilities that can augment Garret’s ability to stealth, pick locks, fight, and other useful thief-related things.

Playing through the game on highest difficulty, I kind of expected something akin to previous Thief games where I would be required to loot a certain percentage of the level’s treasures. Unfortunately, the new challenge system no longer requires that you meet specific requirements to complete a level. Instead, you receive bonuses for meeting certain criteria like “avoid detection” and “knock out X enemies”. The only overall requirement the game seemed to impose, even at the highest difficulty, was “don’t kill or knock out civilians”. So basically you can just zip through levels and avoid collecting any treasure if you want (not very thief-like!) Most of the upgrades are pretty useless for stealth playthroughs too as well as most of the arrows and tools.

Towards the end of the game I kind of stopped caring about looting places and picking pockets because, to me, the whole game started playing more like an action-fest than what Thief is supposed to be. Even exploring the hub areas for secrets and treasures is soured by the requirement of buying expensive rope arrows, only to find out that the loot you uncover barely covers the initial cost. This is essentially punishing the player for exploring levels, and a huge no-no for making a Thief game. The collectables system doesn’t even pay out until you’ve completed a set, further forcing the player into unnecessary debt from spending arrows to reach secret areas. The whiney female sidekick dream sequence levels didn’t do much to improve my mood either and probably could have been handled way better. Additionally, they decided that adding boss battles to Thief would be a good idea (it isn't).

Ultimately, I cannot recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of previous Thief games. If you’re completely new to the series, you probably won’t care and it’ll be another barely-memorable action game to you. Thief’s only saving grace is that it wasn’t AS bad of a game to its series as Absolution was to Hitman, but man, it’s not very far behind either.

reviewText:
As an original Thief series fan, I find it difficult to enjoy this new installment:

1. Opaque, over-used, slow-to-open, worse-than-loading-bar windows are the real plague.

2. None of that stop its texture pop-in, especially in zoomed view, it's high-res for sure but not seemless.

3. This is not the same Garrett, and arguably a less intriguing character.

Maybe Thief is trying to find new root in the Stealth genre (seems to be taking a lot of cue from Hitman, another SE product), but the little I played of it didn't seem promising.

reviewText:
Growing up, the Thief games were some of my favourite. Even today I still hold them close to my heart. From the distant call of the Horn of Quintus,  to the ambient terror of the Shalebridge Cradle and everything in between, there was never a dull moment. It was a magical feeling that I rarely got with other games, that within minutes of loading the game I would be hooked for hours. So upon hearing the announcement in 2009 of 'Thi4f,' naturally I was extremely excited. So I waited...
and waited...
and waited.

Then came the announcement that broke the hearts of many a diehard Thief fan. Stephen Russell (the voice of the original Garrett) would not be returning. It was like being 5 years old and having your favourite teddy bear torn apart in front of you. Yet I still held somewhat high hopes for the game.

This hope was short lived. I bought the game, and loaded it up. The Hammers that I had grown to hate, yet love were gone. The Trickster and Builder were non-existant, the Pagans and Keepers all but vanished.

I didn't even hear a single mention of the word taffer.

That magical feeling I got with the original trilogy was no longer there. Thief was no longer Thief. After 3 hours of playing, I knew this wasn't the game that I'd grown to love as a young'n. Saddened, I put the game back on its digital shelf, where to this day it gathers e-dust.

TL;DR, diehard Thief fan becomes saddened upon playing this taffin' piece of non-canonical nonsense.

tl;dr: if you want a purely stealth game with minimal combat and story elements, you may like this. If you're looking for anymore than that skip this game or wait for a price drop)

Visuals/animation
Visually, it's pretty fantastic and I don't have all the settings maxed out. Models and animations are very well done as well from what I can tell (random NPC animations aren't the best but whatever, they're not that important). I just wish I could play it in third person due to the character movement being really annoying (there's a lot of bobbing, too much for me). Almost all textures on max settings look great. You might run into some blurry or muddy ones but they are quite rare.

The one thing that is a bit annoying to me is the character movement. Whenever you walk forward the camera zooms in a bit, when you stop, the camera zooms back out. Same with all directions, it gets annoying. It has WAY too much of a bobbing" effect and I absolutely hate this about the movement system and the reason I wish I could just play in third person.

I've now gotten to a point in the game where it goes into third person for some wall climbing/scaling sections. Animations look great

reviewText:
Thief is an interesting experience. It doesn't seem to have much middle ground. The good parts are good, the bad parts are horrible. You play as Garret, a black-clad amalgamation of edgy cliches trying to steal a thing because this guy used another thing to do a thing. This is not a story-driven game. That would be fine if the gameplay made up for it, but it was frequently frustrating and confusing.
Pacing is all over the place. This game doesn't know whether it's a deliberate, slow approach or a heart-pounding chase, and ends up being a jumpy block of neither. Every action has an pre-rendered animation for it, from opening a door to picking up an item, which breaks the flow of gameplay and pulls you out of the immersion. The hand-holding is painful, with the 'optional' focus mode forcing you to choose between using the blue-tinted cheat vision to do almost everything or you get lost trying to do things on your own. The city (which by the way is simply named The City) feels unfinished, with branching paths that don't actually go anywhere and entire streets that serve no purpose. The levels themselves are pretty small, with dimly lit sections of the City hub separated by- OOH THIS PART.
Incoming rant brace yourself.
WHEN YOU REACH THE END OF THE LEVEL SEGMENT YOU HAVE TO GO THROUGH A LOADING SCREEN. HOWEVER, TO ACTIVATE THE LOADING SCREEN YOU HAVE TO COMPLETE A QTE. I SWEAR HALF OF THIS GAME IS LOADING SCREENS AND QTES. HALF OF IT.
Ahem.
Sorry about that. The character development is minimal, but some of them are interesting. The level design for the hub world is pretty awful, but the mission levels are layed out in fun, puzzle-like corridors reminiscent of Dishonored or Deus Ex. Gone is the atmosphere of the old Thief games, but the feel of this game can stand on its own. The story is rubbish but doesn't really need to be anything more than an excuse to get some stealth action in. The stealth AI is laughable, but has the nostalgic charm of the original Thief games enough that I'll let it pass. The puzzles are a breath of fresh air, the takedowns and pickpocketing are satisfying, and the items are very fun to use.
Overall, this game could go either way. While it's not a very well-made game in my opinion, you can get a lot of hours out of it in a scavenger hunt for every last valubale.
I'd give it a 6/10. It's passable, but DO NOT BUY IT AT FULL PRICE.

reviewText: At first glance I was excited about this game. reviewText:
I'm kinda glad I got it in the HB to witness what an abysmal failure it is, totally no buyer's remorse here folks. So I forced myself through it to see what all the fuss was about and it really blows my mind how Eidos could ever come up with something so atrocious. I'm gonna start off by saying that this game does have its moments, but they are very few and far between, it looks good and runs really well, but for most part though I found it to be just extremely frustrating experience due to it's downright idiotic design. Now I should also mention that I only dabbled in the previous thief games and am not a stealth games fan.

My main issue with it is the deliberately horrible combat, yes I know its a thief game and you're not supposed to be engaging in combat to begin with, but its inevitable that you'll find yourself in those situations, either because of your own clumsiness or just poor design where there's no way around it because you're all out of tricks to get the guards to move or put the lights out, most of which cannot even be put out anyway. It happens, and when it happens its essentially game over because 1 enemy can take you out in 1-2 hits while you have to endlessly keep bashing their heads with your little club until they fall over and you can perform a takedown, however the problem is most of the time if one enemy engages you theres gonna be more guards rushing to simultaneously fight you, so you cant even knockout a guy on the ground whose head you already bashed a dozen times because the other guards will instantly kill you if you do, so you're forced to just keep dodging their hits and trying to keep hitting them with your woefully underpowered club until a guard with a crossbow hits you from a distance or you miss a dodge and get killed since theres usually 2-3 guards fighting you at once. The instant guards spot you, you either have to run and hope you dont run into more guards or get shot by an arrow while you're running away and actually get into another area, missing out on all the loot in the previous one, or you can do the sensible thing and just reload your game, which completely takes you out of it and breaks the immersion, which was more likely going to happen anyway as soon as that fight started. Also sometimes, seemingly randomly... without rhyme or reason or any alert when you sneak up behind someone and knock them out its an insta-fail and you have to reload your previous save. Some enemies cant even be knocked out at all. Idiotic game design at it's finest.

Whats more? your typical loot is gonna be worth crap while stuff like arrows which you require to put out lights and general upgrades cost a considerable amount of gold, and to make it even worse as a master thief you start the game out without your essential tools that literally cost an arm and a leg in this game's currency. So the loot you do find for half the game you end up spending on those outrageously priced tools that you were supposed to have in the first place in order to disarm traps, open air vents and cut out paintings from their frames, paintings which you discover to be only collectible items that you cant even sell. Regarding the story, theres not much to say other than at one point or another it seemed a little interesting, but ended up being kinda stupid IMO. In conclusion, I really cant recommend this game to anyone who enjoys well thought-out games with solid execution that allow for different approaches to gameplay, this is a mess of a game and you're much better off playing Dishonored, a game that doesn't force you to dread combat and lets you play it your way.

reviewText:
Fascinatingly bad. I made it through thirteen hours before having to bail as I just couldn't take any more.

There is no fun to be had in this game. Not a single bit. No satisfaction to be gained, no immersion to accumulate, nothing worth experiencing. Joyless. Dead.

It's interesting because it's a high-profile game. A lot of work has gone into it. I think it's an excellent example of what what's wrong with major title game development. This is product. It's not art, it's not designed to make a statement -- it's designed to be as bland and marketable as possible. It is completely generic. It might as well be called Action Video Game". There isn't anything you won't have seen before many times -- it feels like took as many bits from other popular games as they could and shoved them into a machine which mushed them together and sucked all the individuality and interest out of them.

Let's cover the good things first

reviewText: Thiefs back from a long hibernation to prove its worth, is it any good? Thief is a stealth first-person stealing game set in a alternate steam punk age where poverty is strong and plauge is common, in this mess you play as Garret the master thief from the previous games and you run around stealing expensive things. I found myself loosing interest a bit in to the game and I could never realy get back to playing from where I was so I just left it as it was. This is a very slow paced game that realy tests your patiance, now you could either love this or hate it. As you are a thief, combat is not realy a viable option and as such you often find yourself doing odd choices you wouldn`t do when you have a flame arrow and a gaurd walks pass you such as lerk in a closet way to long just waiting for the gaurd to leave as he never does. Sure it can be very satisfying to sneak pass a dozen gaurds unnoticed but after a while I found myself growing tired of the same exact scheme that I had been pulling the 6 or 7 hours that I had been stealing that being acting passive. Anyways, the visuals are pretty great and there is some nice 3D tessellation going on which of course looks great! The games is I guess OK optimized with weird FPS drops here and there ( tested on R9-290 ) could  definatly need some smoothing out. Hard to recommend this game for everyone based on its extreme stealth elements. Still a great game with lots of atmosphere. I'd say go a little loud with the weaponry to spice things up at least if you cant take the slow gameplay.

reviewText:
I had to refund it because the performance was just to bad at my end, I don't have a great graphics card, but even at lowest settings and resolution all the way down to 1280x720 I barely got 15fps while I can play games like GTA V and Hitman with 30+ on medium settings. And this game as far as I played it had only small linear levels with not all that much to render so it should perform better than it did.

I have finished the prologue in the game and the gameplay up to that point was also not all that good. It was hand holding all the way and moving from one visual marker to the next marker (on a restricted linear path) and stealing some meaningless stuff from dressers and the AI also seemed pretty bad as far as I encountered them. At the end of the prologue I also started to notice that the gameplay for the rest of the game will have a lot of QTE's (melee combat for example) and if there is one thing that I don't like in games it is QTE's. The story was ehh... no idea, I already can't remember anymore what it was about. Something about the main character and a thief chick you are running after. If this would have had the gameplay and movement of a game like Dishonored then I no doubt would have liked it a lot more, but this game feels like a bad attempt at being like the game Dishonored.

Not recommended unless you have a high end graphics card (higher than advertised on the store page). And even then I would buy Dishonored if I were you (if you haven't done so already).

reviewText:
Let me first say I'm recommending it, but only just.
In terms of the Thief series, this game doesn't hold up quite the same. Your freedom in traversal isn't plentiful, you will have more than a single path to get through areas, but these more or less come down to simply what the dev has provided in terms of following a path you have selected to its end, you will have options, but not quite open freedom. Do you like to jump? Forget that with this game, the only ascent in any form is achieved by climbing things, and you are only able to climb onto objects which the devs have allowed you to.

The difficulty options are nice, in that you get to customise them more to your liking. It has the typical easy, normal, hard, etc, but on top of that, there is a custom setting where you can turn on/off various other things. This includes the infamous perma-death setting (applies to being caught, seeing as this is a stealth game), no upgrades, no kills or knockouts, no manual saves, slower movement, more expensive items from sellers, and a few others. Personally, I'm doing my first playthrough using the highest difficulty, with all these settings turned on except for the perma-death and no manual saves.

A little nuisance, however, is also something that might just bother completionists, as it is impossible to get 100% on the hardest difficulty. This is because certain difficulty settings make it impossible to complete certain objectives in various missions. Just recently I have completed a mission where I did everything perfect from a stealth standpoint, found all loot, never spotted, never harmed an enemy in any way, and so on. But you couldn't count it as 100%, the reason being... one of these objectives was having exactly 1 kill or knockout, which is impossible with my difficulty settings.

Ignoring the previous entries in the series, it is a pretty decent game, I find myself mostly using it to kill time, though being a stealth fanatic, I can get caught into fairly lengthy sessions despite its flaws. It can still be fun, provided you're a fan of stealth, to just get by without being caught while stealing everything, that is available, in sight.

In terms of performance, it seems well-made for PCs. The only issue in terms of framerate I've encountered being during pre-rendered cut-scenes, where it was noticeably choppy, but otherwise, the game runs smoothly for me with the highest settings. The general appearance of things can also be admired, considering what they were aiming for, seeing as the scenery in this game doesn't necessarily pass for pretty."

I managed to get this game for $37 before release. I'm not exactly unhappy with that amount
date: but to those of you looking to purchase
recommended: I'd have to say it's more worth your money to buy it in the $20-30 range."

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of the original Thief games which are in my top 10 favorite games of all time. So I was worried this new game would not live up to the original. I am about half way thru it and I think it does it justice. In many respects they improved things, such as the graphics, which is to be expected. The sneak aspect is tough in this game like it should be., They leave it optional how you want to power your character up, so he can have an easier time or not, They add some stuff like dogs and birds in cages that can react to your presence, which is great,

The voice actors aren't the same but are OK. A problem with this game that the older game did not have is the characters have limited sound bytes so you hear the same dialog a lot. The old games were good about not doing that. The writing isn't as good, but its not bad. It's just that the original games were top notch. As good as Half Life games. This is solid but not quite as powerful. The original games had a creepy feel to them that was actually very effective. You always felt danger was around every corner.

I just replayed all of them and they still worked on me. This game doesn't do that quite as well. But it is still very good, regardless, and it is not easy. It also has excellent puzzles and Tomb Raider style climbing skills which it needed.

So I would say it's well worth the money and I want more. Thief is an awesome series.

reviewText:
I spent a lot of time mulling over what can be said about Thief.

Unfortunately, nothing in the game is particularly bad, or good. There's very little of anything actually interesting to do or to see.

Gameplay is standard 1st person with stealth elements. Hiding in the shadows, breaking into buildings, stealing loot. Picking locks gets repetitive after the 100th time, like most of the content in game you will be repeating over and over. The fun part is plotting your method to break into a building, most of the missions will give you multiple ways to do so.

Graphics are fine, but performance is poor. Frame-rates dip when entering new areas. Sometimes characters glitch out and start spinning in a circle or textures take on a strange rainbow-like flashing colours. The city is a gloomy, depressing place and the visuals reflect this very well.

Audio is weak. Half of the time, I can't even hear what characters are telling me. The other half, I can hear people through solid walls as if they were stood right next to me. Add to this there isn't any noteworthy music or voice acting.

The game is relatively bug-free. Aside from the rare graphical glitches and framerate issue I previously mentioned, I did not encounter any game-breaking bugs during my time playing.

In conclusion, it's a very meh" game. Not bad at all
date: but it fails to impress in any area. If you can pick it up for 50% off
hoursPlayed: it's hard to think of anything to say about this game because it manages to straddle the "average" line so accurately."

reviewText:
I finished Thief as the sun set, left my apartment for a walk to stretch my plague shrivelled toes. Emerging from that dark world, I reflected on the deceit of Orion, the moral quandries of our nobal thief, the cries of terror and hollow moans of a city squeezed by the plague, and the stench of rats and fecal matter in the streets. I eyed the windows I passed, assessing each based on ease of entry and likelihood of occupants, unconciously feeling for the crowbar at my hip.

Total play-time: 18 hours.

Thief is set in a dark world, bridging stealth gameplay with linear horror elements. The ambience was great, once you get into it. Sad to say the first 10 hours of gameplay was spread out over a number of months, as I just couldn't really get into it very quickly.

Gameplay: 5/10
The controls are all over the map. And the map is a murky labyrinth at best. I almost quit playing because I couldn't figure out how to drop off a dangling rope. Turns out there is a seperate key for that.
Once I became comfortable with it the game became much more enjoyable, but it takes a while.

A/V: 8/10
Ambiance, thy name is Thief. Excellent enivronments, albeit slightly linear, but that's ok because not every game released these days is obligated to be open-world survival. The architecture and attention to detail was great. The background noises and sounds drifting through the city were haunting. The music got old after a while, so I turned it off and was still immersed by the sounds of the city.

Dialogue/Storyline: 5/10
The dialogue was sub-par, but the overall storyline was quite interesting. Nothing is really explained in detail as most of the characters don't mince words much, so there are some intuitive leaps in the story. Most of your journey will take place alone in the dark, if you're not prepared for that then go play Nekopara or something. You really get a sense of  stoic pessimism from most of the characters that sits quite naturally in their bleak world.

Overall: 18/30
I love horror games, and I do enjoy stealth, so this one was uniquely catered to my tastes. That being said I can't recommend it for everyone. If you do give it a shot, give it some time, keep it on the backburner as it moves pretty slow at times.

reviewText:
I wanted this game to be good.  Thief games are smart titles, a welcome breath of fresh air in the din of shooters and roguelikes.  Alas.  It's not just that it fails to meet expectations for a Thief-lover, it's that the game itself is littered with so many problems and poor choices that it fails to even be a great game- Thief entry or no.

This game is, in a word, inconsistant.  There are great things here, but there aren't enough of them to counteract all the terrible, annoying, broken crap.  For every one good thing there's about ten bad ones weighing it down.  If you didn't preorder this game, there's really no reason to pick it up unless you are a diehard stealth gamer, and even then trust me, wait for a sale. As to fellow Thief fans, well, I am sorry this is the game we were all waiting for for so long, because not only is it easily the weakest entry in the series, it wipes away all the canon we came to love, and it ruins a beloved game character that didn't need reinventing.

In short, this is not a Thief game, nor is it a particularly good game.

--absolutely insulting choices made by the dev team to constrict player freedom at nearly every turn.  This studio clearly has control issues if they don't want the players to jump or mantle on just any surface.  This game felt like someone was telling me what to do and limiting my approaches at every turn.

--Levels are nothing to write home about but they work.

--AI can be a challenge on master.

--the audio is a completely broken mess.

--The music goes to some strange places.  I could've done without the dubstep wobbles, but I like that they aren't going with straight orchestral.  The originals had a disctintly odd dark D&B thing going on that I always liked, so at least there's some throwback.

--The NPC's are some of the worst in any game in history.  Forgettable, cookie cutter, constantly raving and yelling, always saying the same phrases over and over in very close bursts.  Super annoying.

--Garrett.  They got Garrett so, so wrong.  I can not put into words how disappointing this is.

--The story is weak and superficial.  None of the characters feel real, and I don't feel for any of them.  They don't seem like people, they seem like fictions in a made up world to serve the story.  It's the most unfortunate thing about the game IMO.  Even when things start to happen in the city it all feels very contrived and forced, I never once felt immersed in the story to the point that I forgot I was playing a video game- with the exception of some moments in Moira, which stands out as the best mission in the game.  Anyone who says the Thief games aren't about narrative haven't played them.  A single mission from the originals has more depth of content than this entire reboot.

--Start a mission with a cutscene, play the mission, watch a cutscene, mission over.  It's not so far from the original thief model, it's just that the cutscenes are poorly done.  they are trying to be hollywood or something, i dunno.  it's not well done.

--There are boss battles.  Someone please tell Eidos Montreal that there do not need to be boss battles in their games if they write them well and design the levels well.  It didn't work in DX:HR and it certainly doesn't work here.

--The main city hub has got to be one of the most irritating things in any game in recent memory.  They should have cut the hub system from the game entirely and just made good missions.  It didn't work in T3.  In fact T3 suffered from a hub system that is fragmented and difficult to navigate.  That was a BAD thing about T3, why they saw fit not only to emulate it but to expand it and make it worse is beyond all reason and logic.

--Some of the side missions show promise, but they are short.

--The stealth system is servicable, but the loot placement is ridiculous and opening drawers gets old real fast.

--I will play through one more time without custom master.  I may have crippled the game with not using the new items and focus.  (Not playing with focus the first time through did get a little frustrating when you can't jump over pressure plate traps, but have to look around for a single brick switch or something.)
{mild spoilers follow]

I couldn't help but notice these things:
--garret's hand gets injured and it's wrapped up for the rest of the game (bioshock infinite)
--there's a plague infecting a city that is on its last legs (dishonored)
--there's no jump button and the contextual edges that the gamer can jump on are painted white (tomb raider)
--there's QTE's to mash a button to open things and to relocate from area to area (tomb raider, other games)
--there'a  couple parkour-style sequences where you hold down sprint and hit space to vault (mirror's edge)
--there's a hold button to observe" hotkey (bioshock infinite
date: other games) (i despise this trend)\n--there's a third person climbing system (ala splinter cell blacklist/tomb raider) but it only appears a few times"

reviewText:
I enjoyed this new Thief, but the paranormal stuff about halfway through made the game less and less enjoyable. I'm going to sum some things up again, so here we go:

+ Realism is great and can be very tense.
+ Stealth works great.
+ Graphics are gorgeous.
+ Plenty of content; collectibles, secrets, sidemissions, jobs, story missions.

+/- Lots of upgrades could've been more interesting. Plus, I didn't feel like traveling through 5 seperate maps just to upgrade my gear and character.

- Paranormal activities halfway through the story.
- I don't think I've used that many arrows, except near the end of the game. They are a bit useless.
- Seperate maps instead of using one big city; frequent loading times = annoying. I have no idea why they chose to do it like this.
- Routes aren't always obvious. It took me tens of minutes to find an entry point sometimes. Very time consuming.
- Jumping is context-sensitive but doesn't always work properly. Many times I fell to my death or the jump didn't register properly.

[Rating: 75/100]

Reviews like this only come when I did not enjoy a game.

I haven't played the previous game in the series, and though this game is supposed to focus on stealth, I found that the clunky controls and plenty of load times in between places and areas made the game a chore to play. Perhaps most people like this game but I did not enjoy it for various reasons including the optimization and game play style.

Thumbs down from me.

reviewText:
Thief was one of the games I was looking forward to play because I like stealth games in general and played all the predecessors. Unfortunately Thief was a disappointment. While the game has very nice graphics and a strong, sinister atmosphere in a well designed, credible steam punk world, the game-play is troublesome and a drag. I had to force myself to play Thief and it felt more like work than fun. In fact, I can't remember a single moment of joy I felt in this game.
Satisfaction? Sometimes.
But it was no fun.

Pros:
- Beautiful graphics
- Strong, sinister atmosphere
- Highly detailed settings of difficulty, allowing you to adjust the difficulty to your personal preference

Cons:
- Path-finding in the open city is terrible. You can't just walk from one quarter to the next. Often you have to break into apartments so you can leave them again on the other side of the house in order to reach another part of the city. Terrible! Moving through the city is like a riddle in a maze.
- Very few, repetitive pieces of thieves goods
- Really bad story
- Horror elements. Do we really need zombie like creatures in a stealth game?
- Ridiculous, annoying riddles
- Unrealistic hiding places for jewelry
- Boring and troublesome game-play

If you want to play a really good fantasy stealth game play Styx. So much better than Thief in every aspect.

reviewText:
Game has a great atmosphere,art and premise, but it fails to deliver.
Each chapter feels increadably small. I don't know if they were trying to optimize the game for weaker machines(It didn't work), but I feel like there were much better ways to do it. How small is it? About two streets for an area. There are about 2 areas each chapter, and maybe a few rooms. If you were living in that gloomy city it'll take you 20 minutes to walk from one end of the city to the other. That's when you combine ALL of the areas presented to you, sans the tomb-raider level (I ♥♥♥♥ you not).

Each level has only 1 or 2 possible ways to do it. Don't bother trying to wander off and explore - you will probably have to get back after getting yourself into a stiky situation.
This feels increadblt constraining. Isn't the point of stealth is to find the optimal path best fitting your playstyle?
I recall when I wandered off to loot something in a hallway, and got stuck between two guards. That's right. Neither was moving. I waited a solid TWENTY MINUTES to get an opening to slip away. and even then I alerted one of the guards and he attacked me.
Not only that, but you also have a restriced set of...things to interact with. A few beams to walk on. Only some walls can be climbed. Only some beams can be shot with a rope arrow.

LOTS of loading screens in the middle of a chapter. They did this clever thing where the animation of opening a window is loading time for the game.
So you are trying to complete a level. You find a window and think that room will lead you to there. You wait for the loading of the room to complete. Then you open another window on the other side of the room to load another area. Or maybe it loads the area you've just left. And after getting there, you suddenly realize this is the wrong way. Or you want to pick up a quest. Now you have to go back throught TWO loading screens.
I don't even know what are they loading - each area is incredably small (as I mentioned) and there aren't a lot of objects to render. They could have just as well loaded the entire thing all at once in extra 30 seconds and saved us the pain.

The art direction of this game is great. I wish it was a big less dark and a bit brighter, so we could see the world better. When I got closer (really closer) to objects I could see how beatifull they were. Shame everything's covered in shadows and you can't see it.

The story is the only reason I completed the game. Although it was predictable, I still enjoyed it very much. I WANTED to get to the ending and feel the world around me.

Magic is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Magic is used as a cheap device to deliver plot. No I don't mean plot device. It literally, on a few occasions, delivered plot to us. It was like an exposition. With clouds. Nothing of intrest is ever done with it. I would have liked if they pulled the magic aspect all together out of the story, except the last reveal about Erin(which still can be done differantly but I accept the fact that the screen writer are lazy).

Any character that Isn't Erin or Garath is a cardboard that speaks. And this is coming from someone who read Twilight and didn't want to kill themselves. There are lots of characters that have an interesting design or concept, but don't do anything and don't contrebute to the story at all.

Game time is short. It says I have 17 hours in game. That is a lie. Remember I said I was stuck between two guards for 20 minutes? This is the entire game. You wait for guards to ♥♥♥♥ off so you could climd that wall behind them. Then After going through more guards, you relise that it's the wrong way. Shame on you - the way back isn't as easy. Better wait some more. I'd say I probably only got half of my total time on record with actual gameplay.

Side quests are boring and hard to get. In all my error prone exploring, I've only managed to complete two or three side-quests. THREE. I was TRYING to get some. But they were in the 'only one way to do it' catagory of how to get to the room that has that quest.

A lot of people are complaining about combat system being ♥♥♥♥♥♥. They are right. It's so horrible it's only there to laught at you because you can't use it. But a stealth game doesn't have to have a good combat system. I respect the devs decision to make this game stealth-only. It only becomes an issue when the stealth mechanism is horrible. but the combat is even worse. And then you are left with two ♥♥♥♥♥♥ options, when one would not get you killed but will kill your patience.
Ususally for games like this I'd recommend buying it on sale. But this game is so bad, that it's not even about the money anymore. If you were to recieve a one million dollar inheritance I'd still tell you to not buy this game. The time wasted on it is not worth it.

tl;dr - Bad gameplay, Bad stealth. Bad characteres. Bad Level design. At least it's pretty

reviewText: Don't let the name fool you, this isn't a game about a thief at all. This is actually a simulator in which you play a sanitation disposal tech who is tasked with picking up various rubbish strewn about a mysterious, grim dark quasi-steampunk city. As a disposal tech it's your job to scour the city for various types of trash such as old ink pens, used flasks, empty ink bottles, cracked vases and various other manner of similarly exciting items. You'll often have to squeeze into tight spaces to remove fallen timber and push it out of the way in a most exciting mini-game. Occasionally you'll have to sneak by various thugs and hooligans who are most likely the people that deposited all the rubbish in the first place. Definitely one of my favorite sim type games and it's almost as good as the gold standard, Garbage Truck Simulator.

reviewText: What a massive disappointment. Incoherent story, innumerable load-zones, broken movement mechanics, and a boring protagonist. reviewText:
Well, to start I want to clarify one thing – the game is not bad, it’s just mediocre.


While I have played all previous instalments (and The Dark Mod) I’m not going to judge Thief developers for the level of fidelity to its predecessors. I don’t mind changing the backstory and getting rid of the known and established lore, the conflict between the Pagans and Mechanist etc.
The thing is – new Thief fails in creating something equally interesting on its own. It just has this generic XIX century steampunk vibe, that didn’t manage to tackle my interest.

I will just try to explain why I’m rather disappointed in this game. There is no single game feature that would make it mediocre in my opinion, it’s just the sum of little things, that create this rather bland experience. I will try to explain it giving just some points as an example.


Lack of the ability to jump – it’s not that limiting as I initially was led to believe, because you can mantle practically on any surface you would like to, with only few exceptions, so I’m ok with that.
Contextual rope arrow – I can live with that, but implementing that solution causes the rope anchor point to stand like sore thumbs and screaming invitation – “look, here you can climb, this is the way further to something interesting”.

Sound design – now this is a big letdown for me. Original Thief games had wonderful sound design that let you place characters and objects in 3D space. Judging by the sound of footsteps you were able to determine the surface someone is walking on, but also whether someone is closing up on you, or getting away further.
In new Thief it’s hardly the case. Footsteps really doesn’t give you good sense of direction, and to make things worse – they are often muffled by generics speeches that persons give. About ♥♥♥♥ rings. From the other side of the stone wall. With audio repeated twice. And alas, that happens frequently, especially when you load new area (which also happens frequently). So often what would be a tense moment of hiding from a patrolling guard will be ruined, because you will only hear repeated generic guard chat (to loudly, even from the other side of the wall (sic!)) ad nauseam that will muffle the footsteps.
As for the random chats and guard lines – they have a big variety of them, but it seems like every person you encounter has only 2-3 limited lines, that they repeat constantly. So you creep for long minutes around the guards that are having the same conversation over and over. Occasionally you will encounter a scripted exposition conversation that shed some light on the world, characters, or even gives you clues about hidden loot. But Karras forbid you raise their suspicion level, because if you interrupt them, there is no coming back (except for a load long before you encounter such situation).
Staying with that – voice acting is pretty decent, albeit there are some issues with lip-sync, and Garret on liners are sometimes over the top.

Speaking about conversations we go to another element – the writing. It’s not that good. I don’t know how the story was butchered and changed in its turbulent development process, but the outcome is average at most and sometimes straight out laughable (so the protagonist is a Thief – lets name his nemesis Thief- Catcher General). Conversations imply sexual things in not very subtle style, like it was written with teenage audience in mind. Plot is uninteresting and cliché-ridden, not to mention that it bears unhealthy resemblance to Dishonored (city dying of plague, you are the only saviour, your allies betray you).

Going back to gameplay – City hub is divided into many districts, all separated by loading zones, and sometimes having loading zones in them. It’s painfully boring to navigate, especially if you have explored most of it on the beginning, because some side missions are available only after finishing main story “Chapters”. So, one mission requires you to go through 3 separate loading zones before you get to the mission area, and there is nothing to do on the way. You have to sneak (or fight) past the guards with, well known by that point, patrol routes, listening to the same conversations.
The City itself seems lifeless.  I didn’t expect crowds on the streets by night (and the plague is a poor device to justify keeping NPC’s of the streets), but even if there is a public event, like hanging  there are 2 persons performing it, and just 2 citizens watching.

Main story is divided into Chapters, but they are designed rather linearly, with multiple loading sections (cleverly disguised, I admit). They just feel like a scripted set of arenas you have to complete in order to move forward, to the next arena. And what’s worse, they feel even more limiting than Dishonored. Admittedly, there are some missions, where you can freely roam big mansions, and they gave me big enjoyment and this “Thief” vibe I was longing to feel. The plot sometimes acts as just to give you a pretext to move your character to a different setting.

The graphics are nice, and lighting is especially good looking, but not always working well. For example if you hide behind a crate with only your head sticking out and the passing guard will have a lantern, the screen will flash to indicate that you are fully visible (another not good design decision), but you will still remain hidden. Or you will be spotted on the other side of the fence, even if you were hiding there (maybe the can see you through the space between planks?). But those are rare instances. Other than that, the bluish tint in everything, and the repeating window textures for rooms that you cannot get into got me bored after some time. On the other hand, interiors are sometimes exceptionally well designed, and underline the differences between mission locations.

As for exploring the City – almost every breaking and entering will be proceed by a loading screen, which takes form of your hands working a crowbar animation, paired with a QTE. Also – your hands are almost constantly visible, and you can see the animations for doing almost anything – looking for a hidden switch, working a lock pick, or taking the loot. But since the most common loot is a pair of scissors laying precisely in the middle of a drawer, it quickly gets boring, and rather brakes immersion, because you know that behind every pair of golden scissors there is an 1-2 second long animation, that you can’t do anything about. I don’t know why they just didn’t go for stacks of coin here and there.

The AI – while they seem competent, when alerted, it’s painfully easy to lose the chase, even by going around the corner and hiding behind a crate, or changing the climbing up or down. Other than that, the change their patrol routs on the basis of your current location. So even if they have no indication of you moving to a different area, they will go and do their routine over there, because the game says so – also a poor design decision.  Other than that they react rather properly to you dousing the lights, or making too much noise.

Now for the good things. Side missions proved to give me most enjoyment so far, and some have really brilliant moments. They are well thought out, loading screens are better incorporated (talking about bank job mission here), the gave me the thief experience I was hoping to get.

But, alas, those few great moments drown in the sea of mediocrity.

And that is why I don’t recommend buying this game for its current price. I’m rather disappointed with the experience, and while I’ve spent around 30h, I had to fight boredom on much more occasions that I wished.

So, to sum up – while not a bad game, it’s not good either, I would recommend waiting for a 50% sale before buying it.

reviewText: Don't play this game as a sequel to the original Thief trilogy. I played those, really loved those and for me Dishonored feels much closer to them than this game. Apart from the occasional reference and the name of some characters, the protagonist among them, this game has not much to do with them. If you can accept that this is not a sequel, if you can somehow separate the two things, than you will find a great game. It's a different Thief, but it still do things quite well. It has a great atmosphere, nicely working stealth mechanics, less combat options (which for me in this genre was an improvement), and quite a lot of stuff to do (haven't seen much of the main plot yet, though I liked it so far, because I was sidetracking a lot). I think this game would have been much better received, if they gave it a different name, because people nowadays have crazy expectations and amazingly whiney attitude, and feeding them hype is the worst thing to do for any game, almost anything is doomed to fail this way (just look at Watch Dogs, which is also a decent game in my opinion). So if you like stealth games with great atmosphere and lots to explore, I can really recommend this one, but if you want to pick up the story of that (ok, it's true, won't deny it) better and cooler Garrett of old and see what happens after Deadly Shadows, then you will be disappointed.

reviewText:
9/10

+ some of the  best graphics i have seen in gaming (if you can run them on ultra settings that is), not only technically but also artistically
+ sound is also fantastic, with a great soundrack, excellent voice acting
+ the well known from previous games in the series atmosphere is here, especially when just exploring the city, you get that mystic feeling
+ garett seems darker this time, story is also darker, some david-lynch moments in the presentation, like the visions
+ gameplay wise, stealth works although the enemy's ai is not the best, still you have to play using stealth, the known accessories are there, this time garett can climb and use ropes to access higher points, nice new swoop movement
+ excellent side missions

- enemy ai is the biggest concern, sometimes you stand in front of them and they are not alerted or they pursue you and if you just change location they stop, you can't hide the bodies in closets etc something you could do in hitman etc
- as with other square enix/eidos new releases, gameplay feels automatic sometimes, they have to invest more time and polish gameplay since everything else seems to work fine

i don't really understand the negative reviews and i don't really care, this is a modern thief game that i really enjoy and will replay for sure.

reviewText:
You know a game is fantastic when you can’t even muster up the spiritual, physical, and emotional strength to finish it. At least I finished the Xb360 port before this one, so I KNOW how the story goes. I bought the PC port to try and replay and see what exactly made me uphold this game to such disdainful regards.

Big Mis-Mother♥♥♥♥ing-take. 29.99 that I’ll never get back. Wish this game came with a real blackjack so I could beat myself mercilessly.

Long-ish review incoming!

Thief is just 3 letters away from ♥♥♥♥. Remember the older Thief games, and how they basically defined the NON-LINEAR stealth genre? The freedom you had in those games? How you could basically approach the situation in many ways? Hell, in Thief 3 I’ve still to find ALL the secret passages/places to explore in a lot of the levels. THAT’S level design right there, making for some really amazing replayability.

And then this incestuous clone of a Dishonored “””game””” (I’m not feeling generous) comes along, takes AAAAAAALLL the established Thief canon, wipes its merry ♥♥♥ with it, and shoves it out the window.

Let’s start with the pro’s and cons:

Pro’s:

+Fantastic graphics. I really feel immersed in the world.
+Pretty nice soundtrack! I like the title theme and a lot of the fighting themes.
+Fluent controls.

Cons:
+Gameplay is boring and feels like a half-♥♥♥♥♥/cancelled Dishonored DLC.
+Very. Very linear. I’m a thief, what the ♥♥♥♥? Why can I only climb certain ledges?
+Very. Very. Bland. Level. Designs. Holy. ♥♥♥♥. I swear two levels are exactly the same outline.
+Something’s wrong with the audio. You can hear guards from like 500 feet away talking as if they’re right next to you?
+This story feels so unfinished? Garrett’s motives for being there is never really explained?
+Oh yeah that takes me to:
+Garrett
+Garrett
+The Protagonist
+Garrett
+(Not pictured: Me, crying.)

Garrett deserves his own paragraph, excuse me for a moment.
Now. Let’s go to other protagonists for a quick comparison.

How come when The Master Chief says he’s a legendary spartan, we believe him?
Because we saw him go from soldier to legend in all his games!
How come when Samus Aran says she’s a bounty hunter, and really good at it, and we believe her?
Because we saw her become one in all her games!
How come when SLY COOPER says he’s a MASTER THIEF, we believe him?
Because we saw him become one in all his games!
How come when Luke Skywalker says he’s a jedi master, we believe him?
Because we saw him become one in the original trilogy!!!
How come when Garrett in the Thief reboot says he’s a master thief, we believe him?
Errr….Because...He...Said...So? And...Uhh…..He does a sick jump???

Do you get what I’m coming at?
If you didn’t, here’s an explanation:

Garrett is one of the most badly written, bland, cliche characters I’ve ever seen in a video game. It’s like Eidos just opened up a template in Character Maker 2.0 called  ‘dark and edgy hero’ and just left it blank.  You can’t just introduce a character out of nowhere and say they’re the BEST at what they do without ANY EXPLANATION.  That’s so bland, that’s so BORING! He never really changes throughout the story. He ALWAYS speaks in the same tone, NEVER seems to show ANY OTHER EMOTION other than Dark Edgy Batman. His REASON for being in the MAIN STORY is never really CLEARLY given out? He’s just… There?

Now, this is all taking into account that this is a reboot, so I’m going to take HIS OLD GAME PERSONALITY AND CANON, and just kinda...Grind it to dust beneath my foot.

The voice acting in this game makes Symphony of the Night look like a Shakespeare opera. It’s either too monotone or WAY TOO forced. Just like every single popular youtuber! The story is so lackluster, and fails to explain A LOT of things. Real talk, if you ever ask yourself  “Will this ever be explained?” , NINE TIMES OUT OF TEN, IT WON’T!

In short: Thief was a promising reboot game, but ultimately falls short because of a lot of Cons that massively outweigh the Pro’s. Boring story, boring protagonist, bland gameplay, but impressive visuals once again bring out the “graphics don’t make a good game” mantra.

Final score: 4.5/10. Can’t recommend this to anyone, not even on sale. Dishonored is 10 dollars less, and is a much, much better stealth game.
