reviewText:
This has one very dissapointing thing compared to the original series:

When you encounter a challenge to surpass, does it feel like you're **inventing your own** solution to the challenge, or does it feel like you're **discovering** the pre-made solution to the challenge that the level designer put there?

This new game makes it feel like your job is to discover the solution that was implemented by the level designer.  In the original games, it felt more like you were inventing the soluton yourself by applying the tools in your theiving skillset.  Even though you can turn the hints off that still doesn't change the feeling that there's a single solution hardcoded by the level designer - it just takes the clues away to help find it but in the end you're still following the method intended for you.

This isn't about the plot, the graphics, or the glitches.  This is about the basic game engine design.  In the older games, Looking Glass studios hooked your thieving abilities directly into the low level behavior of the game's engine.  Whether or not the environment allows you to peek around corners, shoot a rope arrow, or jump, were all the responsibility of the game engine to decide.   If the person designing the level wants to make a jump possible, they have to abide by the rules of the game engine and make the jump the right length to make it possible.  If they want to prevent a rope arrow from working they have to abide by the rules of the game engine and make sure no surfaces are made from shootable materials. In the newer game, however, they took the lazier design of doing that all backward.  They made it the responsibility of the level designer to TELL the game engine where those abilities work and where they don't.  The game engine isn't in control.  The person who wrote the level is.

And that means inventing your own solution to the challenge isn't possible anymore because there is no such thing as the rules of the universe" that you can work with to create your solution.  Every solution that works works because the level designer allowed it to work at that location.

And that ruins a lot of the feel of the game for me. Eidos Montreal got the rights to the game's name but ignored the entire design philosophy that made it good
date:
and stole control away from the player.

It's a shame because using modern computer hardware you could have made a game with the "game engine in charge" design and gotten something a lot cooler than what Looking Glass did with 1999's limitations.  But instead they ignored that part of the game design and managed to make a game that was somehow worse despite using modern technology that makes everything prettier.

"

reviewText:
As a long time fan of the series, I was really excited to hear Eidos was making this game (especially having enjoyed Deus Ex Human Revolution so much so I expected good things).  That said, this a pretty sorry excuse for a game regardless if you are familiar with the previous titles or not.

First of all, let's start with the awful storyline.  Not only did I find the story completely predictable, it was not even remotely well written or interesting at all.  There really is not much else to say about the story, moving on.

The number one complaint I have against this game was how little it actually felt like previous thief games.  Sure there is a sneaking mechanic, but the rest of the gameplay completely falls flat when the AI is asked to anything other than move from patrol point to patrol point.  The second you are detected, the horrible AI reveals just how bad it truly is.  Expect to see guards running into walls and unable to show any signs of intelligence in trying to track you down.  When I was detected, the simple act of clambering up onto a dresser or balcony is enough to evade them for good so long as you wait for them to give up.

If I was not getting annoyed over how easily I was able to sneak wherever I pleased with little to no resistance, I was facepalming my way though all the parkour driven rush sequences which feel completely out of place in this game.  Hey Call of Duty does these types of sequences great, that does not mean I want to see it in a game like Thief Eidos, COMON!

When there actually were brief moments in the game when I thought it had a chance to feel like the Thief games of old I love, those moments were quickly erased and forgotten amidst the horrible dialogue, out of place action sequences that you are forced to endure, and laughable AI that was about as challenging as pressing DELETE from my installed games...

reviewText: EM has managed to kill Thief for good with this stinker. Gameplay is more linear than a second rate side-scroller. The main charcters resemble a couple of sad emo kids with smeared makeup. Game mechanics are laughable. Garret for the most part only does scripted actions. Hit the jump button and he stands there like an idiot. He needs a special key binding to drop off a ledge - with out it he stands there like there's some kind of invisible wall.  Want to shoot an arrow ? Just zoom in and dinky little marrkers will show your way, line themseleves up and you hit fire. Forget about compensating for arc, distance or wind. We have a ♥♥♥♥ing bow and arrow with magical sights. Stuck in front of a window or by some crates / objects you would normally pick up or find a creative way around ? Just mash a key and iniate a brainless scripted scene. That's right just walk along and mash keys. I'm waiting for the tablet or smart phone version where we just swipe garret through the game.  By far Thief 4 has the worst player controls and mapping of  all 4 games. That says something given how much time passed between versions. The bugs just add icing to the cake. It's very fitting that the PC version locks users into using M$ windoze. A Linux / Steam version by Valve would look better, play better, be relatively bug free - and open to the community for modding. The last part is what really popularized the Thief franchise, but if EM didn't get anything else, why would they get that ? Ah, I see they have a Mod contest using, get this, Darkradiant from the DarkMod team / Id Tech 4. What a shame ID, or better yet, Vavle didn't handle this Thief sequel so it would have been done right.

reviewText:
Well, in general this is an awesome game. You can actually feel that the developers put in tonnes of effort to give you the old, dark and corrupted slum of city. I have not played any of the previous Thief title but this game gives me enough freedom to play and approach each quest. Thief is basically a semi open city game where you have to try to avoid being detected while achieving your goals.

The graphics is awesome specially when you maxed out your settings. However there is a serious performance issue after playing a while. There is a benchmark feature in the game and with maxed out setting I can get 50-60fps. The game is smooth for a while and after a mission or so it begins to lag terrible as if the game is trying to reload the texture for the location. The only work around I can find is to set graphics to the lowest possible. Even running on low texture will cause the lag issue. The background music only plays during encounters or certain event and you can only hear sound effects the other times which is excellent.

The story mission brings you to different locations and settings. Each mission feels really unique. The side quest are basically, well, item retrieving but there is a short story to accompany it. There aren't many side quests but in my opinion it is just right. As you progress, you will be able to purchase enhancement item, upgrade your equiptment and even skills. The game offers a selection of ammunitions that gives you more options to play the game. After each story mission, you are able to freely roam in the city completing side quests or simply finding loot. This process can be time consuming but it does give you a really great sense of completion as your collectibles loot are show cased in your hideout.

Apart from the performance issue, there are a couple more things that can be frustrating. The game allows quick save and load. But I do notice each time you reload, the enemies behaviour are reset. Example the guards are suppose patrol in certain pattern but instead they are teleport to a certain location and stationed there. There is also this particular guard in the city when you reload a quick save nearby, he will spin in a 'fasionable' manner while stationed. It is really difficult to approach him then because he will spot you (spinning 360). The city is divided into 2 region. Within each region the map is again divided into 2-3 areas. Now crossing between these areas will not cause the guards to respawn but moving across region will cause the guards respawn. This is extremely annoying and time consuming because you might need to travel between these area several time to complete side quests. And to travel between these areas, you might need to find the exit/entry point which could be an apartment, roof, blockage or door and there are no markers in the map and might be a little frustrating since you haven't memorize the entire map.

Now looking pass through all those set backs, Thief is a really great game and if you are a fan of first person stealth genre, you can give this game a chance.

reviewText:
LASTING IMPRESSIONS
Thief

GENRE
Stealth

STORY (SPOILERS FOR THE FIRST MISSION)
It was supposed to be an easy job. Get into the manor, get the stone, and get out. There wasn't supposed to be a ritual. She wasn't supposed to die. It's been a year since then, not that Garrett would know of course; he's been unconscious all this time. Things have changed, and not for the better. There's a plague going around; the Gloom they call it. The City's been quarantined, death fills the air, and the watch is worse than ever. There's risk all around, but reward is always nearby as well. Besides; since when has a little danger gotten in the way of a master thief's paycheck?

GAMEPLAY
As per usual for stealth games, you must stick to the shadows at all costs. Running is a good way to get yourself caught, as is walking, so you'd be wise to be crouched at most times. When sneaking, you have three states of being. (I guess that's what I'll call them.) You can either be highly visible, in the light, barely visible, in the shadows, or hidden, in complete darkness. To better help you move from shadow to shadow, there is a mechanic known as the swoop. This will allow you to move quickly for a short time whilst crouched and is essential to stay out of sight. You have your two main tools, the blackjack and the compound bow. The blackjack is a simple club like weapon which can be used for combat, breaking levers, and creating distractions. The compound bow allows you to fire an array of arrow types to help during your missions. The arrows available range from the lethal to highly dependable. You also have the ability to lockpick and pickpocket. (I'd hope those don't need an explanation.)

ABILITIES
Your major ability in Thief is known as Focus. Focus will allow you to do a variety of activities with higher efficiency. Loot items, NPCs, and various other things will be highlighted blue. With the help of upgrades you can be lead to unique loot easily, slow down time, conserve your vision meter for effectively, silence your footsteps, and many other improvements.  Something to note, many people are very averse to this ability. It CAN be disabled when beginning your game by choosing custom for difficulty.

VISUALS
The game doesn't look too bad. The texture quality is very decent at the least; many of them look good even from a short distance. The game has great cloth physics; due to the engine used. Lip-syncing is good as well; dodgy is some parts but fine overall. The atmosphere of the city is probably one of the best parts of the game. It expertly conveys the image of a plague-ridden society. The game runs at a solid framerate as well. I can't remember exactly, but I believe it ran at about 58 to 61 fps. The main menu has a benchmark feature to test the framerate.

FINAL THOUGHTS
I wanted to like this game. I wanted to enjoy it so badly. It looked like the kind of game I wanted; the stealing of Sly Cooper mixed with a cohesive stealth system? Great, seven dollars during a sale is a steal! (Pun intended.) The game gave me what I wanted but had forgotten just one thing, charm. Garrett is a boring, cynical, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at most times when I know they were trying to make him sound like a loveable smartass. The story makes no sense; it's bland, boring, and uninspired. Even by stealth game standards, the game is a chore. Nothing happens, ever. At one point (SPOILERS) a building blows up. Mass hysteria, death, fire, rebellion; none of which had any impact. You're immediately thrown into an elevator, which is followed by some platforming without any guards and minimal danger. It has its moments, but with all its untapped potential; Thief did not leave a lasting impression; not a good one anyway. I wish it wouldn't have gone this way.

If I'm gonna be honest, I think Carrot is more of a kleptomaniac than a 'master thief'. I've never seen one man take so many ashtrays in my life...

reviewText:
Thief is not like the previous entries in the franchise and I don't care.  Game franchises, like everything else, evolve over time; in some ways good, in other ways bad.  Just because it's not like how you remember it doesn't make it a bad game.  Quit your whining.

That being said, I still can't recommend this game unless it's on sale-- like, for super cheap.  It adds nothing new to stealth gameplay, other than a pretty immersive atmosphere; but even that is cancelled out by this game's bugs and terrible audio.

How is it that a guard that's 20 yards away from me sounds like he's screaming directly into my ear and yet a guard that's standing right next to me sounds like he's a mile away and whispering?  Simple: the developers don't give a ♥♥♥♥.

At one point, I was lurking in the shadows, trying to figure out how to reach a hidden collectible that was on a higher platform and I heard the guard down the street repeat the same coversation over and over again with another guard that was down the opposite end of the street as if they were standing right next to each other.  If that's not laughably annoying enough, HE WOULD ALSO INTERRUPT THIS CONVERSATION IN MID SENTENCE WITH THE START OF THE EXACT SAME CONVERSATION!

If you can't picture what I'm talking about, I'll give y-- If you can't picture what I'm talking about, I'll give you an example.
If you can't picture what I'm talking about, I'll give you an example.  If you can't picture what I'm talking about, I-- If you can't picture what I'm talk-- If you can't picture what I'm talking about, I'll give you an example.  If you can't picture what I'm talking about, I'll give you an example.  OKAY, I'D LIKE TO HEAR THIS EXAM-- If you can't picture what I'm talking about...

Annoying, right?  If you couldn't figure it out, that wasn't the dialogue, that was a demonstration of how stupid and random it was.  After a half-hour of hearing this crap, I finally threw all stealth out the window, dropped down to the street below, ran up to these idiots (who finally figured out that they weren't alone at this point) and beat them both to death just to get them to shut the ♥♥♥♥ up and stop ruining my gaming experience!

Some of the guards will even get stuck within their normal patrolling pattern and just glitch out trying to walk.  That's right-- THE DEVELOPERS SOMEHOW MESSED UP WALKING!

What upsets me is that these problems could easily be fixed with patches/updates, but for some reason, the developers are REFUSING to fix these problems in their updates.  And why should they?  It's not like they took $50 of my hard-earned money and made off like a... oh...

reviewText:
The game is dood, just not as good as we hoped for.

The thing about Thief is that it’s inevitably compared to the original series.

And well… I have to admit it doesn’t measure up.  Much of the freedom of the originals is gone, for example rope arrows can only be shot at per-defined by developers spots rather than any wooden surface.  With that freedom much of the emergent behavior and lateral thinking is gone too.  The significance of sound is also reduced - you no longer strain your hearing listening to guards footsteps, you no longer get caught because you accidentally put left headphone into your right ear.  The planning and observation are dismissed in favor  of more action style… you no longer watch the guard patrol route for minutes at a time, keeping count under your breath, looking for that one prefect moment, a tiny window of opportunity to sneak past.

And you CAN get through the game by killing everything that moves.

But… if you stop comparing Thief to original games, you will find solid stealth game, with interesting settings, descent story, pseudo-open world, RPG elements, and plenty of content.  If you like stealth games – it’s definitely worth playing.

reviewText:
One a 5 star scale I would put Thief at 3/5 stars.  Now, that's actually not bad.  2 stars is bad, 1 star is horrible.  3 stars simply means that it was average, enjoyable, but not so good that I need to go brag for it to everyone I know or replay it ever again.  4 stars is an excellent game with some minor flaws, and 5 stars is a perfect game, of which few are.  But Thief is fun, but its easier to quantify what is wrong with it rather than what is right.

The graphics are well done and they seem to run well on most systems.  The game is solid, although I did encounter one bug and one game crash.

The stealth system, I thought was lacking.  It was sorta like the Elder Scrolls Oblivion stealth.  If I crouch walk and stay in the dark no one cane see me.  Yes, there are other obstacles like walking on broken glass makes noise (the city has a serious shortage of janitorial staff, glass is everywhere), but overall the stealth system seems undeveloped.  It occurs to me that the stealth in Watch Dogs was actually more fun, and that's only a small part of that game.

The scenery is bleak and dull, perhaps that is unavoidable with a stealth game set entirely at night.  The characters are all dull, undeveloped, and uncharacteristic of themselves.  Most bothersome to me is how righteous Garret, the protagonist, is portrayed.  Garret is a hero, saving the city.  The people whom he gives concussions to and sometimes kills are evil greedy pigs – how dare they work for a living, including those damned guards.  Further, there is so little choice about who Garret is that its like you are playing through a boring movie.  The plot is very strange.  In fact, it makes little sense to me even now.  I pulled out my trusty smart phone and headed to Wikipedia as the credits rolled to see if anyone summarized it for me.  No one had, No one!  So I think other players might be having the same issue as I had,  We are not entirely sure what the story was about other than some weird blue crystals, a freak girl, and a rich pig-man.

reviewText: My Playthrough          Youtube Playlist                 The Review        This is a very disappointing game. I enjoyed Eidos Montreal's Deus Ex: Human Revolution. So when I heard that they were doing a reboot of the Thief series I was excited but then I played it. This game is nowhere near as good as Deus Ex: Human Revolution as this game story is terrible and the stealth elements aren't their. This game is more of a platforming stealing game pretending to be a stealth game. As you can see from my playthrough above is that I played on the hardest setting and yet the guards A.I are still laughable. It was times where I was right in front of them and they couldn't notice me and if they did notice me all I had to do was hide for 3 minutes and they would go back to normal like I was never their in the first place. The story is also terrible and it's not helped with Garrett being one of the most boring videogame protagonists that I have ever played as. His monotone voice and nonchalant attitude does not work well with the narrative. And the worse part is that the game's plot is all over the place and makes no sense. I don't know what went wrong when Eidos Montreal was developing this game but I hope that they learned form their mistakes.

reviewText:
Using the name of an established gaming series is already a task riddled with expectations. It is a difficult and often daunting task to replicate and improve a milestone of any genre.

Like the gentrification of your favourite suburb; Thief, as much of a title as it is a testament to the gameplay, has deducted the core values of the franchise and replaced them with shallow marketable features.

Any game focused on the design principles of 'stealth' would do so with intelligent level design, a player directed experience and tools that feel valued to their potential contexts. However I found a substantial lack of engagement in all these areas, both in my experience at home and while playing at a friend's house.

Although the game falls short on everything that should be expected of Thief, the nature of a purely market-orientated game gives rise to some impressive features. Features that I did enjoy, were the noise hazards, expanded options to tailor your gameplay experience, and the visuals.

They did an excellent job exploiting the first person medium; having you direct Garret's hands over containers, paintings and items of interest. This feature could be perceived as redundant, but it gave you some ephemeral agency in your role as a 'thief' and made you feel much more engaged in the action of stealing itself.

However this could not save the game for me. On every objective level, the game fails to deliver innovation relevant to it's title, legacy and to this era of gaming.

The common challanges that drive the appeal of stealth are replaced with linear environments, predictable enemies and uneccesary assistance in beforementioned challenges. Players will feel little agency in their navigation through the world, and any illusion of choice will always be broken from poor combat mechanics and a lackluster sandbox attempt.

This game would be worth the money for $20, but I feel there are many games out there with half the production size, but infinitely more in gameplay features. For this, my time with Thief was frustrating and in the personal space of my own home I felt uninclined to continue my gameplay experience.

reviewText:
Why does Chapter 5 exist?
First Thief game I've ever played and it was a huge let down. This game is riddled with bad AI, bugs, and overall ♥♥♥♥♥♥ game design. If you have any sense of what they call Gamer's Intuition, this game is a damn breeze, and a boring one at that.

It did have it's good moments, though! Like when I found out how cathartic it is to smack civilians upside the head with my beating stick.

SPOILER ALERTAlso, Chapter 5 bears mentioning. What the actual ♥♥♥♥ was that? This bad stealth game all of a sudden took on the visage of a horror game, like Outlast. The sad part? That was the first piece of solid game design I'd seen! It was so good for what it shouldn't have been. If Thief had been a horror game, this review would be positive, and I would have loved it. Sure, the horror was weak, and predictable, but they established atmosphere, and that's what they lack in most AAA horror games nowadays.

reviewText:
I accidently alerted the cook while stealing cutlery in the kitchen. He started yelling and was going to blow the whole job for me. I started beating him badly with my blackjack and had to wack him 3 or 5 times until he crumpled to the floor. He then fell down the stairs into the basement. I hope he recovered and turned out OK because I really felt bad about it.

I hid behind a building on one mission only to hear growling behind me. This damn dog was going to alert the 5 guards in the courtyard around me... I was trapped and he was starting to bark now. I had to shoot the dog. Yea thats right I shot a dog. I love dogs. God, what have I become?!?

This guy was blubbering in the corner begging me not to hurt him. He saw me shoot one of his guards in the face and ran to alert another nearby guard so I had to fight him too. Little crybaby really messed up my stats for this mission and now Im all wounded and stuff. I was pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥ so I smashed him in the face with a blackjack and threw him to the ground.

I went to a brothel and had to beat a woman to the floor cause she caught me stealing a candlestick. She screamed and cried at me the whole time. It was horrible, I felt like a monster. I had to hide here unconcious body so the other ladies wouldnt find her lying in the middle of the room like that. I little bit of me died when that happened.

I recommend buying this game if you can get it on one of the sales. It isnt perfect, and it certainly isnt The Dark Project the one we all love and cherish in our hearts, but it is still a really good game.

reviewText:
As someone who's never played Thief I was interested in trying out the newest game in the series. To put it simply, Thief 4 is a fun game with some big issues.

Story - You are Garrett, Master Thief. During the tutorial your friend goes missing and you must rescue her while robbing the city blind. Overall the story's pretty generic so there's not much to talk about. It serves its purpose although the characters are quite bland and unmemorable (the only ones I liked are your fence Basso, and Garrett himself).

Gameplay - The gameplay is a mix of stealth, action and stealing. You'll be sent on various missions and have to use your skills to complete them. I liked these missions. There were various ways to get through them, the environments are diverse and Garrett has a lot of tools are his disposal. Arrows in particular are a big focus and can be used to light fires, distract guards and so much more. You can buy these with gold you earn from stealing loot (which includes both regular items and special collectibles) and there's loot EVERYWHERE. It really feels like you're a Master Thief who's robbing the city of everything it owns.

Unfortunately being a thief has its dangers and if you get seen then you're pretty much screwed. Garrett can only take a few hits and dying will send you back to your last save (although you CAN sneak behind guards and knock them out first). This brings me to another negative which is the hub city itself. Things are put VERY far apart and often have several loading screens in the way, which turns city exploration into a huge drag as you have to find the particular gate/window that gets you to the next area. Overall the missions are fun but city exploration is sluggish and can slow down the experience.

Graphics - Here we go... Thief 4 looks great and there's LOTS of graphical options too. However it's horribly optimized and ran poorly on my computer. I did research and it's a common issue so keep that in mind if you get the game.

Music - Nothing much to say here. Pretty generic but serves its purpose.

Difficulty & Replayability - I played through Thief on Normal and found it pretty easy, that being said there's a great amount of customization with the difficulty and you can tailor the experience to your personal tastes. This increases the replayability but I don't see myself playing through this game again. There are a lot of collectibles if you'd like to though.

Final Verdict - Thief 4 is a fun game with some big issues. If you can get past the poor optimization, generic story and sluggish exploration then you'll find an enjoyable game. I would recommened it, but only when it goes on sale.

reviewText:
Where to start.....

I first played this when it first came out in 2014 on the old gen consoles and found it rather an odd way for Eidos to go in the series. As a standalone game i could see it working but it is definitely not a good 4th game in the series (More like the Blacksheep of the family)

The music and sounds are continously at odds with each other, id reccomend muting the Music so you can actually hear whats going on around you, and the Dialogue.... It's just crude and crude and crude and crude... Oh it's also extremely repetitive after the first hour or so hearing different guards talking about the same things.

The gameplay itself can be pretty exciting if you are new to the Thief franchise but if you are a veteran player it is to linear, forcing you along a set path to your end goal (not what thief is about, impo) The city is less linear although you will find yourself going back and forward along the same routes, again hearing the same dribble from the same npcs over and again.

Graphics wise, cant really argue there. It's got nice crisp scenery and some decent cutscenes (Although for a next gen game i gues it had to be a cut above the rest)

I only bought this on steam recently as they had the Eidos Anthology on offer at £24 down from £160.
If you like stealthy games and are a fan of Eidos then for £20 i would reccomend Hitman: Absolution instead, there is a lot more gameplay and it stays true to it's franchise.....

Overall if you have never played the Thief franchise and can get this on offer then i would say go for it. If you are a longtime thief fan i wouldnt reccomend this to continue the Adventures" of Garrett (Again unless it's on offer)

6/10"

reviewText:
I would rate Thief a 7/10 in my book.

This game is definitely directed towards certain types of gameplayers. If you're the type of person who likes Call of Duty and fast paced run 'em down games then Thief is not for you. If you love games like Skyrim and will spend hours of your time in games looting bodies then Thief is definitely for you.

The graphics were absolutely stunning and I rarely found myself lagging or having problems with my computer playing the game. 11/10 for graphics for sure.

I really enjoyed a lot of the gameplay throughout this game. I found it to be challenging and tricky enough to keep me on my toes and using my brain and I wasn't ever bored. The storyline is where I have my issues with this game. I found it slightly confusing and felt as if the developers went way too far into the vagueness rather than spelling it out for the players. Maybe im just thick skulled and didn't catch on fast enough but towards the end I found myself more confused than anything. The ending was not as great as I would have expected and left me a little puzzled.

Regardless though I would definitely recommend this game for those of you who have patience and value your looting.

7-8/10

reviewText:
Bought the Thief collection when it was on sale for $11. Never played the originals and wanted to play this first, to judge it without as much bias. After playing for two or so hours I thought it was alright and not as bad as people made it out to be.

Then, some things started to irritate me. Nitpicks I suppose, but after playing the original for a bit, the issues I had/have compounded. Contextual jumping is my biggest issue, having Garrett decide the best way to grab a ♥♥♥♥ing rope in front of him was to jump off the 3 story ledge he was on, straight into the ground below, killing him. This has happened more times than I can count in the 15 hours I've put in. The pseudo-AssCreed style 3rd Person climbing in certain places just feels like it shouldn't be there, and really is pointless. Every time I try to open a drawer in a desk, the contextual leaning decides I wanted to lean, not open the drawer.

Nearly every action you can do is contextual, causing issues as I've stated, and essentially turns everything into a small cutscene or an animation in which you've no control. Knocking out a guard, pickpocketing, even opening ♥♥♥♥ing drawers. It makes everything feel sluggish, even in the rare moments Garrett decides to skip the aftercare when knocking a guard out. What comes to mind is an attempt to mimic Deus Ex: Human Revolution's takedown system, and as much I love that game, that takedown system wasn't good there, or here.

The story, so far, is best to be ignored. Every supporting character seems to only be there to annoy you, Garrett seems to think he's discount Batman, being about as intelligent as the caped lunatic. I've gotten to the point where I've dropped the pretense of Garrett just being a thief, trying to stealth his way through the wallets and safes of poor saps, and just killing everyone in my path just to get through the game quicker.

The focus abilities seem to be damn pointless, the upgrade allowing you to see lock mechanisms when picking just makes it even more difficult to pick, as the pins actually fight against you now. The stealth Focus upgrade doesn't appear to do as advertised, that is, keeping you hidden in light for a brief moment. With the standard eye ability, the best thing you can do for yourself is drain the focus meter entirely, and just tap the focus button, as the ability will flash on and off, but highlightable objects will be highlighted for a moment. On the subject of safes, I have found maybe 2 combinations in the entire game, and at least one of them you get no matter what because of story reasons. I have found it to be more prudent to brute force or even flat out looking up the combination, as I'm not going to scour the entire city for some cobbler's damn safe combo, for 20 gold.

There are a lot of moments this game has where it could be fun, but it seems to be content with spoiling it as much as possible. On a more positive note, I absolutely love the swoop mechanic, and ignoring the focus ability for it, I enjoy the lockpicking as well.

The only reason I'm still playing is I can't stand not finishing a game, but as soon as I beat it, there is no way I'm touching it again. I suggest you don't bother with this.

reviewText:
The problem with naming a game after a beloved series is that it will inevitably be compared to that series' best version. It happened with DMC: Devil May Cry, and it happened here.
On it's own this game isn't that bad. It's biggest problem is that it feels like it was made on a factory line with a checklist. Standard love interest, check. Standard villain, check. Standard gameplay, check. Standard weapons and gear, check. Nothing in this game really makes it stand out from the crowd. In Thief 2 you had huge sprawling levels you could get lost in with tons of secrets to find if you were observant and clever enough.
One thing that I really noticed was that rope arrows in this game only worked at very specific points. If you fired a rope arrow anywhere else it would just be a waste of time and arrows. In Thief 2 you could fire one of those suckers anywhere and climb up even if it led nowhere. It encouraged exploring outside the linear hallways and streets.

TL:DR version. Not the worst game, but there are better stealth games out there.

reviewText:
This game is unfortunate that it suffers for being a reboot of one of the greatest and most important series of games of all time. Thief is a very good stealth game on its own but as a reboot, it is a terrible Thief game. What made the original Thief games great was thrown out the window for linear-looking levels, weird A.I and lots of problems and bugs for some Steam users who preordered the game although I was fortunate not to have to deal with it. And don't get me started on the story. There's potential but the execution was bad. And the last third act leading to the ending was a complete disappointment. Without Stephen Russell in the role, Garrett's voice sounds pretty flat most of the time.

However, Thief The Reboot FELT like a Thief game and that's where this reboot excels. Stealing here is as fun as it was in the original games, maybe even better. The tension as you're opening a drawer to pocket a bit of loot is there and the glee as you watch your loot count rise brings back memories from the old games. Challenge Mode is brilliant, that's where the replay value for this game is. Its more tense and more exciting than the base game itself. No need to worry about the story or anything, just focus on good ole stealin.

Not a great game but not a terrible game either. Thief 2014 will probably be remembered years from now as a missed opportunity but hopefully, it will ignite an interest for more returns to the Thief universe. But it looks like we'll have to wait some more for a more triumphant return of the Master Thief.

reviewText: I played the original Thief games when they came out over a decade ago and really enjoyed them a lot. I remember thinking how much more fun a game like Thief would be in the future once computing power and graphic quality increased. Well, the future is now and I can safely say that it isn't good. Sure, the graphics are obviously nice and the story is decent - but, this is a game that hasn't captured any of the charm of the original. Where are the wide open cities and its huge potential to do anything? Why with the decade of improvements in game engine design, computers, and so forth does the game need to turn most 1-bedroom houses in the main city into their own little loading zones?\n\nSuch wasted potential, I'm really sorry to see how badly they missed the plot.

reviewText:
I've played the other Thief games many years ago - they were superb for the technology at the time.

New isn't always better. The interface feels broken, movement is sluggish, the voice acting is often annoying & sounds noticeably generic. The actor they picked up to voice Garrett sounds like he is from either Brooklyn, New York or possibly the Bronx - I can't tell which. I'm starting to see why this is getting low scores on reviews. The sounds overlap and mute each other out, the music drowns out important dialogue at times. I'm wondering how this can feel broken if they've had so much time since the game was announced? How do you &*@^# something like this up so bad?  When the intro screen popped up I wasn't sure if I was about to play a Batman game or a stealth game.  If they're not going to work with Stephen Russell for the voice acting (I'm thinking it was a greed-based decision) then make a new character in the Thief world rather than have someone new pretend to be the old character and mimic his voice. I just can't imagine Garrett spent some time in New York/New Jersey prior to this next installment where he has somehow picked up an accent. Stephen Russel played a sharp, seasoned, calculating, intelligent thief, the new guy sounds like he could play an Italian hitman in some other game or whip out a tommygun.

I really want to go all out & cuss about this game but I'll  just say one final thing - wait until it's $7.99 - $14.99. Give them time to patch this game because it needs it.

reviewText:
Being that I never played the original Thief, I got this on it's release and I never bothered to review it and up until a while ago, did not touch the original, So here is my run down.

The Good : - For a while it's incredibly immersive
- It's world is definitely something that is interesting
- Good atmosphere
- You don't need to kill people at all
- It's stealth is better than, I dare say a lot of stealth games now a days
- Quite a nice looking game
- Some big open areas
- Takes longer than 10 hours
- Some replayability through the difficulties
- Flowing movement (Excluding the unexistance of jumping)

The Bad : - The story is all over the place
- Erin
- Game falls apart if you aren't a stealthy person (Don't even buy it if you aren't a stealth fan)
- A lot of the locations are very bland
- City Hub is tedious to explore often
- The AI can be pretty stupid
- Incredibly easy on lower difficulty settings
- Voice acting feels pretty weak
- Tries a bit too hard to be a Supernatural horror at times
- Really begins to feel bland after half way

Overall the game is very pretty and the definitely tries to be an incredible game, but it does feel really lacking, I feel like Dishonored did a good job of being a stealth game better than Thief but I definitely admire it's effort, this game definitely needed more time to be polished since these are the same guys who made the incredibly Deus EX Human Revolution. But if you are looking for a good stealth game but don't feel like being too retro, I'd suggest trying Dishonored then this, I'd recommend paying at around $20 as it's still a likeable game just feels as if it tries to get too far ahead of itself.

reviewText: You have to first understand that the city is the game. The characters, plot, and the gameplay is all an extension of the city that is gloomy, full of sorrow, dark, and even humane-less. After this, you will take advantage of the controls, adjust the hud to the way you think is best to get the most out of the game, and you will enjoy being lost in this city! If you strictly follow the story and feel no connection to the exploration factor of the setting based on the way this game allows you to (its not meant for you to go everywhere like youre spiderman, just play with the mood of the game) then this game is not for you or you need to give it some time.

reviewText:
It's like a mixture Dishonored and Dark Messiah of Might and Magic, but without a majority of the good part. Bad level design and way too many loading screens. Combat feels odd and clunky. Story is nothing worthwhile mentioning, no character development what so ever, and the only two characters which i somewhat cared about(Garrett and Erin) was ruined by the poor ending.

The game looks pretty good, and there is alot of details, the  characters looks nice, but i do think that Garrett looks like a emo with emotionel problems and prehabs a bit of a hobo.

I would wish that i could equip a diffrent meele weapon or a diffrent bow to mix up the combat.
The diffrent arrows is nice but you are gonna end up only usinh two or three of them.

I really tried to get as much gameplay out of this game, but i only got about 15 hours or so.( I do think you could finnish this game in 4 hours)

I suposse it is a okay(-ish?) game to buy if it's on sale, but have low expectations. 6/10

reviewText: Thief is a huge letdown for fans of the original series. Thief is a thief game in name only. The gameplay is incredibly easy for a stealth game. In the originals, guards would spot you from across entire rooms, in Thief (on the hardest difficulty) I was able to walk to the side of someone, easily within their peripheral vision in a well-lit room, and was not seen. I do like the amount of options they give for changing the game to suit your own style, but a lot more needed to be done to this game to be worthy of the originals.

reviewText:
The thief series have long been my favorite game series of all time.

Thief - The Dark Project was a masterpiece with a wonderful engrossing story to it, that starts small but then drags you into an epic conclusion.
Thief - The Metal Age deals with the aftereffects of the first game. It can be played standalone, but it is the perfect continuation of the first game, and this too drags you into an epic story.
Thief - Deadly Shadows is a bit different than the first two games, but I loved it. It brings all the games together, making a full circle. Kind of Zen/taoism touch to it all, how the balance shifts due to your actions through the games.

Sadly... the fourth game, this one, is a letdown. I haven't played through it yet, I admit, the story might be as good as the other games. I don't know yet.
But then there's the reason I haven't played through it yet... and that's the controls for starters. It's made for consoles. you have few buttons to press, and those few buttons are supposed to do everything the keyboard did in the earlier games. If you for an example want to crouch behind some crates, your game might decide that you want to climb up on them instead. the same button is used for everything.
Needless to say, if you want to hide, standing on top of well lit crates is a bad idea.

I could live with that, but then there are annoying bugs aswell. I play the game as a thief not an assassin. There's a bug that requires you to kill people to move on. I hope it's a bug, because you're in a vent. someone passes below you, and you get the option to kill them. if you don't, they move on, and you can't get down from there. Ever.
There are more gamebreaking bugs I've found aswell, but i've ranted enough.

I want to love this game, but I can't.

reviewText:
When the first news about this game appeared, I couldn't get my arms down in cheer, but after having played through the main story and finished the game, I'm totally like WTF!!! Game is too short compared to Thief 1 and 2. This so called reboot is nothing like the Thief I used to know. The atmosphere of the game cant reach the atmosphere of the previous games. Dynamic music when spotted, why??? This isn't a FPS, this is a sneaker dammit!!! It doesn't need dynamic music. The city does not feel like the steampunk city that I used to like so well.
The general clothing is too modern, its like we moved from middle age to Victorian times and it does not feel right.
Garret is too obsessed with a girl, something the lone thief never has done before and it makes him a weak character with too much emotional crap involved.
The fact that you cant jump, only when you stand in front of crates designed to be jumped or when you can climb a wall, again designed to be climbed makes the possibilities very slim. Compared to thief 1 and 2 where you could use rope/wine arrows at wood and grates, you can only use rope arrows at certain spots designed to that, again a limitation to your movement. There are too many limitations in this game.
The game also features client jobs to be done, but none of these does actually appeals to be interesting enough to divert from the main storyline. The only reason to do these client jobs as to get gold enough for some extremely expensive perks, that aren't really needed anyway.
All in all this game feel like a console game addressed to the many FPS gamers out there with no taste for quality and only need some cheap thrills.

reviewText: Such promise.  Such horrific execution. Great graphics, interesting storyline...painfully repetitive and uninspired gameplay mechanics.  Horrible ending.  WTF happened? i still don't know. reviewText: I tried very hard to like this game. But there are simply too many problems with it. Everytime the game did something good, it was too little and too late into the game. The controls are very awkward and stiff. You can peak around corners which is a very cool mechanic and is actually necessary in order to carefully navigate the hallways. Vertical movement is limited to specific ledges and ropes that you are meant to navigate, and levels are very small and offer only a few different paths to navigate that all end up bringing you to the same place with hardly any advantages one way or the other. You are equiped with a variety of arrow types that can be used to help you move throughout the levels. The water arrows allow you to douse flames from a distance which is helpful for distractions. Rope arrows are useful for accessing hidden locations, but they feel more like they are required in order to collect all the loot rather than it being a fun optional path. Sneaking around is fun, but getting caught is never fun to escape from like other stealth games. You're better off just quickly restarting from your last checkpoint because the combat is terrible and the penalty for getting caught is so frustrating that there's no point in trying to hide. Other stealth games like Hitman" have fantastic combat that is fun to play out when you end up getting caught.. but thief's combat is just garbage and not worth the waste of 5 minutes before you reload your save. The saving grace of this game's gameplay is the stealth itself
date: which is good because this is a stealth game after all. You can quickly glide from shadow to shadow and you have to pay very close to attention to many fine details to avoid detection. I especially liked having to walk slowly on broken glass and carefully move around animals to avoid the guards getting suspicious. It's a shame this kind of effort can't be found in any of the other aspects of the game.\n\nThe graphics are bitter sweet. The lighting

reviewText:
I have never played that blunt and boring game in my life (and finished it).

Pros:
-	Dark gloomy atmosphere
-	Hideout + some of the locations are really creepy
-       Graphics is okay

Cons:
-	Dull combat system
-	Opening all these windows is so frustrating
-	Uninteresting plot
-	Boring enemies (except for the invisible monsters in hospital)
-	“On trails” all the time. Only one way to go and no choice!
-	Stupid last fight
-	Almost no dialogues
-	50% of the time I hoped the game will end soon
-	Never-ending night… seriously no daytime in the game's world WTF?
-	Tedious protagonist
-	Sneak system is... so bad...
-	I can’t believe I played 150 hours… That is over a week of my life nobody is giving me back…

Conclusion:
All in all... AVOID!

My rating: 2/10

reviewText:
This game would have been a solid 6.5/10 had it come out under it's own label. As a completely independant game with the freedom to create new ideas it may have even been a good game. However you cannot escape the inalienable fact that this is a sequel to Thief: The Dark Project and the subsequent games, therefore it should be a continuation of the story in the same narrative universe. This game fails to make use of the source material in any meaningful way. It is almost like the development team were given just the name Thief as the title, Garret as the protagonist and Basso as the fence and told to make a game about stealing stuff in early industrial revolution generic grey steampunk city. Maybe they didn't get usage rights for anything else, because thats what it feels like.

Garrets character is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ised from the word go. Gone is the aloof, cynical, selfish, anti-hero that only acts on other people behalf when it suits him, when there is no other option, or for revenge. Instead we are given a flat boring character that essentially denounces all of Garrets traits that the first game made us painstakingly aware of. All within the tutorial. What ever happened to 'I only work alone'. Adding to that the Keepers taught Garret to be invisible in a crowd in order to document history, but not interfere. Garret corrupted the teachings by using them  to be a stealthy thief. But in this game everyone seems to know who you are, even the 'Thief-Take General' (*rolls eyes). If the original Garret was in this situation, he would have just left. Why take unessisary risks.

The original games were setup as an unrestricted world puzzle where you felt that your own ingenuity, quick(slow) action and sensory feedback  allowed you to complete missions with a smug sense of statisfaction. This game is an pre-determined obstacle course for the player, complete with '90's sidescroller loot-that is impossible to get untill you know how-and has no earthly reason for being there'. There are points in the game where you try and not follow the pre-determined path because it is too risky, only to find it is the only way. Usually leading to a forced action cut scene where.... YOU GET CAUGHT.... In a game called... Thief. This doesn't just happen once, but all the time, followed by hell being raised as you try to scramble and escape along a new pre-determined path. I know that game designers need to up the ante, but this is just cliche at this point.

All in all this game would have been great as a prequel. Garret having freshly left the Keepers in order to persue a life of burglary of the wealthy and undeserving for his own gain. Working with people he initially trusts, who then betray him or die on the job. Hell... they could have even kept the main story elements intact. Maybe then we could have seen where Garrets dark personality came from in the first game and why he is behaving like such a noob in this one. But unfortunatly the games story line is irrevocably terrible.

Ultimatly game play and graphics are slightly above average. The inability to even try pay lip service to the original brings it down to a 4/10. Don't bother. Go play the originals. If you can't stand bad graphics get the story arc of Youtube.




What is with the obsession with The Claw!! Seriously I had Jim Carrey in my head every time they said it.

Edit: A note for Steven Gallagher. Head Narrative Director. Garret is not against killing 'without thought or good reason', he's not a conscientious assasin. Garret's rationale is that killing is messy, noisy and gets you caught. Again, would have been fine under it's own brand. The game probably would not have tanked.

reviewText: Pro - Graphically the game is gorgeous, fantastic use of volumetric lighting and really great texture work.\nCon - Game is disappointingly linear, to the extent that the full experience feels less like a game and more like a tech demo.

reviewText:
I have never played that blunt and boring game in my life (and finished it).

Pros:
-	Dark gloomy atmosphere
-	Hideout + some of the locations are really creepy
-       Graphics is okay

Cons:
-	Dull combat system
-	Opening all these windows is so frustrating
-	Uninteresting plot
-	Boring enemies (except for the invisible monsters in hospital)
-	“On trails” all the time. Only one way to go and no choice!
-	Stupid last fight
-	Almost no dialogues
-	50% of the time I hoped the game will end soon
-	Never-ending night… seriously no daytime in the game's world WTF?
-	Tedious protagonist
-	Sneak system is... so bad...
-	I can’t believe I played 150 hours… That is over a week of my life nobody is giving me back…

Conclusion:
All in all... AVOID!

My rating: 2/10

reviewText: I've played and beaten all of the Thief games, including this one, and I have to say that this incarnation is NOWHERE NEAR the quality of game mechanics, story, or level design as ANY of the previous games in this series.  I had high hopes upon loading this game for the first time given the sheer brilliance of the original games - this was quickly dashed as the linear, closed, languid environment was set before my eyes.  The graphics are nice, yes, but where is the ambiance?  Where is the quirkiness or the eccentricity of the townspeople and guards?  Where is the magic, the factions, the religious zealotry that I grew to love about the believable and engrossing world that encompasses everything about Thief?  Nowhere.  They have now decided that these things should be stripped out in place of a boring, lazy version of the game that simply takes less time and imagination to create.  I cannot recommend a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ization of such an amazing series of games.

reviewText:
I tried to like it. Unfortunately, there were way too many problems with the game.

First, the atmosphere is very spotty: at times the setting looks incredible! It's awesome to crawl around the streets, lurking in the shadows, or sneaking around the inside of some castle. Other times, it just looks ugly and lazily designed. The character designs are putrid; Garrett looks lame to say the least, and Erin... just terrible. I don't know who designed her. The characters were a major turnoff for me.

As far as the mechanics go, they're smooth and intuitive enough, but there isn't the same level of variety and openness to experimentation with one's toolset as there was in the original games. The stealth was fun, but very shallow and predictable overall. My favorite part of the game was actually just doing the side mission thievery in the sandbox area of the game given to you by Basso, I actually felt more like the original Garrett while doing those. But they're just minor side missions at the end of the day, so there's not much to speak of there, and it doesn't improve the overall game a whole lot.

I bumped into quite a few glitches while playing as well, mostly with the AI. They'd get stuck in their patrol paths, following some crazy loop for eternity, or they'd get stuck in the environment in some way. Sometimes the lighting bugged out on me and I was caught for no reason.

To top it all off, the ending was also terrible. That final boss" was completely unnecessary and ruined whatever dramatic buildup the game's story had so far managed to establish
date: for me at least. I mean the game isn't 0/10 worst ♥♥♥♥ I ever played
recommended: but it's just not good — it's somewhere around 5/10 for me."

reviewText: Garrett didn’t need a reboot, nor if we’re honest did he really need a comeback. He had two excellent games and the third episode didn’t mess things up too badly.\n\nThere’s enough good in Thief to convince me that Eidos had all the moving parts required to herald the return of the Master Thief in style. reviewText:
I'm old school Thief fan. Played T1/2/3 and i loved them all. One of best games ever made in my private ranking.
So i was pretty xcited when they annouced Thief in 2014.

And honestly - this is the worst Thief series game,
and very avarage sneaking game.

First bigest disappointment - they replaced Stephen Russell as voice actor. His voice acting was what made thief so unique.

Next thing - they decided to abandon typical for thief series cutscenes. WHY?! I loved them, they were very climatic. Maybe it's  just stupid little thing, dunno. But try imagining next fallout game without its well known intro (war, war never changes).

As for game difficulty, devs did absolutely great work making this game one of easiest i played lately. Not even close to original Thief.

1. No loud floors (and moss arrows), somethies shards of glass but most of the time its not a problem to run whole level! yes, press shift and run, if too close to guars - you will get sound notification.
2. New 'swoop' feature allows to exploit almost every guard, in any possible situation.  Absolutely no need of using water arrows now, just swoop and dim lights with you fingers.
3. Level design - IMO too linear and too simple. Small amount of non-guard npcs make levels even poorer.
4. Almost every guard i considered that might be an issue was scripted so when i approached he moved somwhere else for few seconds allowing me to quickly swoop behind him.Seriously? Whats next? Patrols that automaticly turn around when they get too close to you?
5. Focus - another game after Hitman and Tomb Raider that has this feature implemented. The game is very easy without it so i cant understand whats the logic behind it.
6. Boring and repetitive city missions. Every single one takes about 1-2 minute to finish and offer no variety.
7. Client jobs - max 10 minutes to finish, with maybe 2 levels really interesting and original.
8. Guards are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, they will almost instanly forget anything they saw or heard after few seconds of inspecting.

The controls:
Master thief cannot jump. Joke of the year. He jumps only when he's close to rope or a gap. You get one key and game decides for you whether you want to jump or swoop or climb. This 'feature' is major set back, FPP with no 'maunal' jumping implemented. Like in first Doom games. Next Thief will have one key binded for everything.

Overall: 5 out of 10 in my personal score incudling sentimental factor.

Oh BTW, visually this game is really hot, audio is also pretty good, but the game lacks everything else.

The only good thing about this game is how i really want to play old Thief(s) again.

To Square EnixŁ You guys made excellent Deus Ex remake. What the hell went wrong here?

reviewText:
I was really revved up for this game since I'm a fan of Dark Shadows but this was... really lackluster in comparison.

Tech wise, the game was way too high def. I can max Skyrim (with mods turned on) on Ultra, Tomb Raider on High and ect. on my computer but I couldn't even MOVE with Thief even on NORMAL settings! Early on in the game I experienced glitches that kept getting worse throughout gameplay. Characters spinning around in a circle, models in the T position, characters stuck when on high alert mode.  There were also some whacked out audio levels.  Music was low, SFX mid and character voices higher but some character voices you would hear off in the distance (like during an angry mob crowd) then suddenly BOOMING VOICE RIGHT THERE of another mob character. Sometimes I couldn't even HEAR Garrett earlier when he talked!

Gameplay, w ooow. I enjoyed the mechanics but it was too easy. I was playing on Master mode and everything was just mostly simple. I was expecting better responses from the NPCs but it mostly got a bit harder at the end but that was it.  The monsters too? I was disappointed in them. The final battle? Holy CRAP was I disappointed. That was honestly one of the easiest boss battles I'd ever fought and I was hella disappointed. Hella.  The second to last boss was actually HARDER than the final one.

I really enjoy this franchise. I had a lot of fun sneaking around and thinking of ways of getting around but I was honestly expecting something better /especially/ since Square Enix, although published it, has their name on it and after seeing the trailers, screenshots and demos, I expected something awesome.  Really awesome.  But nah, it just became a rated B game, unfortunately.

I only recommend if you're a fan of Thief and just want to see Garrett again (<3) or are a fan of stealth games. Give it a shot otherwise this is one to just buy on discount.

reviewText: I've only gotten to chapter 2 of the game and I'm having technical issues. The game freezes and completely locks up my computer. I've followed all troubleshooting advice with no effect. I currently have a ticket in tech support but I have a feeling they are going to tell me to uninstall and re-install. Now only being on chapter 2 that wouldn't be too bad but I've read on the forums that the same problem happens in Chapter 6 as well. This is why I don't normally buy games when they first come out. It seems companies are so hell bent on releasing games to get money with no concern whether or not they are playable. You can't tell me that the developers did not know about this issue with beta testing. I had this same problem with Assassins Creed and I didn't play it for a year because I was waiting for them to patch the problem.\n\nUntil this happened I was enjoying playing the game but take that with a grain of salt because that is only about an hour of play time. My computer DOES meet the recommended requirements. I'll update if/when I hear back from tech support.

reviewText:
OK, so I was going to give this game a good review. I had finished up to the ending of chapter two thinking that aside from some slight glitches the game was overall pretty solid.

There was this small part of town I had to pass through on my way to the third chapter. I found my way into this back alley section where there was a bit of loot and was on my way back out when I noticed the the AI was now frozen in place instead of following their patrol routes. The issue was that there were now two guards staring at each other blackly, one staring down the alley I was to come from.

After several failed attempts to get by them I finally just ran back to the gate that loaded this section of the map, alerting everyone in the process. Upon activation of said door, the game came up with a message that it was saving my game which was a little unusal since there is an autosave function it normally uses. Upon loading of the town map, the game somehow loaded me back into chapter one and saved over my game so I can't even go back to where I had gotten stuck.

Maybe I only but well developed games or something but this is the first time I've run into a glitch like this. I do have a save from chapter two but only from mid chapter and I'm not sure I really even want to bother playing it over again.

I enjoyed the game besides this issue but I'm probably just going to pass seeing as it could just happen again.

reviewText: Solid stealth game with unfortunate flaws\nAt its core, Thief is a great and intense stealth game. Hiding behind corners, lurking in the shadows, stealing that shiny jewel and waiting for the perfect moment to vanish unseen works and feels great. Your tools (mainly a bow with different arrow types), your abilities and the environment work together sweetly and create a fluid and very enjoyable stealth experience. Also, replay value is high. I often found myself playing levels multiple times - trying out different paths, trying not to take out anybody, trying to complete all challenges and so on. The city"

reviewText:
I have played it through.
To be honest at the end it was just to finish it, for the sake of finishing it.
It is not totally rubbish. It can be enjoyed, particularly if you don't have any preconcieved nostalgia (I played all originals and enjoyed them a lot more than this, but that was a long time ago).

Bad
-Characters are shallow
-Repetative environments
-QT like events to open windows, transition to areas, no point as can't fail just mash E for the sake of it.
-QT like take downs
-The city is a bit bland, and traversing it seems like a chore after the first time
-Feels like they rushed it in the end and didn't polish it properly

Good
-Stealth
-Some interesting levels and story discoverys
-A couple of engrossing startle moments
-Don't have to return to quest giver to get reward

I would not have bought it if it was not part of a bundle that made it super cheap.
I am Glad that I didn't pay full price.

reviewText: A review from a newbie gamer (aka me):\n\nI loved this game till Chapter 5 where it screwed with my head in an Insane Asylum. I'm not a fan of horror games.  But (at least till Chapter 5) this game is really nice. The wonderful graphics, the stealth, strategy, looting and parkour are all something you'd want to come back to after a long day. And the story is interesting. Slightly weird, but interesting. Only because of the story I desperately tried to continue playing through Chapter 5 but.. no. Just no. Can't. Nope. The game developers did a good job though.

reviewText:
Despite hate from older fans of the series, Thief 2014 is good game in its own right. Think Dishonored with a talking protagonist, less combat, and more stealing.

Pros:
++Smooth movement, rarely get hung-up and terrain is well defined.
++Stealing is fun, as you must be quick and careful to succeed.
+Interesting levels and enviroment, even if it is stereotypically gloomy.
+Spooky asylum level would've been right at home in a horror game.
+Rewards the completion of challenges based on different playstyles, similar to Mark of the Ninja.


Mixed:

reviewText:
It was okay.

Took about 20 hours of gameplay to beat and I barely understood the plot that was happening throughout the game. As I pushed further into the game I became less interested in being stealthy since it wasn't as satisfying, so I just started hitting people in the head with an arrow, and not going too far out of my way for extra loot.  I enjoyed parts, however by the second to last chapter I found myself looking forward to completing the game and moving on to a new one.

Eventually I did comple the game, and the ending left me confused without any sense of closure.  Reflecting on the plot and it's characters, I realize neither had a great deal of depth in the first place.

reviewText: I'm going to put this out there from the beginning: I adore the original Thief games, and the first two easily rank as two of my favorite games of all time. I find myself going back to them repeatedly over the years, starting from the easiest difficulty my first run when I was a kid, to beating it on expert multiple times. Each game had its own atmosphere, its own story, each fleshed out and gripping while retaining what made Thief, well Thief.\n\nYou feel like Garrett, you feel like a Master Thief knowing that if you screw up and get seen, you're a dead man. That never changed between the games, a constant that grounded each game to eachother You Are Garrett
date: Master Thief". Yet each game had a setting an atmosphere all its own

reviewText: I wouldn't spend any money on this if you were a fan of the old games. The Pagans and Hammerites of the old City are gone, and I almost feel like they just gutted everything that made the original series setting so unique. It's just a standard Victorian ero type place where the rich tend to screw over the poor and the poor all have the plague. Gameplay wise, there's just nothing new that I saw or at least noticed. It's also pretty linear, which does not serve it all that well. What? You wanted to *explore* WELL I'M SORRY BUT TOUCHING THAT SHELF JUST TRIGGERED AN IRREVERSIBLE EVENT. CAN'T GO BACK NOW. I GUESS YOU JUST HAVE TO DEAL WITH IT, TAFFER!\n\nThere are some fun moments, yeah, but... It's not Thief anymore. It's an okay game on its own, but it isn't a Thief game, if that makes sense.
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Story: awful.  'We're all big fans of the original Thief games and so we wanted to....nah, just kidding.  None of us give a ♥♥♥♥.'
Engine: awful.  Judders around while it loads in like a fat man in an earthquake.
Design: awful.  All the quirky stuff from the originals has been removed: funky beasties, religious elements, magic/techno hybrids.  And 'Garrett' is apparently on his way to a S&M club.  For goths.  In stuff that looks like it takes 3 hours to put on.

Assuming you can get past what a horrendous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥isation it is of the original games, its actually alright to play.  Mostly.  Swoop is an interesting addition, you are no longer entirely invisible at 6 inches, and you are still nicking stuff. Still suffers from stupid decisions (no fast travel, christ this gets old fast; REPEATEDLY TAP BUTTON FOR NO REASON AT ALL; missions of dementedly variable length; crappy side missions that take you to the other side of the city (see: fast travel) for worthless reward).

Bonus negative points for 'Wow, Shalebridge Cradle was a good level, lets make it worse.'  'What we need is a really ♥♥♥♥ villain of the piece, who isn't remotely intimidating but is absolutely laughable in a bad way.'  'Pffff, a decent voice actor for the player character (and a decent scriptwriter) is overrated.'

reviewText:
TL;DR: All in all I'd say buy the game, if its on sale. I paid $15 for it and my 23 hours of play time was worth that. I plan on finishing out some of the extra side content and that will probably round out the value of the game for me.

Disclaimer: I haven't played the previous (original) Thief games.

ALSO MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS. I wouldn't consider them spoilers, but if you're a purist I figured I'd warn you.

This game was a few ups and downs for me. It started off pretty great. I was really enjoying the idea of being a master thief. Sneaking around and being able to find my way into different places on the map. As the game went on though you learn that you obtained special powers; that if you focus really hard" things become clearer.

This is were I had my first down. I was expecting this to just become a cop-out over the rest of the game. Giving you god-like abilities (a la Dishonored) in a situation where you seem to be just a normal guy we some practiced thieving abilities (unlike Dishonored which made the powers an integral mechanic of the game). For most of the game these powers
recommended: did not make you god-like. You are fragile enough (without "massive upgrades") that if you don't at least attempt to stay hidden and sneak around
hoursPlayed: you WILL be punished. You certainly aren't a damage drinker like you would be in a Call of Duty game. This made for a fun play through with some good challenges in many areas. I must say though that if you're looking for the "choose your own path" approach this is where this game seems to falter again.\nThere are clearly places in the game at which you are funneled into a specific path. Usually at these choke points if you were playing a Ghost playthrough you are going to have a stupidly difficult time trying to pass it
voteText: when a Predator
helpfulPercent: or an Opportunist
votesHelpful: will pass it in a matter of seconds. It feels like it's an artificial difficulty spike. If each play-style is apparently weighted the same then don't make areas that are stupidly difficult for just one of them. This of course is just my opinion. Maybe I missed something in the surroundings that could have made it easier
votesTotal: and so my opinions may be unfounded.\n\nThe last up and down came towards the end of the game. I was enjoying how the story was developing and how the levels were becoming longer
votesFunny: demanding a more thought out approach to each level. This all came to a head
commentsCount: though
column16: when you reach the last story mission. Here you end up put in multiple situations in which the game is effectively linear. You have to reach ONE door
column17: or ONE opening
column18: to proceed (if there were more openings I must be blind because I spent forever on that last mission searching places). In a game that sold itself as you being able to choose how you get places this was a kick in the teeth. The last mission
column19: the one where everything is supposed to come together
column20: validate your experience

column22: one-size-fits-all experience. It felt like everything I had done for the rest of the game didn't really matter. I lost any choice that I could have and that spoiled the times when I did have choice. It wasn't just the lack of choice that really spoiled the end for me

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of the original series, Thief II: The Metal Age being my favorite game of all time. Compared to the originals, even the 3rd one which doesn't hold a candle to 1 & 2, this is an abortion. This is what happens when you spend 6 years making a game, with frequent changes in the design staff leadership, and attempting to turn a niche game into something with a wider audience based solely on market research. In all honesty, what makes it so bad is comparing it to the originals. If this was just a standalone IP, it might not seem so bad. Not great, but not awful. It'd be about average of the market today, which really isn't something to be proud of. Now of  course people might say Hey
date: you can't really compare it to the originals because it's a reboot and it's 2014 and blah blah." But I call ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t on that. If they didn't want people to compare it to the originals

then they shouldn't have used that IP.

reviewText: I wouldn't spend any money on this if you were a fan of the old games. The Pagans and Hammerites of the old City are gone, and I almost feel like they just gutted everything that made the original series setting so unique. It's just a standard Victorian ero type place where the rich tend to screw over the poor and the poor all have the plague. Gameplay wise, there's just nothing new that I saw or at least noticed. It's also pretty linear, which does not serve it all that well. What? You wanted to *explore* WELL I'M SORRY BUT TOUCHING THAT SHELF JUST TRIGGERED AN IRREVERSIBLE EVENT. CAN'T GO BACK NOW. I GUESS YOU JUST HAVE TO DEAL WITH IT, TAFFER!\n\nThere are some fun moments, yeah, but... It's not Thief anymore. It's an okay game on its own, but it isn't a Thief game, if that makes sense.

reviewText:
Story: awful.  'We're all big fans of the original Thief games and so we wanted to....nah, just kidding.  None of us give a ♥♥♥♥.'
Engine: awful.  Judders around while it loads in like a fat man in an earthquake.
Design: awful.  All the quirky stuff from the originals has been removed: funky beasties, religious elements, magic/techno hybrids.  And 'Garrett' is apparently on his way to a S&M club.  For goths.  In stuff that looks like it takes 3 hours to put on.

Assuming you can get past what a horrendous ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥isation it is of the original games, its actually alright to play.  Mostly.  Swoop is an interesting addition, you are no longer entirely invisible at 6 inches, and you are still nicking stuff. Still suffers from stupid decisions (no fast travel, christ this gets old fast; REPEATEDLY TAP BUTTON FOR NO REASON AT ALL; missions of dementedly variable length; crappy side missions that take you to the other side of the city (see: fast travel) for worthless reward).

Bonus negative points for 'Wow, Shalebridge Cradle was a good level, lets make it worse.'  'What we need is a really ♥♥♥♥ villain of the piece, who isn't remotely intimidating but is absolutely laughable in a bad way.'  'Pffff, a decent voice actor for the player character (and a decent scriptwriter) is overrated.'

reviewText:
TL;DR: All in all I'd say buy the game, if its on sale. I paid $15 for it and my 23 hours of play time was worth that. I plan on finishing out some of the extra side content and that will probably round out the value of the game for me.

Disclaimer: I haven't played the previous (original) Thief games.

ALSO MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS. I wouldn't consider them spoilers, but if you're a purist I figured I'd warn you.

This game was a few ups and downs for me. It started off pretty great. I was really enjoying the idea of being a master thief. Sneaking around and being able to find my way into different places on the map. As the game went on though you learn that you obtained special powers; that if you focus really hard" things become clearer.

This is were I had my first down. I was expecting this to just become a cop-out over the rest of the game. Giving you god-like abilities (a la Dishonored) in a situation where you seem to be just a normal guy we some practiced thieving abilities (unlike Dishonored which made the powers an integral mechanic of the game). For most of the game these powers
recommended: did not make you god-like. You are fragile enough (without "massive upgrades") that if you don't at least attempt to stay hidden and sneak around
hoursPlayed: you WILL be punished. You certainly aren't a damage drinker like you would be in a Call of Duty game. This made for a fun play through with some good challenges in many areas. I must say though that if you're looking for the "choose your own path" approach this is where this game seems to falter again.\nThere are clearly places in the game at which you are funneled into a specific path. Usually at these choke points if you were playing a Ghost playthrough you are going to have a stupidly difficult time trying to pass it
voteText: when a Predator
helpfulPercent: or an Opportunist

Maybe I missed something in the surroundings that could have made it easier
votesTotal: and so my opinions may be unfounded.\n\nThe last up and down came towards the end of the game. I was enjoying how the story was developing and how the levels were becoming longer

The gameplay leaves tons to be desired and I'm not saying that in comparison to the old games but just as a game, it's not very good. I have played all the previous thief games and this one is definetily the worst but if I have to compare, I'd say that it's the most like thief 3 (deadly shadows).
I say that because the whole game has a hub world so to say and from there you travel around to different levels in the game, just like thief 3. The greatest problem for me with this game is that I don't have the feeling of control that I'm used to. You can't jump and alot of times you feel locked to the enviroment as if you were on rails.
