reviewText:
Pathetic attempt at modernizing a classic series. These younger developers haven't learned from the past, believing that QTE's and nice animations make for some fun gameplay. While the world in Thief is quite pretty, Dishonored seems to have really taken the mantle as what constitutes as the new stealth king. Thief lacks a jump button, the designers seem to think that being a master thief AND a free runner, the jump button isn't nessary. The entire world is contextural, you can only do what the small minded designers want you to do. Forget about using the rope arrow to explore the different options of getting into a building, there's only ONE place to use that. While the textures and lighting is nice, the world is too small and cramped, it seems that the City has shrunk.

Why is it that the modern designers think that every game has to be like Assassin's Creed? or Call of Duty. If I wanted to play an Assassin's Creed game, I would, but these days publishers seem to think that everything should be like that. Lack of real good gameplay makes this seem like a glorified tech demo.
Stay away from this unless you like dumbed down games and watching cutscenes which is basically every younger gamer out there and that makes me sad for the future of games.
This reboot should have never happened and I want my money back on this turd.

Ok, three hours into this and yes it's still quite simple and no real challenge. Remember that the designers couldn't make a GOOD game due to the console limitations. I still think that this game is not very good.

Now I am 5 hours in, and while the only thing that I really like about this game is the movement, but the lack of a jump button, dedicated lean keys and just bad level design really make this game more suitable to the console player with its simplistic control scheme and general hand-holding, the game will play itself, and solve all the puzzles for you if the designers were allowed to. Hence, this game really lacks any imagination and freedom of movement that the previous games had, including a JUMP button. Thanks, Edios for ♥♥♥♥ing up another franchise.

6 Hours in and while I like the way you move, it has a nice weight and smooth movement the lack of freedom in the levels make this a neutered piece of crap. Why am I still playing? i paid 10 bucks for this turd and I plan on finishing it. The level design so far is quite ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Small areas and lack of choice are what drags this down. I miss being able to stack and move crates, getting stuck on a box, unable to jump OR climb on shows that the designers don't know how to make good gameplay. Console players will feel right at home with this, the game will actually play it self. One long cutscene, this is what modern" gameplay is

reviewText: If you're a hardcore Thief-fan, this game is definitely not for you. I was more than a little disappointed with all the deviations this game makes from the original Thief-series. Already at the main menu, you can hear the music is more like that of an action movie, rather than the fearful noises and tunes found in Thief. The next thing you notice is that they're using a new voice actor, which is really a pity, but as you play you'll find that this new Garett does a real good job in mimicking the original Thief voice. However the language of the previous thief games is gone, replaced with a more modern and American linguistic. Next, the character of the City. The city atmosphere is completely different, more akin to a medieval city with christian chapels, rather than the conflict between hammerites and pagans. The city's secret order seems to be completely gone, replaced by an old blind lady in some ruins - a poor and cliché-like replacement. Finally, the levels. It seems each map is divided into sealed compartments. You only get one chance to loot each compartment, and each compartment can only be progressed from one entry, and left by one exit. What was once open maps, and an open city, is now more or less a straight path on rails (at least that's the feeling I got while playing). Still, for people who can accept some deviation, this game represents a good addition to the stealth game genre. Voice acting is good, cut scenes are well-made, and maps are very well designed. The game looks stunning, and there's definitely some fun to be had, which is why I can actually recommend playing this game.

reviewText:
The thing about Thief is it doesn't know what it wants to be.

And I'm gonna explain in my convoluted drawn out review style, enjoy the paragraphs.

This entry in the Thief game was hyped up a lot by Thief fans, stealth fans, and others (me for one) in general.
I never played the other Thief games, but everyone knows that they are critically acclaimed, and for good reason, however this entry, or Thief 4, is the black sheep.

When I mentioned Thief doesn't know what it wants to be, I meant it wasn't sure if it wanted to be an action game (from the bow and arrow bits), or a stealth game, if it wants to be a stealth game it's very clunky, and Garret feels like he's carrying an elephant, if it wants to be an action game, the fighting is easy and you get a lot of leeway for bow kills.

Honestly this deserves comparison to recent successful stealth titles, notably Deus Ex: Human Revolution, and Dishonored, especially since it feels like Thief drew a lot from Dishonored, but still ended up a boring game.
In both titles you could fight your way through to the target, or stealth your way to the target, either method worked great and felt really rock solid, in Thief it feels watered down.

The setting of the story is something of note as well, the devs mentioned Garret would not get involved with the current politics, rather just weave through it to serve his own needs. Yea uh...no, and its disappointing because a spectator" point of view from Garret would have been great
date: but instead you gotta get involved to save your jailbait friend who got caught.\n\nThis game is a conundrum

reviewText:
When I first knew about this reboot, I had never played the previous games (at the time), and based on the reviews of them and the features of the previews, I decided to pre-order the game, and I don't regret it. But it could have been much better. Below are the main pros and cons:

Pros:
- Great graphics and excellent art direction, with are very effective in giving a oppressive, glooming but beautiful settings. A fortunate detail is that is possible to see almost Garret's entire body, unlike other first-person games.

- Easy, fluid and immersive playability. Though it should have a jump button, I rarely missed it when I was playing.

- Solid stealth options: places to hide, shadows, distractions

- Offers multiple approachs to pass through the levels, as well as lots of exploration.

- Customization of difficulty, with several handicaps to increase substatianlly the challenge.

- Great side-quests, more open-ended than main campaign. I particularly enjoyed a lot the bank heist mission.

Cons
- Story, characters, dialogues: easily (for me) the worst flaws of the game. For starters, it occurs in a completely different timeline from the classic games, many years after their events, so none of the original characters appear here, even Garrett, which here is someone else. The plot is so incomplete, with so many doubts, plot holes and questions unansewerd or dealt incoherently. Examples: the so-called Baron is often mentioned as someone very important for The City and so, but only appers TWICE during the whole game, in short appearances; the Thief-Taker General appears only in incovenient moments and is always misplaced; and Garrett himself is a shadow (pun intended) of his former self; plenty of times he is so sloppy during the campaign that makes arguable the Master Thief" nickname. And the ending... WTF. So abrupted and frustrating
date: it's like they had run out of time (or/and ideas) and decided to just end there. If not for the several notes found in the levels to understand the lore it would be much worse. No wonder Rhianna Pratchett (yes
recommended: the same from the last Tomb Raider) refused (and still refuses) to talk about the game

reviewText:
I recommend it if it`s a great sale.

Where to start with Thief? It's very tempting to compare it to the good Thief game, the metal age, but that's just going to make me angry and disappointed. So let me talk about Thief as if I never heard of this franchise before.

I played it on master difficulty and it was hard, but the wrong kind of hard. The detection system is unpredictable, sometimes I can walk behind a guard sometimes I can't, sometimes I can stand in front of a guard in the dark, sometimes I can't. Sometimes the guards arrange themselves into impossible configurations (impossible without being detected) because they have some dialogue scripted that doesn't trigger, because they are stuck on a wall or somethign like that. The level design is generally bad and filled with this kinds of problems.

Now, these levels were made by talented designers, so what  the hell happened? I'm not sure but I have a theory. You see, level design of stealth games is the trickiest thing there is. Take a good working level and rotate one of the guards, now it's an impossible level. It's that finicky. In Thief they created this upgrade system that encompass everything, your equipment, your movements, stealth etc and that's a huge problem for the level designer. This worked on Deus Ex because DX is a game meant to be played in several different ways, so the level design doesn't have to be so tightly locked to a playstyle. You give the player options but you can be sure that it has other solutions. Upgrade system is a bit trendy right now so they blindly included it in Thief and it broke the game.

City hub. It didn't work in Deadly Shadows, it didn't work here. The reason is very simple, stealth is 75% puzzle-like, there's no fun in solving the same puzzle again, making city hub/open world thing unfun for most of the time. It works on games without puzzle elements, like car games, action shooting etc. It's a bit trendy right now so they blindly included city hub/ open world in Thief and it broke the game.

The story is all over the place. It's strange, there's a lot of details on the world itself but the story is broken.

Yet another mediocre sequel to an excellent and classic game. I have no hopes anymore, Thief will be like Star Wars, where the bad stuff outweights the good stuff. I understand it's not entirely their (the devs) fault. Most of what made the original games special go against the current trends in game design, and it's hard to tell the person that is investing all the money that your game will have none of this open world silliness, upgrade system, RPG elements and all these things that seem to sell games nowadays, and that the graphics will not be up to par with the current generation because we have to compromise something in order to have larger maps. It's not an easy sales pitch and it's a lot of money we're talking about here! But, who knows, maybe Eidos goes crazy and decides to make a worthy sequel despite its risks, or sell the ip to someone who will, whatever comes first.

reviewText:
tl;dr Grab it for 5-10 bucks on sale if you want a below-average stealth game, else skip it.

First of all: I haven't played the original Thief games, so I don't know what all you series fans did expect or are missing. Playing through the story missions (eight; nine if you count the prologue) took me about 9 1/2h on normal difficulty whereas I consider myself a solid stealth player. I couldn't really follow the story to be honest, I got a rough idea but the flat enactment and missing depth of the characters led to general disinterest. Which is sad as the atmosphere can get quite tense and the world as a whole is nicely set up.

Stealth gameplay works okay, A.I. is bugged sometimes tho. Guards (I've only seen two or three different types during my playthrough btw) should recognize me when I touch them even on normal difficulty, eh? Close combat is rather clunky but handling one or two guards shouldn't pose a problem. Garretts bow is his all-in-one-gear: use it to kill guards, disctract guards, stun guards, blow up guards and also extinguish flames.

You can buy more or less useful additional equipment from merchants which you can rarely find in The City. Inventory management is a pain though, you can't purchase arrows or healing items directly to the storage in your residence" and are forced to pay a visit to the merchant every single ♥♥♥♥♥♥ time you need to restock. Incredibly annoying. Thief also offers a completly redundant skill system which has next-to-no impact on gameplay at all.

Speaking about skill
date: Nixxes software showed their dedication to create great PC versions of games once more. Thief is very well optimized and ran with a constant 1080p60 on my i5 4570 & HD 7870 with everything except SSAO maxed out. The game can't be considered Crysis 4 or anything but offers great lightning and shadows which is quite essential to such a thiefy game in my opinion. You can really see how consoles held back the game in terms of textures since many of them - including commonly seen as close up like windows and doors - lack detail and could have used a higher resolution. Also
recommended: loading times occur too often. They are short still annoying. Whatever

reviewText:
I'm honestly shocked I've spent so long playing this game -- perhaps I was trying to get my money's worth?

Where to start:

* Sound: is poor. Not just the effects themselves, which trend generically, but also the mix. It's impossible to echo-locate, everything's so loud. Guards sound like they're next to you when they're not.

* Level Design: the hub world is broken into chunks by fat loading screens disguised by the repetitive jimmying of windows or squeezing past the same propped beam. Actual levels tend to lack the sand-box qualities of earlier titles, tending towards linear play. The game locks you into ridiculous set-pieces encounters at odds with the game's mechanics (a boss fight, timed action set-pieces) that look expensive and play cheaply.

* Narrative: poor. Derivative nonsense, poorly rendered. Performances vary, but tend to be broad in a way that clashes with the self-important tone. Narrative grace notes pointlessly nasty, ending illogical, leaves a bad taste in the mouth.

Masochists only.
voteText: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've been quite disappointed with this game, not through any comparison to the original Thief, but simply due to the quality of the game itself. The story itself is poorly written and at times makes no sense, almost as if whole chunks of it have just been left out. I also just didn't *care* about any of the characters or what happened next. Loading times sometimes occur when you wouldn't expect, like going through a window to a room within a level which already incurred a loading time to enter. Audio is poorly implemented with a lot of delays versus what is happening, and especially versus the subtitles on screen.

I did find myself enjoying some of the puzzles, but for each decent puzzle there are a couple of other muddly ones.

One saving grace perhaps is the look and feel of the environments you explore; this aspect of the game has had plenty of thought put into it and has lots of great detail to discover, but its not enough to make up for the above points and I didn't enjoy the core gameplay enough to really explore.

I kept giving the game a chance to improve which took me to about 8 hours, and since then I have decided to at least try and play it through to completion, but in general I wouldn't recommend the game to others.

One after another of this games coming out are so lackluster, you start thinking, why did they even bother putting the game out. They push the games back because they are having some type of problems with them. What problems? The city, rooms or general enviorments are flat and no interaction can be had. I wouldn't even say it's fine for a $20.00 game, it's not. Unless you are so hard up for a new or newer game, I suggest passing up on this train wreck of a, I don't want to say game, but that is the only thing I guess I can call it without censorship.

reviewText:
This game is difficult to write a review for. It ranges from brilliant to extremely obnoxious and in the end manages to be a flawed, okay game that really could have been great. It took me about 22 hours with quite a bit of exploring, not killing or knocking anyone out, and doing all of the side missions. If you rushed through the main story it would be MUCH shorter than that.

First things first, the actual thieving is great. The missions are, for the most part, well designed, and they have a good variety. Attempting to steal as much loot as possible without being detected really does have its thrills. Swooping in, stealing something while a guard's back is turned, and swooping back to the shadows feels immensely rewarding. The stealth is well done, and there is a variety of tools and upgrades (if you choose to use them) at your disposal. Most of the levels have quite a few different paths you can take. The Bank Heist DLC / preorder bonus is also quite fun, but probably not worth 5 dollars.

Many kudos to the game for the wide variety of difficulty options, graphic options, HUD options, etc. Pretty much every HUD item can be turned off, and you can adjust the difficulty and change various things (knockout/kills not allowed, no focus, no reticle for your bow, expensive resources, etc). There's even an iron man mode (die and it's over). Really, I can't give them enough props for this. Well Done.

On to the bad. The City, or the 'open world' portion of the game, is tedious at best and absolutely annoying at worst. I feel like this was tacked on due to the popularity of open world games, and in the end it really suffers for it. The game would have been better off without the entire city. It's neat that there is random hidden loot everywhere, but trust me, by the end of the game you'll be really tired of running across the same strange paths, dodging the same guards walking the same paths, and hearing the same dialogue lines. If I have to hear about why that one guard doesn't reek of ♥♥♥♥ anymore... Oh, and if you decide to turn on 'expensive resources', get ready for side missions to be pretty obnoxious to do. Expensive resources makes rope arrows 450g, and you often need one to get to an uninteresting side mission that will net you 50-100g.

Speaking of guards, the guard AI is, in a world, terrible. I can't hold this against them too much, as stealth games sort of thrive on terrible enemy AI (WHERE DID HE GO? ~5 seconds later~ IT WAS PROBABLY NOTHING), but I think it's worth mentioning.

I didn't experience any crash to desktops or graphical problems, but the game does have a few audio bugs. Sometimes guards would say the same piece of dialogue twice in a row, on top of each other, so you'd hear it twice. Othertimes the audio would go out of sync during a cutscene, or other audio would be playing when it shouldn't have been. There was one mission where I couldn't hear Garrett's voice over the sounds of the game. Again, not serious, but worth noting.

So overall, would I recommend this? Maybe-- To the right person. If you can slog through the city and the other undesirable parts, there really is some fun to be had. The story isn't fantastic, but the setting is interesting enough and the thieving is fun.

And finally, this game really isn't anything like Dishonored. Really, it's not. Corvo is a highly trained magical assassin who specializes in murdering dudes as quickly as possible. Garrett is a thief. He steals things. He says, during the prologue, something like I don't just kill people." People will want to compare the two because they're both first person stealth games
date: but they really are not similar games. I cannot stress this enough. Do not expect this to be like Dishonored."

reviewText:
I hardly ever write reviews, but here's my two-cents.

While the game has an okay graphical style, the gameplay is just so old school. The stealth in this game is far from perfect. It seems like this game wasn't thoroughly tested, or was just neglected to make proper changes. It seems more like an Alpha phase for the game.

Stealth:

So when you're walking around concealed in the shadows, hostiles cannot see you at all unless you're close and in their peripheral vision. What's dumb is sometimes I will knock out a hostile NPC from the shadows and every guard around him will immediately turn into super hostile mode and come straight for me. Three seconds before that I was invisible to everyone. This mechanic is broken as far as I'm concerned.

What should happen is if the guards around the guard I'm knocking out somehow notice what's happening, they should not instantly go into super hostile mode and come straight for me for the kill. They should just investigate. It's more connected to what you see in movies. No I don't want exact realism in every single game I play because that wouldn't be fun, but I do want new mechanics. This is 2014, not 2005.

The Bow:

While the bow you have is a great tool, I think the way it works is also broken as far as I'm concerned. Number one, it makes a lot of noise when you're pulling on it. You would think a master thief would have a near-silent bow. If there was a realistic noise mechanic (which sometimes there's an overly dramatic one which I'll get to next) then every guard in the area would be investigating the area because I decided to shoot a rope arrow.

The rope arrow mechanic is also something super dumb. You cannot shoot the rope arrow just anywhere to climb. No, you have to shoot it at specific spots just like in Tomb Raider for it to do anything. This is such an old mechanic, it's stupid.

I could go on about the bow and how it is poorly implmented but it's not worth any more of my time.

Last but not least, the noise mechanic:

While playing the game you will often encounter things in the environment that will cause nearby guards to investigate your position. There's also birds and dogs in cages that will somehow always see you when you swoop (swoop is a near silent movement, by the way), which will also alert the nearby guards of something in your position (you) and cause them to investigate.

Other things you'll encounter are randomly broken glass in the environment that you have to walk slow on or everything around you (even birds and dogs) will be alerted and will investigate your position. Even if you swoop (shadowstep) it will make noise on the glass and will alert nearby hostiles. This mechanic is broken.

The swoop is not a running mechanic, it's more like a shadow-step mechanic yet it makes noise? This is broken as far as I'm concerned and overlooked by the developers and publishing company.

I could go on, but this game is not worth your time or money.

reviewText:
Love the voice acting and dialogue.  I've found myself actually laughing at quite a few of the conversations I've eavesdropped on. Eavesdropping can also alert the player to potential loot locations. The designers implemented great animations for Garret for when he opens a chest, picks a lock, searches for a hidden switch, or extinguishes a flame further adding to the game immersion. **The plot has been interesting so far** and Thief has wonderful graphics.

Now The Cons:

1. The light meter in Thief is a piece of junk. I can't tell you how many times I would hear my thief-sense" warning me that someone was about to see me even though I am completely shrouded in darkness. I've dropped bodies into shadowed areas only to have them instantly discovered
in the patrolling guard's peripheral vision.
There were even instances of Garret visually appearing to be
in shadow but my light meter would say I was totally exposed and vice versa. I extinguished a candle right next to me that didn't seem to give off any light

2. Your dash ability is also crap.
It's context based and shares the same command as climb.
So my first attempt at being sneaky I inched around a crate
recommended:
and watched in horror as Garret climbed on top of the crate and into the light rather than dashing.

A similar experience trying to climb a rope I just hung for myself. I had to dance around the AOE of the rope until I found the sweet spot and the game allowed me to climb it.

3. The same can be said for Garret's drop down ability. I swear some ledges require it and some don't. This inconsistency combined with the idiotic descision to not have a ledge hang just adds to the frustration. First I'm forced to climb up a ledge all the way because of the lack of ledge hang. Next I can hear a guard is going to spot me
hoursPlayed: so naturally I try to back up which would cause me to just fall off the ledge down to the ground below and out of sight. My back hits a wall because of that stupid drop down key and I'm spotted. This was probably from a height of 3 feet and not like up on the cat walks 20+ feet in the air.\n\n4. Guard patrol routes will randomly break. I snuck passed 2 guards while the first was doing his patrol route. Entered a dead end alley and started looting. When I came back he was just standing there and did not resume his behavior no matter how long I waited. Yes I could and did use a bottle
voteText: but when you're trying to do the level without raising any suspicions it's frustrating to get to a moment like this when you're forced to break your rule because the game decided to break.\n\n5. reviewText:
I came into this game wanting a good story, good stealth, and a feeling of RPG like elements. After playing Deus Ex: Human Revolution, I thought that maybe I could have the experience re-created in a different universe. Man was I wrong.
Let's start with the story. The story begins with you and an old-friend roaming a city, looking to steal a prize nearby. However, things go terribly wrong, and an accident happens in which case you wake up a long time later. I think a few months, but I may be wrong as I didn't really care enough to remember. You then try to find your friend, and that's the rest of the game. Trying to find your friend. Yeah, sure, they have the whole thing about the artifact and how you actually need to find that, but your friend is at the center of it all so in essence you really are just there to find her. I will give them props on one thing, though: Some of the characters in this game I really enjoyed spending a moment or two with, especially the villain.
Now time for some stealth and gameplay reviewing. Guys, if you're looking for a great stealth game, Deus Ex is the place to be. Don't even spend time looking at this game. The A.I. is not the best, the odds are massivley stacked against you on multiple parts, and the gameplay is not exemplary whatsoever. The player view constantly bobs and weaves around, sometimes making you feel nauseas. The mini-games become tedious as there are only two or three. In some sections, you are facing hyper-sensative monsters, and the stealth becomes necessary, but it's a shame that the mechanics of it really let you down.
Last, the RPG elements. You have multiple things you can upgrade and buy. The two main categories are equipment and skills. However, the skills are all pretty much useless except for the combat ones as they actually make the combat bearable. The equipment becomes fun, however. Buying a wire-cutter tool can lead you through paths you couldn't make it to before. There is also a screwdriver that allows you to go through vents and such. This leads to some interesting new ways to venture through a level, although the story missions are all pretty linear.
In conclusion, go for Deus Ex. Skip this game. Spare your sanity.

reviewText:
This is not a Thief game as you know it. This is something much worse. There's a lot of polish here, but at the end of the day it's just not fun. The Thief mythos has been redefined and the core mechanics have been changed.

Did you enjoy making a pile of bodies on each level in previous Thief games while slowly progressing through? Gone; now the levels are extremely linear and encounters tend to act as a checkpoint through which you'll pass and immediately forget.

Enjoyed collecting loot and meeting those value goals each level? Gone as well. The loot will literally obstruct your path. Levels feel more like a Mario game than Thief--the loot will jump out at you (especially now that it shines *and* you have focus vision to make it pop). Sure you can go slightly out of your way and grab a few more coins, but it's hardly worth it.

Did you enjoy finding secret areas and the rewards within? Also gone. The secrets in this game are designed to be readily found so that everyone can find every secret during every playthrough. Worse still, the rewards inside tend to be unique loot which will go to your hideout to be stacked on each on a shelf or hung on a wall. Absolutely no gameplay rewards here.

Did you enjoy the variety of enemies in the previous games? Gone again. There are two. TWO! types of enemies in the entire game. One of which is just a lazy version of the other, with sensitivity to noise and other triggers turned way up.

Did you enjoy the AI of the previous games? Probably not, I know I didn't. Yet still it's worse here. Enemies rarely alert each other of events. Wandering civilians have been exchanged for caged birds and dogs. Yes, caged. They couldn't be bothered to make the dogs wander, so they just sit in a cage and bark.

Did you enjoy using a variety of arrows to take down enemies? Pretty much gone. There are fewer arrow types, you can hold less of them (especially starting off), and they're extremely rare. Expect to use one or two a level.

Did you enjoy knocking out opponents? Backstabbing them? Stealing arrows from an archer so he can't fight back? Gone. Gone. Gone. You have only a black jack now and there's no distinguishing knockouts from kills.

Did you enjoy collecting keys and progressing through the level? Yup, gone. No keys here, just linear progression triggered by scripted events.

I could go on, but i think you get the point. Is this a good Thief game? Definitely not. Is this a good game when not compared to the rest of the series? I'm afraid not. It does have a couple genuinely enjoyable moments, but those are few and far between, and they certainly don't make the between bits worth playing.

Do yourself favor and skip this game. Fingers crossed that the Thief series doesn't end with this stinker.

reviewText: Shallow and uninspired in both gameplay and level design, characters with zero to no personality and poor storyline, told even worse. Overall not only it's not a Thief game, but also a mediocre stealth, and it is amazing how they managed to f*ck it up after the great work with Human Revolution: only thing they need to do here was to leave the spooky atmosphere, the slow pace and come up with some new features to a relatively fusty genre. reviewText: Full of desires for fan service and accessibility, ends up satisfying no one. Room-by-room, the gameplay beats feel the same as any past shadow-stealthy-game and I guess there's not much to be done there? The previous Thief games (1 and 2) focused on huge expansive sprawling levels, huge systems with rooms interacting with rooms. Here, each room is so isolated that they might as well be in separate levels. The result is something that feels domesticated and boring. They sacrificed the design scope of past games to meet their framerate targets, forcing you on certain rails so they can maintain tightly controlled levels. Again, the compromise satisfies no one. Best of luck to the dev team, they have some talent but sometimes it doesn't work out.

reviewText:
What should I do with Thief? It does some insane mistakes but underneath it all you can see moments of brilliance. The studio just didn’t have a clue as to what to do with Thief. They just ♥♥♥♥ed it up so bad. It is mind-boggling how game designers would come up with ideas that just ruin the whole gameplay and even after testing they just run with it. The good? The game looks fantastic and the atmosphere is really there. In the settings menu you can turn the whole HUD off. And I did. I can’t even imagine how weak the game would’ve been with all that, quite frankly, unnecessary ♥♥♥♥ taking up the screen real estate. You can also customize you difficulty. And I did! I made it a lot harder that what the master level alone was. And it was still pretty easy. I turned focus off because that has no reason to be in a Thief game. I turned no damage on and it made the game more fun even though some fall damage spots broke the flow a bit unnecessarily. I also tried turning on chapter saves only and that was the worst decision I did with this game so I immediately went back and turned that back off. I’ll tell you why in a moment. One of the good things was also this huge mansion level that just made me enjoy the game like I was back playing Thief 2. It was fun and how the whole game should have been.

Then the bad. The game should have been Garrett turning mansions upside down but it barely does that. The game has some seriously weak insta-kill spots that just ruin the game even if you aren’t playing with chapter saves only option on. The controls are also so god awful that you just cannot master them. The game just doesn’t do what you expect it to do and a lot of it has to do with the fact that the game developers bound several actions to single keys. With PC there’s no excuse to that and it made playing the game a joke. I lost count the times I tried to dash quickly into the shadows only to find out that Garrett had climbed up on a wooden crate exposing himself to all the guards around. I can’t even imagine the times I tried to open a drawer and Garrett either picked up something from the desk, blew some candles off, or worst (and most frequent) of all crouched behind the desk peeking around its corner. The dialogue in the game was god awful. The plot was a joke. The characters were horrible and dull. Everything in the game felt like it was written by a 12-year-old. The journal menu was a design disaster. How can you ♥♥♥♥ all this up? Oh and the music broke the atmosphere up in the worst way possible playing some ridiculous rock music over the scripted action sequences. Like the hud, I had to turn the music off and I DIDN’T MISS IT. The last chapters were boring as hell just navigating through some caverns and the game designers felt the need to do multiple sequences where if you didn’t immediately know what to do you just died. This review is turning into a novella. Also, what’s the deal with all the “Press X to proceed” climbing sections and gateways? They’re not challenging so why were they there?

So, what’s the verdict? I don’t know what kind of idiots made the decisions behind this game but they clearly didn’t have any clue as to what they were working on. And surprisingly enough a couple of the levels were actually really fun. I enjoyed Garrett talking to himself and hiding in the shadows watching the guards doing their thing. I loved the mansion level and the way you could just roam it all around trying to find all the secret nuggets of gold. The game was infuriatingly badly designed but when it was good it was REALLY good. If the game was just 8 levels of mansions and castles to loot I could’ve forgiven everything else in a heart beat. Still, I have to say it felt like a Thief game from time to time.

reviewText:
What should I do with Thief? It does some insane mistakes but underneath it all you can see moments of brilliance. The studio just didn’t have a clue as to what to do with Thief. They just ♥♥♥♥ed it up so bad. It is mind-boggling how game designers would come up with ideas that just ruin the whole gameplay and even after testing they just run with it. The good? The game looks fantastic and the atmosphere is really there. In the settings menu you can turn the whole HUD off. And I did. I can’t even imagine how weak the game would’ve been with all that, quite frankly, unnecessary ♥♥♥♥ taking up the screen real estate. You can also customize you difficulty. And I did! I made it a lot harder that what the master level alone was. And it was still pretty easy. I turned focus off because that has no reason to be in a Thief game. I turned no damage on and it made the game more fun even though some fall damage spots broke the flow a bit unnecessarily. I also tried turning on chapter saves only and that was the worst decision I did with this game so I immediately went back and turned that back off. I’ll tell you why in a moment. One of the good things was also this huge mansion level that just made me enjoy the game like I was back playing Thief 2. It was fun and how the whole game should have been.

Then the bad. The game should have been Garrett turning mansions upside down but it barely does that. The game has some seriously weak insta-kill spots that just ruin the game even if you aren’t playing with chapter saves only option on. The controls are also so god awful that you just cannot master them. The game just doesn’t do what you expect it to do and a lot of it has to do with the fact that the game developers bound several actions to single keys. With PC there’s no excuse to that and it made playing the game a joke. I lost count the times I tried to dash quickly into the shadows only to find out that Garrett had climbed up on a wooden crate exposing himself to all the guards around. I can’t even imagine the times I tried to open a drawer and Garrett either picked up something from the desk, blew some candles off, or worst (and most frequent) of all crouched behind the desk peeking around its corner. The dialogue in the game was god awful. The plot was a joke. The characters were horrible and dull. Everything in the game felt like it was written by a 12-year-old. The journal menu was a design disaster. How can you ♥♥♥♥ all this up? Oh and the music broke the atmosphere up in the worst way possible playing some ridiculous rock music over the scripted action sequences. Like the hud, I had to turn the music off and I DIDN’T MISS IT. The last chapters were boring as hell just navigating through some caverns and the game designers felt the need to do multiple sequences where if you didn’t immediately know what to do you just died. This review is turning into a novella. Also, what’s the deal with all the “Press X to proceed” climbing sections and gateways? They’re not challenging so why were they there?

So, what’s the verdict? I don’t know what kind of idiots made the decisions behind this game but they clearly didn’t have any clue as to what they were working on. And surprisingly enough a couple of the levels were actually really fun. I enjoyed Garrett talking to himself and hiding in the shadows watching the guards doing their thing. I loved the mansion level and the way you could just roam it all around trying to find all the secret nuggets of gold. The game was infuriatingly badly designed but when it was good it was REALLY good. If the game was just 8 levels of mansions and castles to loot I could’ve forgiven everything else in a heart beat. Still, I have to say it felt like a Thief game from time to time.

reviewText:
So, another FPS stealth game that relies purely on stealth, with no superpowers or weapons(the weapons are more like tools in this game), sounds right up my alley!  I said count me in.  Oh what a mistake...

First off, let's talk about the biggest and arguably dumbest design decision I could think of, the controls.  For starters, you cannot free jump.  Let me reiterate again, you cannot freely jump.  What kind of a ♥♥♥♥ brain at Square Enix thought this was a good idea?  Let's just take one of the basic mechanics of all FPS games and exclude it.  It makes Garret feel and play like an utter gimp.  What kind of a thief can't jump on his own?  So how does he actually get around?  Well, the game dicatates where you can jump.  As in only certain platforms or boxes can be climbed.  Only specified platforms can be crossed or leaped across.  It makes traversing the already clausterphobic levels frustrating beyond belief.  Too many times have I thought I could jump across the roof top only to jump straight down into the street, right in front of a guard and get killed.  Only too many times have I have been cornered, and the obvious route is blocked off by arbritrary obstacles like a pile of boxes or debris that any other game would simply allow myself to climb or jump over, but in this case since the object is not specified, I can't do anything with it.  This doesn't apply to just platforms either.  This also applies to climbing roofs and walls.  You have a tool called the claw, which allows you to climb high walls.  But again, only designated walls which are few and far between.  This also applies to leaning around corners.  A normal game typically used Q and E to lean left and right retrospectively.  But no, this game you have to go up to a corner, and press E and Garrett will grab the corner and peak around.  Why couldn't they just assign different keys?  Too many times have I wanted to grab an object on top of a box or table, press E and wind up peeking around the edge.

My second biggest problem is the level design.  It's so cramped and maze like.  The open city of the previous entries is gone, replaced with narrow, winding streets cut up into small areas with too many loading areas  that take away any immersion this game had.  There are multiple smaller routes that can be explored, each with different loot than be stolen.  It's routine design when it comes to these type of games to allow replayability.  Some routes require certain tools to be explored.  However, there's no real reward to all the risk to going near guards because of the next biggest issue...

The combat.  Now, combat has always taken a backseat in the Thief games because it's main emphasis is on stealth and avoiding being seen in the first place.  I wouldn't mind this, but because your jumping and movement is so castrated, combat is almost always inevitable at some point because you either slip up or because not on purpose you jump down instead of jumping across a roof.  You get cornered and can't run away because of arbirtrary game rules.  So running away isn't always an option.  Garret is armed with a bow and a tool called a black jack which is used for striking.  The bow is a typical bow, equips different arrow types and the whole shebang.  However, the black jack is a worthless piece of garbage.  First off,  you press R to swing by default.  Yes, freaking R.  Left click equips your bow and V is for dodge.  So, take yourself throw a scenario where combat is involved.  You have to press V to dodge, and R to strike.  By default, this is extremely awkward, the black jack does minimal damage and your bow is too clumsy to be used in close quarters.  Remember in Dishonored when in combat, parrying and striking with your sword felt smooth and responsive?  Well, take all of that and throw it out the window in this game.

The AI for the most part is passable for a stealth game, if they get alerted they will search around corners and shine their torches into shadows.  They have their routes and can be distracted with blunt arrows, throwable objects and snuck up behind and knocked out.  It's your typical stealth game AI, nothing too remarkable and nothing too terrible.  However a big flaw I notice is if you are in combat in the middle of the street with a guard, the civilians fail to react in any way shape or form.  They just continue standing in their awkward, repetitive idle stances.  It takes away the immersion, and reminds you again that you are playing a video game.  This doesn't happen 100% of the time, but it happens enough where I had to make note of it.

On the other hand, the graphics are quite nice.  Especially the lighting effects.  The dreary gloomy feel of the franchise is as present as ever.  Garrett has full awareness, and looking down shows his legs and hands so he feels more than just a floating camera with arms.  On the other hand the animations are stiff, awkward and flat.  Garrett has a little animation for everything including opening draws, grabbing loot, picking locks, turning the dials on a safe, pressing buttons, opening doors and more.  I can appreciate this, as it makes me feel more in the shows of the protagonist.  But, this comes at a draw back.  You cannot quickly rifle threw draws or cabinets, as Garrett has to straighten out, look down and open every single door and draw.  This little times it takes to watch the animations add up, and more than once have I been stuck opening a window or draw and caught by a patrolling guard.  So you really have to make sure the coast is clear before sifting through every draw and dresser in a room.  So trying to be a quick, cunning thief is harder than it has to be.  Unlike Corvo who could pop easily in and out of sight to grab a key, Garrett has to go through an animation which takes away your control for a second.

The sound on the other hand is busted.  The voice acting is atrocious, with lines awkwardly and poorly delivered.  Dialogue contains many strange pauses in the conversations and combined with lip synching issues, makes cutscenes cringeworthy.  At least cutscenes are rendered in games instead of FMVs though, minus one or two.  NPCs constantly repeat the same few lines over and over, leading to immersion breaking design.Another big issue with the audio is the depth of sound is all sorts of wonky.  For example, if you are standing on the roof top and two guards are talking on the street three stories below, the voices will be loud enough as if they were right next to you.  This is a constant issue I notice throughout the game, and while it's a small quirk, it leads to moments where I would have the volume up and all of a sudden two voices will be blaring through my speakers even though there's no NPCs near me.  However, the audio is not all bad, as sound plays a big factor in being stealthy.  Walk faster, louder footsteps.  The typical stealth sound routine is all in place but to great detail.  Walking across broken glass renders your footsteps very loud, same with walking in water and such.

The game gets a few things right.  Garretts sprint and swoop moves are very welcomed.  The levels are littered with beautiful little details like hidden rooms, hidden safes, traps and alternate routes, which makes exploring every nook and cranny and must.  Paying attention to surroundings is a must, as broken glass, traps, puddles of water and creaky wood planks are almost everywhere, so speed running is ill advised.

The game also contains a fair of customization, such as upgrading your abilities and gear.  Also included is a load of gameplay options, like optional warnings, object highlighting, difficulty settings and how much information you want on your HUD.

All in all, too many clueless design decisions hinder what could have been an enjoyable stealth game.  This is not a thief game at heart, so don't let the name fool you.  2/5 stars, and that's being generous.

reviewText:
The camera is shaky, inducing headaches, and the gameplay isn't as rewarding as other stealth games. For example, there is no satisfactory reward for leaving hostiles undisturbed as there is in Splinter Cell: The Blacklist, combat is very hack-and-slash and not even visually exciting, and the tools at your disposal don't feel very imaginative, and levelling them up doesn't add any new opportunities or facets to the game.

The expansiveness of the world is also comparable to that of a large RPG, so as a casual completionist, I'm annoyed that there are so many paths to the same end-goal, few of which re-converge to give a sense of how much content in other paths I actually skipped.

Overall, I think the technical components of the game are well developed, but in general, it's just not very enjoyable as a stealth game, since there appears to be very little reward for being sneaky over just killing everyone one by one.

reviewText:
The amount of hours is how long i could stomach playing this game masquerading around as a game i once knew as Thief.  Not only is the horrible stealth system, a very integral part of the series, atrociously done, the overall game-play is just flat out bad.  After realizing that this game is really a game meant to be played on an ice rink, with it's inexplicable use of press space bar to shadow dodge and win, the game fails to capture any redeeming qualities of the series.

It is such a waste too since the game itself looks great, how Garret places his hands on walls etc, is very well done and can immerse you in the character, but unfortunately when the large chunk of your game is a stealth game, and that mechanic is incredibly broken, you can only enjoy the little things so long before you give up.  I really wish i had not pre-ordered the game, if this game were under 10$ i'd say it is worth a try, but anything above you're better off with something that will actually be entertaining.

Take the recommendation as you will, but overall a disappointed fan of the game, for someone new to the series it may be a great / fun little game to play around with.  To any fan of the Thief series, know that this game lacks the spirit and soul of it's successors.

reviewText:
Well, fellow taffers!

I played all thiefs, so T1, T2:TMA and T3:DS. I'm still a big fan of the first three installments. Although these three are quite dated, they are all still one of the best games of the genre and out there. Especially T1 and T2 ate an *insane* amount of hours of my life.

Because I do like stealth games a lot, I've played DISHONORED this year until T4 dropped to a reasonable price on Steam. Then I started T4 and went from How it's done" to "What a crap". And now comes a list why I didn't even finish T4 and why I think it's not a good game.

reviewText:
Wow. This game was made by the same people who made Deus Ex: Human Revolution? Or at least some of them?!

This does just about everything wrong. But chief among all is the level design. You thought they couldn't possibly make an open world environment worse than the one in Deadly Shadows? Well, prepare to have your mind blown. This takes the cake as one of the worst environments I have ever played in- and they expect you to run through it, like 20 times if you want to do any side content.

The missions themselves are not all that bad. But most of them are linear as hell. Comparing this to Dishonored.. well, don't do it. I could go on and on about the forced escape sequence after almost EVERY level, the stupid first person stealing animation that takes way too long. The way you have to look through every drawer of a cupboard (well, you don't HAVE to). This game feels like it was designed by 3 completely different teams and then at the end, somebody just took all their half finished work and threw it together.

What a waste of everybody's time. Hey, at least the graphics are pretty, eh?
voteText: 8 of 12 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Its the first Thief I played and im really disappointed. First, the player cannot jump unless promoted to by the game, you have detective vision, you know, like in Batman series. This technique has been copied and pasted numerous times and it completely detracts from the Thief experience. The AI is idiotic and highly unaware. I do realize that this is a stealth game but it is poorly done when you are forced to do it. You can only attack with your blackjack, you cannot parry, but you can dodge. This close combat is highly repetitive especially in later levels. Finally, graphics are the only strong point of the game, it isn't ugly and in fact it is atmospheric. The textures are decent and the particle effects bring this world to life. Generally there is a good contrast between the light and dark areas of the game. Anyway, I have come to a point, that I will now wait for scores as to whether or not to buy a game, instead of buying a game and watching my hard earned cash go to waste, oh well, live and learn. 5/10

reviewText:
In short, the story is missing three key ingredients:  The Keepers, the Hammers, and the Pagans.  This is an unforgivable sin, and this is why The Master Builder hath smitten thee!

This is a good game when you play it deciding to forget the first three games, but if you're a veteran there's a bunch of things that are difficult to stomach.  Stealth isn't absolutely necessary.  What?  Isn't this supposed to be Thief, stealth pioneer?  I love the city, and the story isn't bad.  But not far into it, I realized that I seemed to be playing Batman.  That made it feel like a bit of a rip off.

I suppose that if you’re going to do a Thief Reboot, the best way would be to start over and redo “The Dark Project” better than it has ever been done before.  There were elements of the original game that I did not like, for example the terrible character design, anything having to do with burricks, the miscarriage that was the lost city, and how it always dumped the player off in a menu screen following the successful completion of a mission.  It would be neat to start over with Garrett as a boy in the streets of the current city and do a little background on how he went from Keeper Acolyte to Thief.  I know Garrett now, and I don’t believe he simply did it out of greed.

But I don’t think it ever needs to be a first-person-shooter.  Garrett, in addition to being a thief, is also an adventurer, an investigator, and an explorer.  Build him a City that allows him to be creative in his approach to getting his ill-gotten gains and discover his forbidden intel.

And as for Erin, I think old Garrett is about due for a love interest, and this was a good try.  I sincerely hope that Eidos and Square-Enix doesn’t give up on the title, but I also hope they all have the humility to learn from their mistakes.

reviewText:
I'd recommend this game depending on if you're a fan of the original games or not.

If you are? I would suggest drinking a large amount of alcohol before you play, so that you can experience the game with the added bonus of not remembering exactly what it was you put yourself through afterwards.

You will have played it, because you're a fan of the franchise, but you need never recall the sound glitches, the laughable 'plot', or the frustrating city navigation. You need never spend hours waiting for any indication that the devs even bothered to read the wikipedia articles about the games previous installments, let alone played them.

In your mind, Garrett can remain the somewhat mysterious, sarcastic rogue whos smirk you gladly mirrored as you slipped through the shadows like the morally bankrupt anti hero the title implies you are. (Not that you’re even playing that Garrett, I’m sorry, did you think you were playing that Garrett? You’re totally not! This game is set literally hundreds of years later, duh!)

If you aren't? Sure go ahead and get it, it’s a pretty standard AAA with a decent amount of playtime and side missions. It’s kinda like Dishonored I guess, if Dishonored was a little less steampunk and a little more rubbish.

reviewText:
I liked the prologue, the streets were alive, the introduction of the story gave me goosbumps, and the shining loot made the stealing feel fullfilling.

What I disliked was, after the intro, all you get are dead streets, no factions, limited ease of movement around the city, dumb guards, and anything you do apart from the main quest feels like work.  The game just doesn't seem to have life, only a flicker of it on the main quests.

If you are a fan of the franchise, you WILL be dissapointed, only stick to the main quests for any hope of getting through the whole game without feeling lost inside.  If you are not a fan of the franchise, just don't pay more than £10 for it.


In conclusion, this is not a good game (being generous), the next Thief will need have something new for any hope of the continuation of the franchise.  Then again, if the Assaisns Creed can do it, so can Thief.

reviewText: This isn't terrible, and there are some genuinely good missions in it, but ultimately it becomes less fun the more you play it. I'm quite close to the end, but I don't care about finishing the game anymore. I have been doing a fair number of side missions, but still: 20 hours in, and I don't care about what's going on. It's full of clichés, such as the empty wheelchair rolling towards you in the corridor of the haunted mental asylum (seriously), and other games do everything here better. Get Dishonored and its Brigmore Witches DLC instead.\n\nA big problem is the city that connects everything. Familiarity breeds contempt, and you often have a lot of ground to cover to get from NPC to NPC which leaves the big feeling both big and small at the same time. You start to wish that some of the side mission characters might reward you with a fast travel option to other points on the map, given that you can't earn useful items from that work. Instead, we are forced to walk everywhere through a city that's bizarrely lacking interconnection. Often, you need to find an exact window to let you through into another city section. It is torturously stubborn when you're trying to get from A to B, and worse because of the completely unnecessary amount of loading points. Even with an SSD, this is still irritating. You'll quickly learn to hate the identical animations for squeezing through a tight space and the QTE to move the same fallen beam, and the Hold X
date: now tap X repeatedly" thing for windows (which I could forgive if it was ever about a subtle movement to avoid being heard

reviewText:
Most of the things I wanted to say have already been said in the review section, but after two playthroughs (one for the story and challenge, one for assorted achievements) I feel like giving my two cents nonetheless.
In the very likely case you don't want to read the wall of text below, my overall opinion is that while this game doesn't suck, it's also very much “meh”.
If you want to play a Thief game, go play the old ones! I recommend the second :)
If you want a modern, triple A spiritual successor to the Thief series that also allows for some really fun action gameplay, go play Dishonored.
Thief 2014 is not wasted money, but definitely money that could have been spent better.

My opinions on some major gameplay-related elements:

Gameplay.
The stealth gameplay is there and it's not bad. Sure, now you can see the alert status of enemies, but on the other hand I feel like their AI has been slightly improved: for example, they react to doors being opened\closed.
The parkour stuff is really fun in theory, but you're limited to the places that the game decides for you (and conveniently color-codes for you). As a lot of other people pointed out, Thief I and II did this in a much more fun and creative way with the old rope arrows, fifteen years ago.
There's a lot of potential for action gameplay and lots of upgrades, if you're into that; although it's kinda dull.
Focus mode is basically Batman detective mode and conveniently highlights all the important things for you. It feels like cheating and it's kinda sad it was put in to begin with, but it can be safely ignored.
There are also several action sequences and even QTEs. You can close your eyes when they come up, I guess.

Level design.
You could easily get lost in the old Thief games. The levels were huge and in order to figure out where your objective(s) was you could only rely on a minimalistic map, plus whatever hints you could find. In this game, on the other hand, you have an objective marker and a real-time minimap. The streamlining is also pretty noticeable: there's always a direction that's the correct one and in order to progress you have to keep moving in that direction; often times the game is even so kind as to close off parts of the level once you've reached a certain point.
Since I'm on the topic of level design, this might be a good moment to mention how dark this game is. Not dark as in “it's night”, dark as in “there is no concept of brightness in this universe”: most things are black, grey or brown, any other color is actually a bleak shade of whatever that color is supposed to be. This has the double effect of making every level look the same and being pretty tiring on the eyes (in my experience, at least).

Enemies.
There are quite literally two enemies in this game. The standard human guard, and the freaks. The freaks are... the freaks. They all look the same and only appear a bunch of times, but at least they're pretty creepy and sneaking around them is slightly different. On the other hand, officers of the City Watch, Graven mob and random thugs are visually undistinguishable from each other unless you're actually in their face, and their “personalities” are the same: they all repeat the same lines constantly, relentlessly, until you know them by heart.
In a game like Thief you need a decently varied array of enemies, both for gameplay purposes and to make the universe more engaging.

Open world.
Thief is an open world game. There's a (supposedly) sprawling city which you need to move through in order to reach the starting points of the game's chapters; and which you can explore to discover all its secrets. At first you're going to be awestruck by how big it is: so full of alternate routes, so full of secrets to find... but all that excitement is going to quickly disappear around the second time you're sneaking through the long path you're forced to take in order to get where you need to get, while you're trying to make sense of the map (spoiler: you'll never be able to make sense of the map). And you'll have to do this again, and again, and again.
If all of this sounds familiar, congratulations, you've played Thief III! Except the City in the previous game wasn't as confusing, if I recall correctly.


More ramblings of a salty fanboy
These are mostly minor nitpicks. You can safely stop reading here.

The plot.
In the old games the plot was some kind of creepy big conspiracy that Garrett stumbles upon because he's always where he isn't supposed to be; and it slowly built up level by level. Here they try really hard to make it extremely personal from the very beginning, but they do so using a character that's barely introduced and a world whose only inhabitants are idiot clones who spend their time wondering what's in the sloop.
The plot is also at the same time predictably clichè and ridiculously vague. “Oh no, the bad guy wants to use the vaguely defined plot device to do... something! Oh no, now a new bad guy wants to use the vaguely defined plot device to do something else!”.

Continuity
I can tell they decided to ignore all the series' lore because they thought burricks, treebeasts, haunts , automatons etc... weren't bleak enough for this modern triple A masterpiece of bleakness. The Pagans with their hilarious broken English and their creepy wood witch vibe are gone. The holier-than-thou, priests-turned-engineers Hammerites are gone. The Builder and the Trickster are gone. So how do you deal with making a sequeleboot to a series while at the same time not wanting to use that series' lore, but wanting to keep the main character? Simple: you set it sometime in the future and make it so Garrett isn't actually Garrett, but another guy named Garrett who looks very similar to Garrett and is also an incredibly skilled thief, also has a fence who is coincidentally named Basso... you get the idea. And this is not a complete reboot, mind you, it's officially a future version of the old Thief world. You can check the wiki[thiefgame.wikia.com] to read more about it, because you sure as hell won't get more info by playing the game.
Long story short, you can probably guess that I'm very salty about the complicated stupidity of this game's continuity and lore.

Audio bugs
The in-game meThe in-game mechanism The in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.chaThe in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the vThe in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.ery least questionable.nism that triggers dThe in-game meThe in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.chanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.ialogues is at the vThe in-game mThe in-game mechanism that triggers dialogues is at the verymechanism that triggers dialogues is at the very least questionable.ery least questionable.

Bleakness
I've already talked a bit about how hard this game tries to be bleak, but I feel the best way to convey what it's like and also why I can't take it seriously is to write some sample dialogue, the kind that you'll hear constantly through the game.
Guy #1: “My shift of ♥♥♥♥-shoveling is over. Wanna go get drunk?”
Guy#2:“Yes, I might forget about how I just threw my own mother's body in a mass grave”
Guy#1“I'll have to bury my six kids soon, they have the plague and I lost all my money when the rotting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I was with robbed me. At least some street thugs killed her immediately after”
Enter guard.
Guard:“Did someone say... thugs? And kill?”
Violent noises, Guy#1 and #2 scream
Guard:”I have the plague.”

reviewText:
I'll get this out of the way now: I have not played any of the previous games in the series. My opinion on Thief comes from Thief and Thief alone.

While having potential, Thief lacks what most stealth games do: an element of stealth.

The stealth aspect is virtually non-existant. Enemies will not notice you so long as you are crouched, swooping, walking, or otherwise in the shadows. Nevermind the fact that they're mere inches from your face in an ominous alleyway. When their guard is down, they are completely oblivious. When their guard should otherwise be up, they are still completely oblivious. It is entirely possible to crouch by a group of guards in plain sight with little to no reaction beyond a What was that?"

Too often are there instances where the game provides little to no ingenuity. While each map supposedly has "multiple paths" for the player to take
date: the paths are few and far between
recommended: with little to no deviation from a linear trajectory. The maps are set up to allow you to find your own way to get from point A to point B
hoursPlayed: but after starting your path
voteText: it's simply a matter of holding down a few keys until you arrive at your destination.\n\nOn top of all else
helpfulPercent: the controls are needlessly bizzare. Let us assume you wish to hop down from a rope you're climbing. One would expect the jump key while looking downward would do so
votesHelpful: or perhaps the crouch key. One would be wrong. Instead it's required to bind seperate keys to all of these commands. Instead of grouping together contextual keys in a sensible fashion
votesTotal: Thief takes the approach of "4 keys for 1 action"
votesFunny: leaving you scrambling for the correct key when another should do the same thing. Each additional bind is purely contextual
commentsCount: rendering the alternative bindings useless save for specific situations
column16: and indicating that Thief missed the simple concept of one key being able to do multiple actions in order to allow the player to respond more quickly. To top off the controls
column17: Thief's handling of input commands is lackluster. It often requires multiple key presses before any one action is actually completed. So expect to fall to your death a couple dozen times before Garrett finally decides to hop that 2-foot gap in front of him.\n\nAll in all
column18: while Thief seems appealing
column19: it utterly lacks in any and all expected components."

reviewText:
The original Thief is, possibly, my most favorite game in all the hundreds of games I've played. To be able to immerse yourself so wholly in the experience that you can literally spend the entire day in a single level, sneaking about and accomplishing the mission so perfectly that you are seen only when the pathing of enemies makes it 100% impossible, that you never have to swing your weapon save to possibly knock out a guard or two by necessity.

If nothing else, the core divide I feel is that the original Thief felt like I was actually taking things in logical places from some jerks. This game feels as hollow and forced as smalltalk with a stranger on the street waiting in line for the bus.

Loot is obvious, and placed everywhere without sentiment for retaining the 4th wall - as if they all agreed that if Mario can place floating coins you jump at and feel gratified then so can we!

I feel as sneaky as a rusty shopping cart, and get the sense that the character is as much a Thief as an uninformed constituent is a Voter. Achieving the action with ease, is not the same as achieving the action with sprezzatura.

reviewText:
When I wasn't following the generic save the world story line I found little to do within the ten or so streets I could explore until I was forced to listen as a brick explained the inner workings of clay to me. When that brick finished I was puzzled to find myself forced into some kind of side quest which funny enough involved walls made of clay. With my new instructions I began following the linear road to a door upon which I found a small object on a table. I grabbed it, handed it back to the fine chap of a brick. I did that about another nine times, got bored and played Dying Light with a few friends.

10/10 would listen to horrible voice acting while playing an obnoxiously linear game designed by Eidos which in turn is owned by Square Enix. Oh wait didn't Square Enix recently try a horrible pre-order system the likes of which EA shed tears of pure joy and jerked off furiously to the idea of extorting money from idiots who pre-order games?

Remember kids before buying games like these, please become a donor incase you suffer an aneurysm and suffocate in a pool of mountain dew.

reviewText:
Thief(2014) has tried to renovate its 2 parts: action and stealth adventure.

But, This new thief didn't know it already had enough, unique charms as one of the greatest stealth game,

and so they look like trying to follow common details of contents n systems to meet normal demands in game market.

However, the result what they chose is absolutely fail.

Action, which ensured hardcore but beautiful experiences, change too casual, and light.

You can dominate guards with a lot of methods very easily.

rediculously, although thief is 'stealth robbing action', it's more efficient and easy that you kill or knockout all guards first before you start robbing.


and also, freakery map structure, one-way directing system, collectible with no rewards etc made the contents of adventure too sttufy, boring.

You must see 3~5 loading window if you wanna visit to buy resources and upgrade your abilities.

half of playtime will be wasted to move where you wanna go and need to go.

Moreover, this game can't motivate why players need to finish sidequests, and search hidden spot for more rewards.

Contrastly that you need to spend much time and efforts to do that, the rewards is not fair and not much helpful.

Even if how many, or how diligently you've played, you can't change anything in game story line.



Thief had 'unique action' and 'renovated adventure' contents, but Thief(2014) sacrificed thier own competitiveness to archive many two-bit contents.

reviewText: I really liked the old Thief games. I wasn't a huge fan, but I really enjoyed them. I was so stoked when this game came out, but I was very quickly disappointed. I think the old games were so good because they were a fresh style of gameplay in their time. This game felt like Wal-mart's Great Value" brand Reduced sodium Saltine crackers taste....BLAND.\n\nThe biggest sin this game commited was its storytelling. Cliche's galore! The ending was so.....bad. It felt like they wanted to keep it open for a sequel
date: but they made Garrett look like such a fool. There were shopkeepers to sell arrows and such in the most unusual locations. You never had to worry about conserving ammunition before an important event because. BAM
hoursPlayed: a guy offering items for all your "nefarious needs."\n\nWhich brings me to my next big sin. The voice acting. Zero emotion
voteText: zero talent. I got so sick of hearing the same back and forth banter that never changed or had variation throughout the whole game. I would think that at least Garrett would have a good voice actor
helpfulPercent: but it sounded like the guy the voiced Garrett did it while lying down on his couch.\n\nThe AI was horrendous. They would see you kill a fellow guard in cold blood
votesHelpful: and once you hid for about 1 minute
votesTotal: they would say
votesFunny: "whoever it was
commentsCount: he's gone now
column16:
and go back to their exact same patrol route. No more guards would be summoned, nothing. They either knew exactly where you were, or had no idea. There was no searching around until they found you. For the first 3 chapters, if a torch was extinguished by a water arrow, they reacted to it. After that, they must have had a memo go around the Pony Express for the guards, that ordered them to stop reacting to that nonsense.

Lastly, the level design. It was probably one of the most linear games since Contra for the NES (Contra was an epic game...this, was not). You usually had ONE path you could take to get somewhere. If there were two choices, it was either, stealth path, or fight guards path. There were more doors and windows you couldnt go in, than words spoken in the game. You could only climb in very particular places.

SO, SO.....SOOO BAD!!! This game is DREAFUL!!! For the love of Pete~~! Don't spend money on this game!! Pity.

reviewText:
Thief, where do i start with this ?
seeing the trailers of this game made me a little bit excited but at the same time i was skeptical since i haven't played any of the other Thief games, but then i found a great deal of this game on Gamecards website and i decided to take my chances and buy it.

The game starts with you, Garret, the master thief, in a house full of loot and a drunk man laying on bed, u sneak around and you steal any shiny stuff, at the begining of this game i didn't think it will be that exciting to try and find each and every collectable, but as soon as Chapter 2 started, i fell in love with this game.

The atmosphere this game creates is unlike any other, and the sound of your heartbeats pounding as a guard approaches is one of the amazing things about this game, it's the perfection of sound effects that gets you in the game and makes you wanna play more.

I haven't finished the game yet, but the missions i played were awesome, stealth games just got a new reboot for me with this game, and what i really like is that the games rewards you based on your play style, wether you were a predator, a ghost or an oppurtunist, your rewards will be based on that, and you will get more if you were a ghost, which really motivates you to play the game the way you should, as a GHOST!

At the end of the day, each game has its pros and cons, and the cons of this game were:
- You have to make your way inside any home by opening a window, which is a silly way to make loading screens
- Enemy AI can be stupid at times, detecting you from a distance and sometimes they don't see you even if you become very close to them
- Some tools were useless, as some arrows require more than 3 shots to kill a target


But afterall, i'm really enjoying the game and will soon finish it, and hope you try it as well :)

Recommended,

9 OUT OF 10

reviewText:
Graphics 6/10
Gameplay 3/10
Replay value 3/10
Sound 2/10

This game was designed for console.

This will probaly turn into a rant!

The lockpicking system seems to be just using the d-pad to find the spot, Which is kinda difficult on a mouse setup and no visual clues or audible ones either apart from a sphere brightening.
The audio 3d positioning is one of the worst I've heard. Stood 3 feet from a ticking clock, moved another foot  and the sound faded to nothing.
Might seem like nothing to some people but it destroys the immersion.
The original game had audio so finely tuned you didn't need to see the guards, just hear them to know exactly where they were.

The graphics, while nice, are nothing to write home about.
Kinda has a comic look to things, is washed out and has no real depth.
The field of view feels claustraphobic and going above the normal changes things to a fisheye lens view.
Opening (jimmying) windows is another console driven gimmic designed to instill intrepidation and realism into the act, but alas, fails and only annoys when you realise that you have to do it over and over again even from withing the room you just burgled.
How many people need to jimmy their own windows from the inside?

Th inability to not use your tools unless in the proper place is also a detriment to this game.
Take a rope arrow and try it on a wooden structure you think you may climb and NO.
Predefined rope attachment areas only and also no retrieval of the rope arrow.
Even the original game allowed you to do that. I remember going through a 40ft room swinging from rope arrow to rope arrow all while using just 2 arrows.

The AI in the game is stupid.
Two guards in a room, I open a door in plain sight and fade away again
who opened that"  "ahh twas nothing"
yes
date: nothing happened to pick the lock and open the door.\nPeople on the street don't seem to see you

except guards because they are looking for me? With the exception of the way I am dressed I could be anybody. I haven't killed in their sight or done anything wrong.

The game is almost impossible to play if you turn all the console type features off and try to play like the original game.
Without focus mode you may see traps

else they get back up and kill you.

Consoles are killing the pc gaming scene by diluting original games into a series of button mashing mini games and QTE's.
I'm done with console reboots of orginal pc games.
SOD the lot of em"
