reviewText:
They could have put a lot more effort into this game:

The movement and animations are well done, but general gameplay and storyline I felt was an overall flop and there is not much to keep you interested after a hour or two. The missions are highly repetitive, the skill-tree rather pointless and the combat system restrictive (although I understand it is not intended to be played that way).

I am also confused as to why they choose to role the game out on the unreal engine instead of going with the engine that Eidos-Montréal  had created for the new Deus-Ex which personally I thought would have been the more logical platform.
voteText: 15 of 26 people (58%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Against all odds, the game is actually a lot of fun!

I am a hardcore classic Thief fan, having played the original two games to death, including tons of fan missions. I had sub-zero expectaitons and was growing increasingly horrified by the reboot with each new trailer and gameplay video. Having now played a reasonable amount of the game, I can say that despite all the complaints oldschool Thief fans have, it's actually a solid experience that feels satisfying and thiefy at its core.

Despite the lack of Hammerites / Mechanists / Stephen Russell / etc, the game provides enough tweaks to turn it into an experience very close to the originals. Even if story missions are smaller, the city hub is a lot of fun to explore and loot. You can strip the on-screen feedback to just the light gem and explore using your brains and your senses, which is actually what Thief is all about.

I hated and laughed at this game before I played it. However, at the end of the day all that matters is whether you have fun with your purchase and I am actually having a lot of fun with this reboot.

reviewText:
A reboot of a well-loved series is always a gamble. Even if developers manage to completely recreate everything right about the original games, you're still never going to recapture that nostalgia. I feel for fans of the original games who are disappointed with the reboot, I really do. As a Silent Hill fan, I know what it's like to see a series you love change in ways you hoped it never would.

But as I've never played the original Thief games, I can only base my review on this one, and despite a lot of problems such as the muddled story, linear missions, and inability to climb absolutely everywhere due to contextual climbing and jumping, I found this game wildly fun. In the end, my biggest complaint is that there just isn't any more. The story could be explored so much better with a slower-moving pace and more, less hectic missions that let the narrative slowly unfold through small details rather than bombastic action sequences.

At any rate, despite it's flaws, this game made it to my ultimate top 10, and as such, I feel as though I owe it at least a thumbs up.

reviewText: If you want a first person assassins creed, here you go, you will aimlessly wander around having to spend multiple seconds of hesitation as a thief to make your next move. Every ledge you approach, you have to peer down and consider if the jump is to far, thus moments after, activate this decision with a clever cutscene, that takes up more time, the idea of a first person experience in a thief mind is nice, but do you have to repeat every action with such repetitive motion. Yes, I get it, I'm stealing, but can it just be stolen and not see my hand motioning to grab something every time? When I grab my Burger at McDonalds, I don't grab it, look at my hands, assess the value, and take a new life revelation to figure out what I have become. I take the damn sandwich, I eat it, move on, why is Garret spending so much time with all this unworldly concerns when he starts telling us how he use to steal to live, live to steal, but things changed? Yes, get a job you bum.\n\nTL:DR poor rendition of the series, very glitchy, console gamers will enjoy it, no sense of motive of why you are who you are. You're a thief, not a messiah, you steal, you loot, you kill if needed, why does Garret finally have some Humanity...He doesn't

reviewText:
So, the new Thief game has come and a lot of people have a lot of oppinions on it. Personally, the old Thief games are some of my all time favourites and I gladly place Thief 1 & 2 at some point in my Top 10 list of best games ever. I am also a big fan of the more recent Dishonored game, really hoping for a sequel there, and I hold it as the true spiritual successor to the old Thief games. So how does this new, actual THIEF Thief game hold up?

I am glad to say that I enjoyed it! When judges on it's own merrits, it is a very enjoyable experience with some great gameplay throughout. The story is a bit simplistic, especially when compared to the old games stories, but there are a lot of layers to the story and the universe that you really have to dig for to get a glimpse of. For example, there is a very interesting theory circulating that this Thief game actually takes place in the same universe as the old games, only set about 800 or so years into the future, with this games Garret being a sort of reincarnation of the old games Garret. There is a theme about the cyclical nature of time in the game, and there's a side-quest in particular that discusses the idea of all parts of time existing at the same time all the time (sorry if it sounds a bit confusing from my explanation), but it would make sense that this story could be a continuation as well as a reboot at the same time.

The best part of the game is clearly the gameplay, and stealing things really takes the main stage, as is appropriate. There is almost always something to steal in any part of the environment, and sometimes you happen upon special loot that is especially valuable. A lot of it is also hidden or contained in special places where you actively need to find the loot or figure out how to unlock it in some very intricate ways, which gives a thorough player a great sense of rewarding the dedicated playstyle. The addition of the swooping" mechanic to Garrets moveset is also really enjoyable
date: and it works as a sort of counter to the "Blink" ability that was the absolute best part of the stealth system in Dishonored.\n\nIt is very interesting to observe the evolution of the first person stealth genre visible here
recommended: as the original Thief games so strongly influenced the development of Dishonored

voteText: whereupon the developers here for the new Thief game were very heavily inspired by the style and development of Dishonored in turn. A great example is the three-part introduction to the world of the game that both Dishonored used (Tales from Dunwall) as well as Thief (Stories from The City).\n\nThere are some aspects that detract from the overall experience of Thief

reviewText:
A reboot of a well-loved series is always a gamble. Even if developers manage to completely recreate everything right about the original games, you're still never going to recapture that nostalgia. I feel for fans of the original games who are disappointed with the reboot, I really do. As a Silent Hill fan, I know what it's like to see a series you love change in ways you hoped it never would.

But as I've never played the original Thief games, I can only base my review on this one, and despite a lot of problems such as the muddled story, linear missions, and inability to climb absolutely everywhere due to contextual climbing and jumping, I found this game wildly fun. In the end, my biggest complaint is that there just isn't any more. The story could be explored so much better with a slower-moving pace and more, less hectic missions that let the narrative slowly unfold through small details rather than bombastic action sequences.

At any rate, despite it's flaws, this game made it to my ultimate top 10, and as such, I feel as though I owe it at least a thumbs up.

reviewText: Warning: flaming review.\nStupid scenario that features a mix of teen emo & blatant emptiness, the more you advance, the less you like it. Absent or lame characters, world feels bare & empty. Garret is too silent compared to previous games & unable to jump (maybe he's now too old for that haha). Another bad thing: you will often see Garett's face, which shouldn't be. Tiny & boring levels and no pleasure from exploring/discovering: everything is painted/scratched for you to see the possible routes, only blind players would miss them... Level layout is really bad. Gated gameplay: go THERE, do THAT, etc. Annoying Scripted sequences that you'll have to restart several times. Knocking people is bad, M'okay? So forget about the previous games where it was the hype thing to do lol. To top it all it's rather ugly, with no colors and oddly enough no mirrors (maybe it's my settings though). The AI is ridiculous. A lot seem like stolen from Dishonored: the guards' uniforms, the illness thing and a lot of the decor stuff.\nIn conclusion: I cannot believe what I'm going to say but the average Thief 3 is waaaaay better than this! So huh?! How come? I tried to love the game, you can see that I have put a lot of hours in it & I still have some stuff to do in it but playing more than an hour at the time is too ***ing boring. Best Thief to Worst Thief, IMO: 2, 1, 3, 4.

reviewText:
Huh. It's not a bad game... but not a great game either. Given I didn't play the original games so this reboot was my first playthrough in the series. And I liked it actually... but also there are so many flaws in the game. Wish there is a mixed option for games like this. If we are talking about a numerical value I'd give 6 or 6.5 out from 10 to this game.

There is no background or prequel story (as I said that was my first game from the series) but still I kinda wished they told new players what are the Thief games about. It just stars in medias res" without any further ado. Just play and have fun.

Also I didn't like when the game went from stealth to horror in chapter 5. Overally I enjoyed the game but that chapter was too creepy imo and didn't fit the style of the whole. Other than that the overall story is nice but just a bit shallow.

As I was writing this Dishonored came up in my mind so many times. I know not every game should be Dishonored but one must compare the two games and honestly Dishonored 100% better than this. From every point of view. And that's my biggest problem. Because this game could have been so much better. Like it fails on every single thing but not by a huge margin... yet still enough to notice the negativities.

I got the game through the Square Enix Humble Bundle and honestly that was a good price for it (considering I also got a lot of other games too).

But long story short: don't buy this game for full price. It's 5
date: 99€ if it has a 80% sale and honestly you shouldn't pay more than that."

reviewText:
- Cliche, terribly written dialogue.
- Boring, cardboard characters.
- Awful narrative.
- Terrible combat system.
- Buggy AI pathing.
- Awful mini-map and map system.
- inversed y-axis mouse doesn't save (I need to set this every single time I boot up).

I presumed I wouldn't be lost in the plot not having previously played the other Thief games, but the plot and the characters were given no history or introduction and the narrative is so spartan I have zero sense of sympathy for the main characters and the vague antagonist. I have felt completely dissociated from the plot since the game began. The cut-scenes often have awkward inexplicable pauses that scream for revision. The actions are mundane. The dialogue is trite and doused in cliches. There's no sense of urgency to continue stealing stuff - I don't even understand what's going on most of the time.

Having played nearly ten hours I'm ready to give up. This game feels like a chore to play. Having had no expectations coming into this game, it's hard to be disappointed. I just wish they'd picked up a better script-writer. And...you know...made the game mechanics fun to play or something...


Avoid this one

reviewText:
A mediocre stealth game that I gave up on halfway through.

The stealing of items is fun at the start, but gets repetitive quick. It gets tedious opening every drawer or cabinet in a house and the small rewards are not worth it.

The game has a central city hub you can explore between missions, but there's so many loading screens that you'll give up on that after a couple of hours. Some loading screens are disguised by long animations (opening a window,...), often revealing a small 1 or 2 room apartment behind them.

The graphics are good, but the game is mostly grey and brown wooden buildings. Some more variation and color would have been welcome.

Sound has bigger problems. Voice lines repeat constantly, guards talk over each other and some guards say multiple lines at the same time.
While walking around the city you'll overhear conversations between citizens, but it's always voices coming from a closed window or door. It feels very fake and doesn't make the city feel alive. The few civilians you do see just stand around doing nothing.

The game isn't awful (and the story missions don't have most of these problems), but it wasn't interesting enough to make me put up with the constant loading screens and repetitive thieving.

reviewText:
Thief is a dystopian stealth game where you play as Garrett a Master Thief by his and many other's rights. However, while it may sound good as a tagline (or maybe it doesn't) it's not as good as I thought it'd be. I got an email from Steam telling me that it was on sale for 66% off I believe and I love Steam sales so I paid about $12 for it and it's about as worth that much to me.

Maybe a little harsh? You would think the same if you were like me and played it yourself. The main problems I have with the game are how the map is very difficult to follow and I found myself getting lost in the Stonemarket area while trying to complete some extra jobs for clients. I also felt that the UI/HUD was a little poorly done, I'm not quite sure what it was about it I didn't like so I can't offer a better review on that aspect. I looked briefly, before the purchase, at other reviews and saw that it didn't get really good reviews and I should've known better before I decided to buy it, but I wanted to still give it a shot anyways, to try and be more fair and give the makers of the game the benefit of the doubt. But never again.

I'd not suggest anyone play this game until the rebooted Thief gets a reboot itself.

reviewText: Opening Desk Drawers: The Game, 4/10\n\nStealth is somewhat decent; I enjoyed actually being able to use the shadows to my advantage. But the AI tends to spot you sometimes even when you are completely hidden. Visually the game looks pretty nice. It's a tad bit too dark at times (depending on the environment, of course). Combat system is terrible, which almost forces you to sneak and stay out of sight, regardless of  your playstyle. When in combat, you can only melee and duck. Which not only is boring, but feels clunky. I found myself loading a previous save whenever I was spotted to avoid altercations. The story is very, very forgetable. There were a few times where I had no idea what was actually going on. Maybe it was just boring to me and didn't catch my interest. Voice acting was the worst/funniest I've ever experienced. It's overly exaggerated and forced and the poor writing was not in the actors favor. In conclusion, I only paid 7 dolars for the game, so I can't complain too much. I honestly wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Save your Steam monies.

reviewText:
As a fan of the series I was very worried by the early footage of this game and felt pretty sure they were going to ruin the series.  Fortunately they do seem to have corrected a lot of issues such that I feel I can recommend the game, but it's definitely worth noting there are problems.

Short Summary

For those who want a brief summary, here's the short version first.  The game lacks polish, the level design isn't always up to par, dialogue gets repetitive at times and the story is just annoying and thoroughly awful.  It feels like 30 different people all want to tell their story and you get an incoherent noise where you can pick up some ideas from different stories.  That said, the game is still at its heart a Thief game.  If you want a traditional stealth game you can definitely find it here, especially with the remarkable amount of customisation available, and the actual gameplay itself is sufficient that I would recommend looking past the problems.

Review

So this Thief game is a series reboot which means that there is no story you're missing if you're new to the series.  There are some nods to older fans but nothing particularly relevant.  There is a central hub city where routes through open up as you advance through the main missions and there is a reasonable amount of exploration and side missions to be found.  The missions, and bigger side quests, all take place in separate levels you access by finding them around the city.

The design of the mission areas is hit and miss, with some fairly competent design let down by other areas clearly influenced by the earlier path the game was taking and, frustratingly, late in the game there are boss fights which is never a good thing in a stealth game.  Given they don't break character by forcing an actual altercation it isn't as terrible as it could have been, they all the same feel frustratingly out of place and should at least be a consequence of gameplay rather than something you just have to live with.

Another, more significant addition to the game is focus mode.  With this you can look around your world to highlight loot, hidden buttons or things you can use.  It can also be upgraded to provide a lot of additional upgrades in pickpocketing and lock picking, combat and stealth mechanics.  Whilst I welcome the mechanic being available to help people through the game and make it less frustrating, if you're really in to stealth games you're going to find it makes things a bit easy as the game goes on, especially as you can use it when your focus meter is empty whenever you want to get a lingering highlight of the important things in the world. Fortunately it can be disabled, but only when you're selecting starting difficulty settings.

Customisation is really the strongest part of the game and really sets a standard I'd like to see in more games.  First the PC port of this game has a great options menu with everything you could really want.  The options continue though in the difficulty of the game, with 3 base difficulties but also custom options you can use to tailor the game to what you want.  A few examples include disabling focus mode, no kills or knockouts, no alerts allowed and many more up to even Iron Man where failing or dying means you have to start from the beginning of the game.  The game continues though, with every single element of the HUD being able to be turned off (including loot glint and lock pick help) or being given a timed fade away for things like health bars.  You really can set this game up how you want it and it's remarkable in that sense.

Several other aspects of the game are done very well; the character feels like they're really in the world, with the use of limbs and the way the character interacts with things giving a real sense of there really being a person there.  You can learn quite a bit about the world by eavesdropping, spying on people and some reasonably well written documents and it feels reasonably organic.  The swoop feature (where you quietly dash forward) also feels really good to use and actually adds rather well to some tense stealth sections.

The AI in the game is sometimes quite good, noticing things on their patrol route have been opened and being reasonably consistent in its detection of you or otherwise.  Other times though it will bug out, will get stuck on doors, not notice really obvious things, or notice really unobvious things such as you, through a wall, one floor down, in the shadows.  It's usually alright but sometimes feels a bit under-polished, which is a phrase that would describe a lot of the game quite well unfortunately.

The world sometimes feels a bit lifeless, people have set paths with very limited dialogue options that repeat annoyingly often - you will sometimes hear 3 or 4 guards in a row repeat the exact same thing.  Some rather useful information is hidden in loading screens, such as pressing X to let go of ropes, which leads to perfectly functioning aspects of the game feeling annoying.  Sometimes your character will drop off ledges; sometimes you need to use the drop button.  Sometimes you can leave vents; sometimes you will need to try repeatedly.  Sometimes you will loot the draw with a context sensitive button; sometimes it'll move away and look around a corner with the same context sensitive button.  These kinds of things give the game the feeling of just not quite being finished.

Finally, the biggest problem with the game is the story, it damages the game.  For one thing it starts pretty bad and just gets worse every single time there is some major advancement in it.  It's so focussed on someone it's very difficult to care about that it is annoying to experience, and to make things worse because you're driven by it you're not so much going to places to steal from them, you're stealing from them on the way through.  As a result of this approach you spend a lot more time stealing cutlery than planning a big heist.  The bank heist DLC comes the closest to this ideal and really shows the potential the game really did have when unencumbered by the mess that is the story.

I appreciate this review sounds quite negative; indeed there is a lot to be negative about.  It is the weakest game in the series, but with its great customisation options you can still find a Thief game in it.  It is, at its heart, a rather competent stealth game and if you're a fan of the genre you will definitely get something out of it.  You do need to look past its rough edges though.

reviewText:
Is the game any good?
Short answer - Yes it is.
BUT, the game is plagued by a long history of expectations from previous really good games in this series, and also by troubled development, which makes it much more complicated to talk about. A lot of reviews gave this game a low score, and even though I do understand that point of view partially, I also think it is unfair most of the time.
Why? Well, more on that later.

So what is good about it?
It has very good stealth-mechanics. It has fantastic options for customizing your experience. It looks really great. Movement is smooth. It feels great to sneak, run, jump, and swoop. Good atmosphere in general. Hub-world is quite large and filled with many secrets. Many, really great side-missions. Great voice acting overall.

What is not so good about it?
Story feels unfinished and does not make much sense - it is also really cheesy and out of place. Audio is badly optimized at times. Frequent loading-screens in hub-world break immersion. You need quite a powerful machine to run it well. WEIRD April 1st bug, making it possible to complete the game, because of looping the chapter you are currently at. Bypassed by changing your date on the computer, but WHY???

Control:
Mouse and keyboard is the better experience - and it is excellent . Some controllers have fun rumble feedback, but it is not entirely worth it.

So, why are some reviews unfair?
Because of nostalgia:
Some people have spent so much time into the older games, and they had such a good time playing those games, that they expect exactly the same experience again in later installments.

Reboot-hate (stuck in the past)
You simply can't repeat  an experience - it is not the same game - It is not the same you. The feeling we remember when we played a game the first time is mostly a nostalgic memory, that is probably a little warped from reality. And with that somewhat warped memory we search for the same feeling in the new game, which we never get - hence we become upset.

I see so many reviewers critiquing the game from this angle, and so the critique is not objective in my mind. Instead of objectiviley looking at the game, everything gets judged as bad, because it does not fit the past. and many seemed to have decided in advance to hate the game no matter what it did. Another reason it is judged badly is partially because the game should be played slowly (I think) - Rushing through the game in order to write a quick review, and I think the essence of the game is mostly lost.

Do we really want the game to be the same as the older ones?
I would be really disappointed if they made Thief the same game as before with just better graphics, which I feel a lot of people are asking for.
If that is what you want, I say go play the old games instead. I'm serious. Those games exist here on steam and GoG, they are still great (and MUCH cheaper), and they have tons of mods, updates, and fan made missions that make these games highly enjoyable.

Devs. Damned if they do, damned if they don't.
And, how do you create a game that is both enjoyable for someone who has hundreds of hours invested, and for someone totally new to the series?  It would, for example, not be commercially viable to create a game just for the SMALL devote thief-community. It is also interesting that most players who are not familiar with the older games really like this new Thief.

Is this game a true thief-game?
You hide in the shadows. You can sneak, you can explore, both vertically and horizontally, you have all the interesting arrows and gadgets. The game-mechanics are really good. There is lock-picking (best in the series). The AI chatter is better than ever, even though buggy at times. The atmosphere is very tense, dark and scary. You are weak and vulnerable. There is lots of loot and hidden areas - The game is quite long and re-playable. There is aspects of the supernatural, and the world is kind of steam-punk-medieval.  Sound design is really well made (a part from the bugs), and an integral part of the game.
So, yes, it is absolutely a thief-game.

Problems?
Yes, there are quite a few. The most noticeable one is sound in general. Sure, at times the sound is really great, but it just does not seem to be mixed right. Sometimes you don't hear what you should hear, because something else is too loud. Sometimes you hear NPCs that are not in the same room as you, still as loud as they were right next to you. On occasion the music cuts out which makes you wonder if someone saw you, or something happened.
The guards seem to get stuck sometimes, but there is always a way to get around them if you have your wits around. But then there is also the occasional issue of some NPCs being completely frozen, or glitching out". None of the problems are game-breaking
date: a part of the April 1st bug that truly was a mystery. (You were kept in a loop and could not exit the current mission
recommended:
when you reloaded a save you always started from the beginning.)

What I don't like:
Oh the story... In a way

reviewText: Now I'll start off with saying I have a bias towards square enix games so I might rate this slightly higher than others, but I do believe this is a decent game. Play as Garrett, the master thief who lifts everything that isn't bolted down, but then unbolts said object and takes it. This game was the first game that ever had me play stealth in first-person which makes it more tense, but also fun. I enjoyed playing through the levels and the stealth mechanics are actually quite great making sure to hide bodies and shut cabinets and cases. I have enjoyed it so far but it of course is not without it's faults. A couple being the hub world is a terrible mess of loading screens and confusing pathways and the bow which seems like an item of paramount importance really doesn't seem to be (while playing I only ever found myself using the water arrows). The story and voice acting is rather plain, but not entirely bad and I would recommend this game only during times of steam sales where I feel the value vs. price is a bit better. 7/10

reviewText:
Is the game any good?
Short answer - Yes it is.
BUT, the game is plagued by a long history of expectations from previous really good games in this series, and also by troubled development, which makes it much more complicated to talk about. A lot of reviews gave this game a low score, and even though I do understand that point of view partially, I also think it is unfair most of the time.
Why? Well, more on that later.

So what is good about it?
It has very good stealth-mechanics. It has fantastic options for customizing your experience. It looks really great. Movement is smooth. It feels great to sneak, run, jump, and swoop. Good atmosphere in general. Hub-world is quite large and filled with many secrets. Many, really great side-missions. Great voice acting overall.

What is not so good about it?
Story feels unfinished and does not make much sense - it is also really cheesy and out of place. Audio is badly optimized at times. Frequent loading-screens in hub-world break immersion. You need quite a powerful machine to run it well. WEIRD April 1st bug, making it possible to complete the game, because of looping the chapter you are currently at. Bypassed by changing your date on the computer, but WHY???

Control:
Mouse and keyboard is the better experience - and it is excellent . Some controllers have fun rumble feedback, but it is not entirely worth it.

So, why are some reviews unfair?
Because of nostalgia:
Some people have spent so much time into the older games, and they had such a good time playing those games, that they expect exactly the same experience again in later installments.

Reboot-hate (stuck in the past)
You simply can't repeat  an experience - it is not the same game - It is not the same you. The feeling we remember when we played a game the first time is mostly a nostalgic memory, that is probably a little warped from reality. And with that somewhat warped memory we search for the same feeling in the new game, which we never get - hence we become upset.

I see so many reviewers critiquing the game from this angle, and so the critique is not objective in my mind. Instead of objectiviley looking at the game, everything gets judged as bad, because it does not fit the past. and many seemed to have decided in advance to hate the game no matter what it did. Another reason it is judged badly is partially because the game should be played slowly (I think) - Rushing through the game in order to write a quick review, and I think the essence of the game is mostly lost.

Do we really want the game to be the same as the older ones?
I would be really disappointed if they made Thief the same game as before with just better graphics, which I feel a lot of people are asking for.
If that is what you want, I say go play the old games instead. I'm serious. Those games exist here on steam and GoG, they are still great (and MUCH cheaper), and they have tons of mods, updates, and fan made missions that make these games highly enjoyable.

Devs. Damned if they do, damned if they don't.
And, how do you create a game that is both enjoyable for someone who has hundreds of hours invested, and for someone totally new to the series?  It would, for example, not be commercially viable to create a game just for the SMALL devote thief-community. It is also interesting that most players who are not familiar with the older games really like this new Thief.

Is this game a true thief-game?
You hide in the shadows. You can sneak, you can explore, both vertically and horizontally, you have all the interesting arrows and gadgets. The game-mechanics are really good. There is lock-picking (best in the series). The AI chatter is better than ever, even though buggy at times. The atmosphere is very tense, dark and scary. You are weak and vulnerable. There is lots of loot and hidden areas - The game is quite long and re-playable. There is aspects of the supernatural, and the world is kind of steam-punk-medieval.  Sound design is really well made (a part from the bugs), and an integral part of the game.
So, yes, it is absolutely a thief-game.

Problems?
Yes, there are quite a few. The most noticeable one is sound in general. Sure, at times the sound is really great, but it just does not seem to be mixed right. Sometimes you don't hear what you should hear, because something else is too loud. Sometimes you hear NPCs that are not in the same room as you, still as loud as they were right next to you. On occasion the music cuts out which makes you wonder if someone saw you, or something happened.
The guards seem to get stuck sometimes, but there is always a way to get around them if you have your wits around. But then there is also the occasional issue of some NPCs being completely frozen, or glitching out". None of the problems are game-breaking
date: a part of the April 1st bug that truly was a mystery. (You were kept in a loop and could not exit the current mission
recommended:
when you reloaded a save you always started from the beginning.)

What I don't like:
Oh the story... In a way
hoursPlayed: it seems like they put some real effort into it
voteText: and the voice-acting and cut-scenes are nice. But
helpfulPercent: it also does not seem to head anywhere - Some cut-scenes just did not feel like they fit the situation you were in previously or after.  You get the sensation the story was quickly put together before the deadline

Verdict:
I say that Thief is a very good game despite its problems. The stealth mechanics

reviewText:
A lot of people are hating on this game because of what it didn't do right, but I didn't see enough people give credit where it's due.
- it's a very difficult game (playing on hardest difficulty). You have a very limited number of lethal arrows, their cost is prohibitive. The AI is very good and there are no apparent ways to cheese your way around, blackjacking everyone, like in the original Thief games. You lack a consistent way of taking out guards if they spot you, so you're forced to use the stealth approach most of the time. The combat is stacked against you and you're certainly no Corvo Attano.
- the atmosphere is incredibly well executed. The animations are excellent: the way Garret nudges doors closed, the way he  opens chests and safes, his light touch as he feels for hidden buttons behind a painting. The sound effects are very good, the overheard dialogue is great; you'll once again find yourself trying your best to only walk on softs carpets, or standing still in a shadowy nook listening to the guards chat. The lighting effects are gorgous and very reliable in terms of  where you will be hidden and where you will be lit up (with a couple of exceptions, here and there).
- the world is executed with a clear attention to details. The environment is very rich and believable.
- it is mostly a linear experience, but there is at least one huge level, open for exploration, that for me counter balances the rest of the game (A Man Apart - Northcrest Manor).
- the developers put quite a bit of effort into creating missions that feel different and are not just variations of a manor raid. The morgue, the brothel, the ancient ruins, the asylum - they are all memorable locations.

All in all, Thief isn't the perfect reboot, but I think it's very good if you approach it with an open mind and not expecting a reskinned The Dark Project. It's main weaknesses are that the level design is too linear and that it came out after Dishonored, really. If the developers take into account the feedback they got from the players and focus on a more open level design for a potential sequel, it will be a very good game.

reviewText: I'm kind of surprised how tedius it is right from the start. Opening windows and lockpicking and all other animations are so sluggish, that they're annoying to have to wait for thousands of times you will be forced to. I've already grabbed like 3 dozen of each of the 5 or so types of basic loot. 30 something hair brushes, pens, scissors, etc. This is just dumb. They should have just gotten rid of all common loot, made the game less linear, and only had a few major target items with multiple methods of reaching them. This game feels like a case of no one having the balls to admit that this gameplay structure isn't fun. It's also so dark and void of any color that I tend to get sleepy after 30 minutes. I know it's supposed to be, but with practically no suspense or threat even when caught, I find myself not caring. You can billyjack anyone upside the head and easily dodge sword swings if caught. Every mission and chapter has weird arbitrary goals that arent fun to accomplish, like extinguish 10 fires, pickpocket 5 guards. I mean...why?

reviewText: Thief Deadly Shadows was one of my favorite games and this was a big let down for bringing the series back. The game is extremely repetative, the voice acting is sub-par and the story hasn't really been that interesting (just finished Chapter 6). It's enjoyable when you first start the game and the graphics are very well done. But when you've snooped through the same drawers and cabinets, heard the same NPC voices complaing about sloop over and over again, and pushed the same plank of wood out of the way in another back ally for the 100th time, the joy fades fast. Pick it up when it's cheap if you can't resist another steath game. I'd highly recommend Dishonored instead if you're looking for something to fill that need now, though.

reviewText:
So I got this game over the Summer Sale with high expectations.... only to be let down. Alright let me get this clear, Thief is NOT a bad game. Yes I do not recommend it but I can't trash on it either. Thief is an alright but there are a lot of things which really prevent it from being a good game. First of all is game feel. I've played a lot of stealth based games in my time so I would like to think that I know what makes a good stealth game. This game right of the bat does not have that feel which it should aim to have. A big problem for me is that the game feels too slow and clunky most of the time. It gives me a hard time believing that I'm a master thief when all of my movements are slow and incoherent. Thieves should be quick and nimble and I feel that Garrett, in this game, is not. I really wanted to give this game a try and I tried to like it but it's mechanics and controls really prevent me from doing so. Secondly the game lags quite a lot for me. My PC is not a high end PC which can run the newest Crysis with max graphics but I can confidently say that it can run a lot of games on their highest settings. Yet for some reason I get a stable 24 fps when I run Thief, even in the lower settings. Maybe it's something on my end but then again maybe it's not.


Want a good stealth game? Play Dishonored. Maybe even play some of the older games in the Thief franchise, which I have not played myself but I've heard that they're fantastic. Reading the other reviews here on Steam makes me feel that my arguments are valid given that a few of my complaints were addressed by other consumers as well. However as with any review I can't guarantee that my experience with the game will be the same as yours. If I didn't convince you to not buy the game then go ahead and buy it, you might have a blast playing it. Then again you might not.

I tried to compliment the game somewhere in this review but the only thing I could think of were the different types of arrows they had in the game.

reviewText:
Overall I think it's an okay game.

What I liked:
-Interesting features (blowing out candles, environment obstacles such as making noise from going through water too fast or stepping on broken glass, finding locks behind picture frames, etc.)
-Charts of what type of player you are in the game (ghost, opportunist, predator) and stats (collectables, knockouts, etc.)

What I disliked:
-Unobservant AI (you could stand directly in front of enemies and they won't see you most of the time)
-Linear missions (there was only one path to complete missions and work your way through the levels)

I prefer Dishonored over this game as I found Dishonored was more open, had better AI, and was fun to play. I did play Dishonored first and am new to the Thief games.

In the end I would not recommend this game.

reviewText:
NOTE: I've added this whole review to my blog which also includes a few bonus images. Check it here: http://opbroadcast.com/?p=144

There are quite a few top negative responses to Thief, so for the benefit of my friends I thought I should drop some of my own thoughts. I'll preface though: If you're someone who's looking for Thief 4, or a true continuation of the decade-old series, you've come to the wrong place. Even so, I still enjoyed my time with Thief and I'd gladly recommend it if you're a fan of first person stealth-action games.

Graphics and Style:
The promotional screenshots for this game are terrible. Just look above and what do you see? Boring monochromatic vistas set in a pseudo-English, steampunk town. Even the gameplay footage above isn't that great. However, once you're in-game, the atmospheric quality is sold incredibly well. This is a dead city, filled with dust and decay. High contrast shadows draw attention to the light sources to create an incredible noir-like environment, and each location has enough unique architecture to keep you interested in exploring the space.

Story:
This certainly is the weakest part of Thief. The characters are laughably bad and the voice acting is delivered awkwardly (especially Garret's want-a-be noir quips). Square Enix (mostly from the Edios run studios) has always had a bizarre cast of characters.  (See Hitman's latex nuns, Dues Ex's painfully racist informant, etc.) Accents change on the fly, modern curses are thrown around like a modern rap artist, and the in-game notes are poorly written and unfocused. There are some good points though, in regards to the atmospheric storytelling. Walking through the hub town you'll hear muffled stories through the walls, some simply giving depth to the backstory of the city, while others can potentially provide you with hints on finding hidden loot throughout the world.

Gameplay:
The meat. The real reason you should be thinking about buying this game. I could talk about all the systems, annoyances and enjoyments, and everything else that made up the 20 or so hours I invested into this game. Many of these things you've probably already heard about elsewhere and have been written on extensively and far better than I could have, so I'll summarize first:

Thief was fun.

It's clear this is a game from the same studio as Dues Ex Human Revolution. Even though it's a separate team, you can't work in the same room as someone without borrowing a few of their ideas. It's also likely the development was influenced by Dishonored, as the game borrows quite a bit from its systems. (Ironic, as Dishonored was also inspired by the classic thief series.) While Dishonored was more of assassination sandbox where the game gives you a few tools, a loose objective, and tells you to have fun, Thief is directed. There's still some alternate paths and open exploration (especially in the hub city), but most of the primary missions give you a series of spaces to navigate through and it's up to you how stealthy or murderous you decide to be. This is especially prevalent in the side-quest missions, which mostly involve one self-contained zone giving you more power to plan your assault, rob your target, and attempt to make it back out in one piece.

Oh, and I'll touch on movement for a moment, seeing as the lack of a jump" key is a heated contention. When you start
date: it definitely feels weird not being able to jump up on things. However
recommended: the game features a surprisingly robust contextual movement system (it's a good thing they haven't invented fingerprinting yet as Garret touches damn near anything he gets close to)
hoursPlayed: so you get used to the flow of movement rather quickly. There was only a few times I had trouble with jumping and most of them involved me trying to get somewhere I probably shouldn't have been anyways. "Swooping" between shadows and cover is tremendously fun though
voteText: and while I wish it didn't come with the lack of a jump key
helpfulPercent:
I hope more games include it as a potential action.

In Conclusion:
Thief is not a fantastic game

votesFunny: I found fun even when it's issues and strange design choices emerged. I even enjoyed it enough to complete most (if not all) of the game's side-quests and collection opportunities

reviewText:
This was that kind of game that comes with a lot of hype and turns into meat for the gaming community.
Was told not to spend money on it but, as I usually do, I ignored those coments and focused on enjoying the game.

Result? how about a 7.5/10?

Let's go by parts:

GRAPHICS:
Cool stuff. Probably not at the top level of detail of current games, but sacrifices a bit on details to gain more realism in enviormnets: putting shadows (which are not just for visual but also affects the gameplay), fog, and cool stuff that makes you feel you actually are in the city.
Good stuff here let's go with 9/10

GAMEPLAY:
As any game of the genre it has some static mechanics like pickpocketing, or forcing doors that become little bit repetitive.
It fortunely has no QTE (quick time events) but there are too many times in which you got to spam your e in order to do a single action. Disliked that.
By the other hand it brings lots of possibilities to de user so @he can choose how to complete the levels.
However, at the end of each mission, when the statistics appear it calculates strangely and being a stealthy guy that doesn't even knock up guys becomes a very challenging (but not really in the good way) task.
What is true, nevertheless, is that everything is fluid, things happen as expected in real life, guards detect you mostly when they should (despite you are in shadows, which causes them to have a blindness attack and ignore you even 2 steps away).
Finally, I shouldn't probably be reviewing this part, but lately some games come with bugs and ♥♥♥♥ that only breaks the gameplay and the overall expirience, and I've been very satisfied this game does not have any of these.
I think I'd be running an 8/10


LENGTH:
As you can see I spend about 30 hours to complete the first big half of optional quests and the main story. I must say I'm a calm player and i'm not always hesitating to see more, so if I want to spend an hour exploring the city looking for something I miss (even if it's a single purse) I do. I guess you can rush the main story in about 15 hours and you have 60 granted hours if your goal is to complete 100% the game.
For this section i'm going with another 8/10

So we have 9,8,8 why does the overall review show a 7? We are missing a part:

PLOT:
Far behind my expectations. It's not bad, the world created and the main line of stroy are really not bad (prehaps they are not great or fantastic, but pretty solid though). It's just they could have worked it out a lot more. The end of the game is clear but leaves you with lots of unnecessary questions (and i'm not refering at the question they want as to have an individual answer to, but simple questions which you expect an answer before the end of the games) I miss that and this is how all is connected" part to enjoy the plot.

I judge a game by the expirience it transfers
date: not for the cool programing or the fancy graphics. And in this case I finished the game with a "meh.. was good
hoursPlayed: far from being a masterpiece
voteText:
but still... correct".

That's why i'm giving this part a 5/10

THE BEST:
Chapter 5. Really enjoyed that moment. The enviorment and feeling that gameplay makes you feel.

THE WORST:
More things of the plot needed to be explained
helpfulPercent: good backline story but could have been worked out a lot more.\n\nTO SUM UP: If you have a really funny mechanic you can abuse it's ok to focus your game on it
votesHelpful: else you will need a strong plot which this game has not. Prefectly build
votesTotal: enjoyable and fun to play
votesFunny: with an EPIC chapter 5 and lots of possiblities. Just doesn't transfer the expirience it could if the plot was more polished."

reviewText:
Brief version.
- Upsides: Awesome atmosphere, good narrative style, nicely written sidemission, somewhat satisfying main plot.
- Downsides in a word: Gameplay. It isn't too bad, but it's so clearly flawed that it sometimes ruins the upsides.
- Evaluation: 6/10.

Longer version:
I played Thief's games a long time ago, and this pseudo-reboot/follow-up/whatever-it-is isn't anything close to the originals. Honestly, just the drop from 90+ metacritic score to 70 says something about a very wide gap, and that gap is real (and even bigger than 20 points out of 100).
So why the hell do I recommend this game? Because it's still a decent game, and it provides for good entertainment. It is a 6/10 game coming from a 9/10 and 10/10 series, so if you played the previous Thief's titles be warned: you'll be disappointed, mainly by gameplay mechanics. I'll start with the bad to end with the ok.

What is wrong about gameplay?
- Sounds: you can hear YOUR footsteps even when you stay still and turn around (wtf!) but you can't hear a GUARD's footsteps if he's around a corner more than 2/3 meters away. Bad. Plus, into the houses you just hear very loud random footsteps/conversations from the other floors of the building (which you can't access). This this could be very cool if played right, but it becomes annoying since it's too frequent, and the people in the city seems like a bunch of sleep-walkers.
- Random dialogues: while missions and main plot dialogues are satisfying to my taste, you keep overhearing like 6-7 exchanges over and over again while you roam the city, all from the same voices. Are those guys following you? Also, there is a chance that you overhear something useful, pointing you at thieving objectives like sub-sub-plots: cool... except it happened only 2 times in the whole game... meh...
- Stealth is often awkward, mainly for two reasons: sight and sound (again). Sight - you are hidden in the shadows or you are not. In the first event, guards may also walk close to you - too close - they then look your way and they... don't detect you. What? Not very realistic, not in a *realistic* stealth game. In the second event they may see you just right and from afar: it's ok, but isn't there any middle-ground? - Sound - surfaces almost do not matter unless it's glass: you crouch if you want to move silently or you stand to move faster, except on carpets where you can move faster and still be silent: that was so cool when pace of movent and sound were so important, in previous Thief's installments, but now they introduced the swoop: if you want to move fast then just stay crouched and *swoop* around. Noise/speed trade-off doesn't exist anymore.
- Swoop: sounds cool to me, and it really makes you feel a shadowy thief with great skill, but it's just too much prone to abuse. You want to go around faster? Swoop. You want to reach the back of a guard without alerting him when you WOULD alert him if you walked? Swoop. It's so abusable that it seems like a cheat rather than the cool tool it is supposed to be.
- Footprints: they made you leave footprints in a 2002 game (if I remember the year right), now in 2014 you randomly walk into oil, pools of blood and such and do not leave any trail, not even for a few steps. Are you kidding me? That was very disappointing.

AI is ok. Despite the many critics to that, I find the AI consistent enough, if you purge its behaviour from the effects of what's above. Only thing is: you are in a house with only 3 guards, you knock out the patrolling one: good. Wouldn't the other two notice he's missing, after a while? If so the game *realism* would have been so improved... but whatever.

Let's get to the upsides!
- Voice acting: some hardcore fans make themselves disgusted by the voice acting because it's different from how it was before. Why? Get over it, dudes, this one is good and well done.
- Story: it's not a story of overwhelmingly epic proportions, but it's very good and entertainig. Moreover it's very well-balanced between thieving, discovering things (you won't understand half of what's happening unless you search for the documents and read them), supernatural activity, crowd madness when they revolt... a good story, well written too.
- Atmosphere: awesome and very well designed, could only be better with less random-dialogues (see above) and more dialogues giving some insights on the city life. But grafically it's very good.
- Overall feeling: if you are able to get over the downsides, Thief leaves a lasting feeling of... playing a dark gothic, almost satisfying stealth game, and that's why I recommend it.
- Interface design: people complains a lot about it, and I wonder why. Focus makes the game like 100 times easier? Map indicators disturbs you and prevent you from feeling the exploration/orientation stuff you want? Frigging DISABLE it. I played with everything disabled and I like it, but there are many players too used to mmorpg (lost without map indicators) and some players who play to have a good time without having to pay too much attention (they are welcome to use focus). Who care? Let people play the game the way they want. Customizable difficulty/helpers are a BIG upside to this game IMO.

Last thing worth mentioning, not related to the game but to its development. Many of the flaws above were highlighted during early beta stages by fans screaming in anguish. Why didn't the developers listen to the often good advise? Did they WANT to make a mediocre game? That I cannot understand but it isn't a reason to hate the game, rather to despise the developers' hybris.

reviewText: I'm kind of surprised how tedius it is right from the start. Opening windows and lockpicking and all other animations are so sluggish, that they're annoying to have to wait for thousands of times you will be forced to. I've already grabbed like 3 dozen of each of the 5 or so types of basic loot. 30 something hair brushes, pens, scissors, etc. This is just dumb. They should have just gotten rid of all common loot, made the game less linear, and only had a few major target items with multiple methods of reaching them. This game feels like a case of no one having the balls to admit that this gameplay structure isn't fun. It's also so dark and void of any color that I tend to get sleepy after 30 minutes. I know it's supposed to be, but with practically no suspense or threat even when caught, I find myself not caring. You can billyjack anyone upside the head and easily dodge sword swings if caught. Every mission and chapter has weird arbitrary goals that arent fun to accomplish, like extinguish 10 fires, pickpocket 5 guards. I mean...why?

reviewText:
Certainly not a bad game, but has some short commings.  Main storyline is quite short and relies on you screwing up and replaying to give length to the game.  The rope arrow mechanic appeared to be lifted from Tomb Raider in terms of appearance.  Also some sound effects such as the threat/beginning of being detected I'm fairly certain were lifted from Dishonored - or at least very similar.  The bow seems very weak even when upgraded and the story is pretty much misery from start to finish leaving a somewhat well that was all pointless" taste in your mouth.

I think there is more content to the game than I witnessed but it would require a completionist attitude to appreciate it.  I simply didn't love the mechanics enough to follow this through.

All that said it is quite pretty and is a solid stealth title with multiple ways of playing and dealing with the presented challenges.  I'd be disappointed if I had paid release price for this but it is a nice title if discounted."

reviewText:
It's 2014 and I had more fun going back to Thief Gold / Metal Age / Deadly Shadows, than playing this game.

Thief game isn't about stealing things... it's about Garrett and then stealing things.
So game is playable, and you may even enjoy it from time to time but is painfully shallow, main character doesn't remind me of Garrett I know and it's really hard to immerse in this game.

I'm not sure what went wrong with map design but I had that impression that developers wanted me to choose one and only patch to complete the game and there is no fun in that.

Community mentioned bugs but I haven't encountered that many. I was looking forward to play this game, because it was great that someone noticed great title like Thief. Developers have put in this game a lot of new stuff and completely forgot abut everything that made previous games fun to play.

Thief 4 is great disappointment, don't buy it.

reviewText:
TL;DR
The gameplay is meh, watered down for beginners and there's not much to do about that. Higher difficulties can't change it. Difficulty changes, not the bad game design. Fighting is really meh, sneaking is pretty okay.
Visuals are disgusting and monotonous, doesn't do a depressing and brooding mood justice.
Story is convoluted but more importantly stupid and the characters are uninteresting and bland.

I would recommend it, but there's so many better options, including the original game this is based off of.
Try Dishonored for a much better designed levels and more interesting, properly told story with unique visuals and setting.
Try Mark of the Ninja for probably one of the best true stealth games out there, though it is 2D.
Try Metal Gear Solid, besides just in general, it's usually considered what ultimately popularized the stealth genre.




Compared to the original, this new version is simplified and dumbed everything down, makes everything feel too slow paced (for me at least) and mediocre, almost insultingly so.
It lacks new variety or creativity in change, and while the bow n' arrows are nice, they are very situational (ex. rope arrows can only be in extremely specific spots). Focus mechanic is very meh, it is the here's what you have to do" button

reviewText:
I personally regret buying this game.  I was truly expecting so much more and I was left disappointed.  I watched some videos of game play and foolishly decided too quickly that this game was something incredible.  That was my mistake, and I'm simply writing a review to hopefully prevent someone else from making the same mistake.

The storyline had promise, but it was very poorly put together and very difficult to follow.  This continues until the very end of the game and you're left feeling as though nothing was resolved.  By the end of the game the only thing accomplished is stopping Orion from turning everyone into monsters and saving Erin. ‘Nothing’ in the city changes. Gloom is still running rampant, people are still dying, the city is still corrupt and now it has no leaders...

The side missions are a catastrophe.  They are bland and unrewarding.  You simply enter the location steal an object and your mission is complete.  There is never anyone inside the house to challenge your sneaking skills or anything at all.  You don't even have to deliver the object after you've stolen it.    You simply get a tiny description on the mission and that's it.

The full map and mini map are extremely lacking with barely any detail put into them whatsoever.  Certain areas of the city are mission locked and the areas that you can explore never change. It's a very boring and bland place to explore.  All of the accessible ‘houses’ are rundown and every room looks practically the same. Really, you don’t get to explore houses as 90% of the house is always off limits and no one is ever inside either.  I also hate how you can't fast travel.  That is extremely annoying, especially when everything about the 'free roaming area' of the city is repetitive.

The population of the city consists of possibly at most four generic AI faces.  There are never any events in the city other than the occasional hanging which consists of a crowd between three and four people.  The city doesn’t feel real at all.  Gossip between AI’s never change either even if you’ve stolen the loot they’re discussing they just keep looping forever.  They even follow the same path after the events of chapter six when their city is on fire burning around them! They don’t react AT ALL.

There are so many features that could have been implemented into this game that would make it incredible.  But, aside from stunning visuals of the game it really has nothing else to offer.

reviewText:
After Dishonored (if you like the stealth genre but havent played Dishonored yet grab that one, as its one of the best game of the generation) I was really excited for Thief, the next stealth game set in a dark desperate steampunk like environment, but I was very wrong with my high ecpectations. The only thing this game excells in is the very nice graphic, all other thins are bad to medicore. So here is my breakdown:
(+)Very nice looking graphics
(+) good stealth engine with a nice but somewhat narrow selection of gadgets (mainly different arrow types)
(-) Very limited freedom which imo is a natural expectation against a stealth game, maps are almoast entirelly linear.
(-)Very very bad mimimap of the city hub which absolutelly does not aid you in getting where you want, its frustrating searching the right path to the actual quest location
(-)Very very bad secondary quest design where actually the main difficulty is to get to the quest site and not the sloving of the (mainly very trivial side quests) this is largely due to the useles minimap
(-)The selection of sounds and banter and chats of NPS is substandard
(-)No real background story of main character and the city
(-)Story is somewhat weak..
(-)The gameplay revolves around thieving thins which gets dull after a while because mainly you steal pottery, forks, scissors,  small liqour flasks and the like useless junk...

Althogether a quite frustrating game..
J.

reviewText: I haven't had the chance to play the older Thief games just yet, but I was greatly impressed by this reboot's mechanics, graphics, etc. I was once so immersed in the game during a chapter centering around the Asylum that my cat jumped on me and I screamed. :D As far as games go, I think people generally downvote this one because they've played the older games and are unimpressed by the newest addition to the series, even if it's a reboot - for someone coming into the series belatedly and playing this one first, the story was very interesting and the attention to detail for stealth missions and the chase scene over rooftops kind of threw in a little extra thrill for me. Overall, I thought it was great, but other people might not. Still happy with my purchase.

reviewText:
Aside from the lockpicking mechanics, this game is BAD, BAD, BAD.
In comparison to other games in a similar genre:

1-Awful interface- clunky, with redundant keys for some movement, while jump is missing except in certain situations.

2-Level design is massively linear; including the hub. No fast travel and it gets really boring.

3- Bad design ideas make exploration a chore. 'Rewards' rarely worth the cost of the materials you had to use to get there. Hidden traps require turning on 'trap detecting vision' and avoiding.

4- Stealth mechanics horribly simplistic, easy, unrealistic and unfun.

5- Gimmicky 'player punishing' gameplay (not challenging- just makes you wait and wastes time)
Sometimes you follow the map, break into a house (takes ages- and then a loading screen)- to realize my entrance was surrounded by traps and I was then expected to backtrack out of the window (another loading screen) and take a back entrance (another loading screen) to just walk in.

Uninstalled it. Regretted my purchase. DO NOT BUY. If you like this kind of game- buy Dishonoured"
date: or Assassin's Creed (either Black Flag or Rogue). Avoid this game at all costs!"

reviewText:
TL;DR: Not a successor to the Thief-Franchise but (except for the story) a damn good stealth-game on its own.


As you might imagine, I do not have much experience with the Thief franchise, due to me being of very young age. I wasn't even born when the first Thief was released. However, I do have experience with stealth-games in general, and I hope to bring you a detailed insight of Thief 2014 and answer your question if you should buy it or not.

STORY
The Story begins with Garrett robbing a Safe for an expensive necklace. After he escapes the attic he found the safe in, he meets his friend Erin, who leads Garrett through a kind-of-tutorial-area. At the end of the mission, the two observe a group of people who look like priests or monks performing a ritual in front of something called the 'Primal Stone'. The Building Collapses, Erin falls down and dies, Garrett falls down, survives, but falls unconscious.
A Year later, Garrett wakes up while two beggars try to smuggle his body into his hideout in the clocktower in the center of the city. The smuggling attempt fails, one beggar is killed, the other runs away and Garrett is on his own, with the claw he inherited" from Erin. He later learns that the main antagonist is still alive
recommended: the "Gloom" is running about in the city.\nGarrett now works for several sides
hoursPlayed: his fence Basso
voteText: Orion
helpfulPercent: the leader of the resistance
votesHelpful:
and as a freelance to discover the secret behind his hallucinations of Erin in some kind of otherworld.

HUBWORLD / THIEVERY
In the Hubworld you can take side-missions or go and heist houses at your own leisure. There's loot everywhere and some guards even carry little valuables on their belt

reviewText:
So I got thief on a special deal and decided, before i play it, to play Thief Gold. Thief Gold is the original and features many great things. It has a range of arrows that the player can use to do a lot of things from putting out torches to causing distractions on the other side of the room. It is older than me so my hopes were not that high but it is still a very challenging game.
But anyway, to the game in question. The first thing I noticed was the fantastic PC port. I was not expecting this but you can change almost everything including controls, audio, graphics etc. Jumping into the game I found myself in a world of grim beauty. The artwork creates a very good atmosphere along with the eary music that keeps you on edge.

Those are all nice things but after completing a couple missions I realised the city/hub world was an always on". The guards will always want to kill you and that makes getting around to the shops quite annoying. I read some reviews of people saying they liked this as it was good for practising but I found it more of a nuisance. Another unneeded nuisance is that
recommended: the only way to increase arrow holding capacity is to buy three extra DLCs all 79p each. It seems cheap but I do not want to pay money for something they could neatly add as the player gains more focus points. That leads me on to the skill points in thief called focus points. They are gained from completing certain missions and by paying in game gold to "The Queen of Beggars" for an ever increasing price. This is fine. I am perfectly happy with the gaining of focus points but not so happy with the usage. The skill "Trees"
hoursPlayed: even though they are barely branches
voteText: consist of two perks; one will read something along the lines of "Slightly encrease your ability to..." the second one will be along the lines of "Majorly encrease your ability to...". I do not see a point in having them if they barely do anything. Even the first branch gets given a point already allocated to it before you get given an open map
helpfulPercent:
leaving one space left for upgrade that early on in the game.

The puzzles were another thing that stood out to me. They all seemed so forced like a cry of attension reminding everyone you bought a game with more than stealth. THey never really fit into place and delay the proper gameplay.

At the end of each level you are "rewarded" for how you played. I say "Rewarded" because I have yet to see what it does besides XP. The three wins you can get are Opportunist
votesHelpful: Predator and Ghost. I put them in order of how good it feels to get them
votesTotal: Opportunist being last. Opportunist is where you steal a lot of things and put out the most light sources but doesn't feel as rewarding as the others. In the first mission it teels the that the main character
votesFunny: Garrett
commentsCount: is against killing people then lets you get rewarded for killing as many people as possible. The game should strive towards making people want Ghost or Opportunist
column16:
not just Ghost.

Another thing that made me want to steal less was the fact houses had around 2 things to loot in them and some even had really oddly placed traps that make their houses unsusable and just dumb thief killing machines.

The combat was actually quite clever. In the original you were given a sword and blackjack
column17: but in this game you do not get a sword. This makes people want to do more stealth than if they could just complete the game with stabing everyone under the sun. The blackjack is still used for takedowns
column18: although in an animation format instead a 'Click to hit' way
column19: but you can press 'r' (by default) to hit with your blackjack. One verse one battles are easy enough with correct dodging along with one verse two battles
column20: but any more and you are certain to loose life.\n\nOverall Thief was still a good game
column21: it has an immaculate stealth system and an atmosphere that keeps you on edge with the chance of guards always being around the corner. I will compare it to the original and say it clung to it like it should. So I will give this game 7/10 as it seems completely finished just could be better in all the above stated reasons. :3"

reviewText: For a game trying so hard to be Dishonored, you'd think it take some of the things people liked about Dishonored. The level design was the standout part of Dishonored, with open, expansive levels with plenty of paths and secrets. At first glance, Thief's levels look like they have a taken a page from the same playbook Dishonored copy-pasted from, but once you explore a little, you'll realize that there is never more than two paths on each level. There is a level where you have to sneak into a mansion. There were two obvious paths into the mansion: one through the front door, surrounded by about six guards with the intelligence of a Michael Bay fan; and another path leading to a vent, which was completely unguarded. I first went through the vent but, upon realizing that the vent just put me behind the front door, I reloaded and played the other path.\nAnother bonus of Dishonored were the abilities, each of which had their own use for exploring the levels. Thief's abilities are almost all boring passives, that I didn't upgrade at all after the initial level. Thief's abilities have no use in the levels, they open no new paths. There is almost no point to stealing things after the first few levels, as once you have the wrench and the wirecutters, the upgrades are almost completely useless. The focus is lifted right out of Hitman: Absolution because originality is hard.\nThe game pretends to encourage different playstyles but anything other than pure stealth is completely unreasonable. The only way to kill guards is the bow and all of the lethal arrows are absurdly expensive. I'm alright with a game being a stealth game, Square Enix, you don't need to cater to the ritalin popping droolers who get bored when their fellow man isn't being exterminated at a rapid pace. Have some backbone and stick to your guns: If you want to make a stealth game, make a stealth game.

reviewText:
The struggle to enjoy this game. As a long time Thief fan this just does not feel like Theif at all and even as a stealth game its not really that good either. From the boring level design to the audio engine which pales in comparison to Thief: Deadly Shadows, and the inconsistant A.I. its just a shame to see one of my favourite franchises hit this kind of low.

The story is like something out of a childs book and isnt very interesting and it doesnt do a good job of making you feel as if you are somewhere you are not meant to be unlike earlier Thief games, in this you just feel like an everyday petty thief.

Though I have only played 4 hours of it so far I just cant bring myself to play in long stretches unlike the previous games were they had me glued to my screen.

As of now its a no but if it gets any better the further it goes in then I will change my review.

reviewText: I own every game of the Thief-series, I loved the first 3 and would put Thief 1 and 2 in my all time favorites list. But Thief 4 was such a horrible dissapointment that I felt the need to write a review for the first time, and warn others. If you have any love for the old Thief games I suggest you avoid this like the plague. The game felt as if they had removed everything that I liked about the series with surgical precision. The game reminded me of Call of Duty way too often in it's casual, linear and clichéd way. Dishonored and Amnesia: dark descent gave me more nostalgic thief feeling" than this game did.\n\nI miss the freedom to explore
date: I miss the little details that made the game-world come alive for me in the old games
recommended: I don't like the cutscenes and I don't like the way Garret's character changed (or should I say "was removed"
hoursPlayed: because what's left of him is so generic and lame that the old and the new Garret have little more in common than their name). I even preferred the sounddesign and ambiance in the old games. It just felt more real and the musical action cues in Thief 4 seem so out of place. When I take down an enemy with the blackjack I don't need to hear the music freak out every... single... time.... It breaks immersion more than it helps in my opinion.\n\nI have been playing the old Thief 1 when I got too frustrated with the newest installment of the series and I have to say I just have more fun with it. The gameplay is way better and more rewarding in my opinion. All the added mechanics in Thief 4 just make it feel more artificial and contrived to me. Never did I have the feeling of being in a world that I could explore or that any of my decisions mattered. Also Thief 1 on the easiest setting is in my opinion for the most part harder than Thief 4 on hardest setting. One bossfight in Thief 4 was incredibly unfair and hard though

reviewText:
I went into this not expecting much, in fact I went in not expecting anything at all. Which is probably the best thing you can do. This is the first thief game I've played seriously. From my understanding all the thief games have a certain level of mysticism.

Traversal - I think the open “city” bits are extremely small and overly designed. It doesn't feel like I'm traversing a living city. Cutting through the same windows to steal things from houses that in addition to barely ever having people inside don't feel like houses I had a choice in entering or not. Absolutely everything in the city feels contrived and convoluted. This game would have greatly benefited from a more organic feeling of being nimble and clever during traversal.

Mechanics and narrative – Think Skyrim but only the thieves guild and without a decent combat system. Just a mediocre one. And zero to no character customization. Its got your sneak walk, its got dashing, its got takedowns and a wide variety of arrows for specific situations. Its a stealth game. However very little of the time do you ever need to use them. The AI is awful. Aside from technical glitches where upon loading in area NPC's, they were stuck in the T-pose. You can circumvent the AI very easily. And checkpoints are virtually everywhere.

The storyline isn't... uninteresting.. its just kind of boring to a degree. At one point I felt like. “Yes, I'm aware this building is burning down but I really need to steal all this cutlery” It wasn't uninteresting to watch unfold it just felt like felt separate from my own desire to steal all the spoons in the city. And to the games credit in Chapter 5. Despite feeling like I, myself was the shadows previously. I truly felt like I was being hunted in this chapter. Definitely my favorite chapter story wise. It pretty much can be summed up with “I believe myself to be a Honorable thief, my girlfriend who is also a thief is doing something I believe is dishonorable. My arrogance got her killed but I can't remember exactly what happened. Magic turns out to be real and my girlfriend is not dead. Girlfriend is bitter and feels betrayed. Use magic to stop her from being crazy meanwhile the city is filled with death and disease and a new religion is born by a false prophet.

Personally I like being a sneaky rogue type in games. I like duping, tricking and outsmarting people however you only really get decent satisfaction from disarming the traps or picking a lock successfully while the guy on patrol is walking toward you. Only when he arrives at the door, its closed and you're on the other side.

reviewText:
Felt Like I Was Playing an Unfinished Game
The long and the short of it is this: Thief is, quite simply, not a game I would ever recommend playing. To anyone. Do I regret playing it? Not exactly; some parts of the game were fun and enjoyable. But on a whole, I could have spent that time on a better, more worthwhile game. Dishonored and the original Thief games come to mind, and I've heard good things about Deus Ex. I have a few main reasons for disliking it this game: bad gameplay, poor level design, and low quality writing.

Gameplay

I found the gameplay to be severely underdeveloped, counter-intuitive, and choppy. There is no lean" control as there is in Dishonored and Amnesia: The Dark Descent. Not only can you not perform this simple motion wherever and whenever you like in Thief
date: but if you're going to look around a corner you have to approach the corner and press E. Which is the action button for everything. So while you are searching a desk
recommended: you may find that Garrett gets in one of his jumpy moods and suddenly huddles behind it
hoursPlayed: peeking cautiously around the corner at...nothing. All because this feature was poorly designed. Also
voteText: counter-intuitive actions. You hold E to peek through a keyhole and press right-mouse to stop? Who thought of that awful idea? It makes sense to me that you press one button to start an action and the same button to stop it.\n\nAlso

On several occasions while I played the game

Writing

Conclusion

Thief was a game that tried to be everything that Dishonored was
