reviewText:
So it's been 30 hours so far, and even though I'm having such a blast, the collecting of EVERY SINGLE LOOT (OCD) is starting to get to me. I just had to get that out of the way, here and now! Surely Garret is content by now?! Moving on...

This reboot of the original Thief will not be suited to all, in fact I wouldn't be surprised if only 1 in 10 people actually will enjoy it, as the taste is a rather specialized one. If you are a diehard fan of the original series you may or may not enjoy this one, since while it still captures the essence behind Thief, the whole openworld experience is quite hampered with long loading times, awkwardly placed transitional zones and poor openworld map layout, other than that it is everything you could want from a Thief game!

If you're used to running around and killing everything without repercussions then I suggest you look elsewhere. As the original games, Thief is very unforgiving in all but stealth actions. And rightly so, for this is a fully stealth based game, and thieves are no match in combat. Thief, not Rogue, there is a difference. They're light footed, they get in and out, that's all there is to it.

A lot of people seem to want to compare this game to Dishonoured, and while the two may share similarities I can honestly say from playing both that Thief is the one to go for a complete stealth experience and a very dark storyline whereas Dishonoured you can get away with pretty much anything you do, without a real challenge (unless you impose one on yourself).

All looting and thieving aside, Thief has one of those rare atmospheres that manages to draw you into the game world, and that is thanks to the talented developers at Square Enix, the driving force behind Deux Ex: Human Revolution which also had such an amazing atmosphere to get absorbed into. The story in itself is quite an interesting one, and later on towards the end the game starts taking a turn for the horror/paranormal reminiscence of Outlast which both terrified and excited me since at least in Thief you have a chance (emphasis on YOU, not me, as playing on Master difficulty with instant fail on taking damage/being seen is what I've condemned myself to).

While the graphics in Thief never was an issue since it's such an old game, I can't help but feel that they limited themselves quite a bit by using the Unreal Engine (though I've seen much better looking games with the same engine). But to be honest, it's not about realism (though it does get that across), but about the dark noir/steampunk feel which goes hand in hand with its rugged graphics display. The audio is what really makes the game come to life though, with footsteps perfectly positioned and the rest of the sounds matched correctly more often than not you'll feel like you're really in the game until you're stuck humping a wall because it's not a predefined climb spot.

Take all this and add the ability to start a custom difficulty game where YOU get to decide how the game will play out, if you can use healing items, if you are allowed to take damage or use specific items amongst many other modifiers makes for a completely unique experience tailored to your own playstyle! Think you're a Master Thief? Prove it!

For those who haven't played any of the Thief games and are looking for something new which doesn't heavily rely on combat (though it is available) a la Metal Gear Solid/Splinter Cell then I'm sure you'll find something of value in Thief.

For those of you who are Thief fans, or have played any of the older Thief games then for nostalgia sake you will enjoy being a Taffer once more, causing mayhem for the guards, racking up loot, finding the secrets and generally just being a badass.

I don't write many reviews, but this game warrants one:  UGH!

reviewText:
The whole game feels very clunky. If you're climbing around there's a good chance you'll get stuck because you're not in the exact right position for the game to register you need to jump to the next ledge.

The stealth elements are not much better. If you're discovered you may have little choice but to restart the area because you have no escape options at least not early on and combat only works 1v1 anything else and it's not worth the effort.

When you're not being detected everything feels like a very linear path even when it looks like it may be more open. Sometimes there's a second way to go about doing things but it's rare and sometimes you'll require a special tool you'll only get later on.

Had the combat been more fun or the game was more forgiving when you were caught it may have been better. It's not like it's a rewarding challange either. It's missing a bunch of little things that would have really made it a decent game.

reviewText:
TL;DR for you lazies at the end.  (Review for those who haven't played the original)

SO!!! Thief! Where to begin? Well let's start with the gameplay. Not going to like the stealth gameplay was really great! I haven't played too many stealth genre games but in my experience I enjoyed the mechanics and the way the game worked. The game also has a decent amount of content in it if you add in all the side missions along with achievements. One cool part is how the game has a custom difficulty setting where you can set certain things in the game. While some stealth games open the chance to do missions loudly (open combat) thief highly discourages it. The game has it set so that even if you want to kill/knockout foes rather than avoiding them you still have to be stealthy about it if you want to succeed. There are limited amounts of arrows that you can use to hit enemies so the best way is to sneak up behind them and knock them out. So an overview of the positives : Great stealth mechanics, Great game content, Custom settings for difficulty. While there were a good amount of pros to the game there were also cons. One of the major ones was the story. Very sloppily done if you ask me. The story was just so generic and seemed very uninteresting to me. It seemed like something a 5th grader could make in a literature class. So if you're really into story rich games NOT RECOMMENDED. Secondly the game is very unclear on how to jump down from ladders and ropes. This is a minor thing but left me frustrated until I looked up how to do it. Personally for me I did not like how there were so many mini cinematics in the game. Everytime you knock someone out from behind it plays a little action scene. You lose control of the character and this happens EVERY time you get someone from behind. This little sequence became very tedious and annoying the more I played the game. Lastly for the cons, the game in my mind didn't seem very fluid. The movement of the main character seemed somewhat jagged and not verry buttery. Overall the game is a cheap thrill. I Cannot in my right mind actually recommend anyone pay a full $30 for it. I got it through humblebundle at a reduced rate. I will end up recommending it for people but at a reduced rate.


TL;DR
PROS
-Nice stealth mechanics
-Good amount of game content
-Custom difficulty settings.
CONS
-Not a great story
-Tedious scenes after doing a common action
-Not the smoothest gameplay

reviewText:
So, I just finished Thief, in about 39 hours, or so Steam claims. So anyway, I wanna throw out my thoughts on the game.

First of all, I am a fan of the old thief games. They were the first stealth games I'd ever played and it was just great going around stealing things and not killing anyone for a change. I will be making comparisons with the old games, but keep in mind my memory might be hazy and blinded by nostalgia.

Overall, I was neither deeply impressed nor disappointed in this reboot. It was alirght.


The Writing:

The overall story just wasn't very interesting to me. It has some plot twists, but they seem borrowed from Thief: The Dark Project in some way. I think the original Thief series had much better writing, from Garret's backstory, to the setting - the three factions Garret has to deal with, manipulating the fate of the world in various ways and Garret always getting into trouble with them, getting mixed up in some crazy plot. The whole steampunk technology versus supernatural elements the original series has going is just really awesome.

While both the original series and the reboot's stories might be simplified to A loner's journey through a society where powerful factions struggle for power"
date:
the new Thief just wasn't that interesting to me as the older games. I guess it's a matter of details.

That's not to say that there weren't some cool aspects to the writing/story. I did enjoy the mysterious gloomy atmosphere. There are also some spooky elements which I enjoyed. I did enjoy Garret himself as a character too.


The Gameplay:

I found the new lockpicking mechanic enjoyable.

There's plenty of exploration and loot to find

reviewText:
Oh boy its remake time again. Remakes are always a dangerous thing I guess. Very often a remake is trying to be something completly new and so it is too far away from the original. On the other hand, if a remake does nothing new it does raise the question why you should make a remake if you did change nothing?

This review is probably not very positive and some people will probably say something like: Hey you just had wrong expectations!

While I will say something about the whole expectations thing later, let us just look at the plain facts.


Let us start with the most obvious thing, how does thief look? Well it does look pretty well if you ask me. Well of course it is not the most colorful game, but hey it is a about sneaking in a dark city with steampunk elements. Thief is actually pretty good at this task. The city does look nice and so I can clearly say that thief is a good looking game.

However trouble is easy to find, or in that case easy to hear. The sound of the game is pretty much underwhelming in all aspects. While the voice actors are okay (not great and not terrible) I do miss the old voice actor of garret. However there is more trouble ahead. The entire soundscape is underwhelming and is often schockingly silent. The attempt at a dynamic music system ranges between annoying and broken and I have to say it has been a long time since I actually actively hated the ingame music of a game.

Well sound and graphics are obviously not everything so what about the gameplay and the story? Sadly those two departments show the biggest flaws. Gameplay is pretty linear and often not very interesting, of course there are some alternative routes here or there but they are neither elegant or interesting. While you can roam around the city and do some sidemissions you always feel how limited your routes and by that your options are. It does not help that the enemy AI is pretty stupid and that the guards are awful at their job. So gameplay wise the game is pretty linear and not really challenging. Of course you can raise the difficult in the settings and customize a lot of things, but that does no really make the gameplay itself more interesting and fun.

The story of Thief is also sadly pretty boring and dull. Beside that it is full of logic holes. I dont expect a story to make 100% sense and of course there are things in a story that happen because the story must go somewhere. However a a story most have its own logic and if things stop making sense inside that logic, then you have problems getting engaged in a fictional story.

So much about a look about what I would call the facts. Thief is not a terrible game, I think games with a big budget can hardly be completly terrible, but just having a big budget mean you produce a ace game. Thief is far from being a ace game. I spoke about expectations earlier and this game wants to be a thief game. The problem is that in nearly no aspect it is one. It may sound a bit extreme but this game could have been released under a completly different title and some people would only call it a part time rip off of the original thief.

Can I recommend this game? Well not really. This game claim to be something that is is not and beside that it is only a average game.

reviewText:
Screw you all - turn off ALL the helper settings (and I mean ALL, no exceptions) crank the difficulty RIGHT UP, and get immersed in the game.  This is a worthy successor. I feel like I'm lost in the world of Thief again, a feeling I haven't felt since Thief 1 and 2.  For the record I enjoyed Thief Deadly Shadows but it was fairly weak in comparison, and overall felt poorly made.

This one is oozing hard work and meticulous care at every turn and every crevasse - and I mean that.  The city is so full of nooks and crannys, I felt myself getting lost in the alleyways and staring at a doorway with a sign above, wondering what its like for that house or shop during the day.  The city is layered upon layers, of old buildings somehow impossibly built upon other old buildings and streets, in a fantastical dream-like way which still seems believable and gives me the impression that people actually live on these different levels.

To me, the AI is impressive yet fair.  No matter how good I get at the game, I cannot race through the city towards another side mission without stopping and taking time.  Even with the swoop mechanic (which I love by the way) moving fast will almost certainly cause some guard to turn their head at the moving shadow in the alleyway, go investigate, cause a fuss which will put others on alert, and your careless continued running will certainly be spotted - and you'll be chased.  This will likely end in your death, and best case, cause you a lot of lost time and potentially lost resources as you do what you can to escape and wait till the whole thing blows over.  Damn you, developers! I cannot carelessly exploit the AI as I could in the original game - I MUST take care and play like a proper thief!  (PS. that means they did their job.)

As for the artwork, story, dialogue etc. it has the same level of care, but I want to keep this review short.  Watching the dialogue between the effeminate (male!) brothel owner and the ThiefTaker General had me invested in the conversation, as he stood up to the brutish General and would not let him mistreat the women. Original things like the sex workers at the brothel being called Petals" show that they really have taken care to flesh this world out and want you to get immersed in it.
And the plot is multi-layered enough and full of enough content to be worthy of the Thief title.  By that I mean

I, personally, found myself enjoying most of the game, but even then, I could see where it went right and where it went wrong.\n\nThe relative non-linearity of the levels that encourages exploration: Good. The immersiveness of your character with simple things such as hands and feet, putting you into the shoes of Garrett: Good (great, for an immersion nut like myself). The phenominal graphics that breath life to what you would assume is a horribly dark and dank and dirty place with nothing else to offer: Good. But then you have the bad" side of things. reviewText:
The second you read Thief and dishonored in the same review, quit reading. Except for this one of course :)
I have no idea why the comparison, They are totally different games to be played in a totally different way. I've finished both, they are nothing alike, only extremely superficial people would compare them, but one thing is sure they are both incredible.

Thief oozes quality, re-playability, amazing sounds and visuals, atmosphere is fantastic.
It is to be played in a raw fashion, bow and arrow, ghostly assassin, or silent thief.
Whereas dishonored is an stealth-action game with supernatural abilities. Really couldn't be more different.

Buy this gem of game, you will not regret it, at the current price, it is a steal.

reviewText:
The newest Thief game can be compared to a reboot/remake of a beloved Hollywood franchise. It's nowhere near as good as the originals, but it's not terrible, and it's updated.

I've played Thief for roughly 7 hours, the city sucks to travel through and the map is completely horrible and there is never a clear direction. Thief shines when you're in a mission through a building or house, and stealing things under someones nose is really rewarding. Outsmarting guards never gets old either. So if you're a fan of stealth games, than Thief is a no brainer. But if you're fairly new to the genre, play Dishonored as it is a much more polished, fun, rewarding and realized experience. In my opinion Dishonored did Thief better than the new Thief did.

I hope there is some kind of fast travel option implemented into Thief, because if I have to traverse through that map every time I need to get somewhere far away I'm simply going to stop playing, it's that bad.

reviewText:
Eidos Montreal had all the experience they needed for developing Thief through the making of Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Although the new Thief was a bit harder to create since the last game of the series was released in 2004 and they had to keep the new game's atmosphere as close to the older ones as possible.

Starting with the story it's not what you will remember after you have finished Thief. You will be expecting most of the plot twists and towards the end the story seems a bit far fetched. The City is divided in different areas or districts. The problem is that those districts are divided into smaller areas as well so there are frequent loading screens. Also the city offers an illusion of an open-world environment but the truth is that you can't go everywhere you want to. But even in a smaller area there are many paths you can follow to your destination whether it is on the rooftops or the roads.

The biggest problem of the game is it's AI. It may be easy for enemies to spot you but it is really easy to escape and hide. Just hiding in some shadows or climbing on a roof does the trick. Also their reactions to noises, torches of fires going off or when finding bodies are really bad. They may look around for a while and then go on with their patrols as if nothing happened.

Leaving the games problems behind, the stealth mechanisms are really great. Garrett has a lot of tools and his trusted bow at his disposal which he can use to avoid his enemies or dispose of them. The City is filled with loot to steal and a lot of them (especially unique loot and collectibles) are really hard to find so that offers a good challenge. You will have to find safe combinations, secret passages behind bookcases and items hidden behind paintings. Sneaking around the city and searching every corner and every house for loot is really fun.

If it's hard for you to find loot you can use the Focus ability which highlights objects you can take or use and enemies. The thing is that Focus makes the game a lot easier so try to avoid using it as much as you can. Garret's abilities can be upgraded by buying (or findind) Focus points and you can also buy new tools or equipment upgrades from merchants around the city.

The game's graphics are great. Especially the character's faces which are really epxressive. The animations are smooth. As for the music, it gets a little annoying at times. For example when you are trying to sneak around somewhere and you hear music pounding in your ears. The voice-acting is good as well with Garrett's voice standing out.

If the bad AI is not a really big problem for you then Thief can give you a really great time. There are a lot of secrets to discover and finding them using Thief's stealth mechanincs is a real pleasure.

75%

reviewText:
First, an important point: I only recommend buying this game if it's cheap.

Once I disabled SSAA from the start-up graphics menu, the game actually became playable on my stupidly high-spec computer and oversized widescreen monitor. I don't understand why a computer that is above and beyond the recommended specs is unable to run this game out-of-the-box. Anyhoo.

Once the game got working properly, the graphics are very pretty. I feel that the facial animations were a bit messed up, particularly in cutscenes, but besides that, the game looked nice.

The sound mechanics of the game are STUFFED UP. Someone might be two floors below you, with masses of stone separating you from them, yet you hear them like they're right next to you.
You're in a silent room. You peep through a keyhole, and you can see a couple people talking. Suddenly, you can hear their voices blaring at you, even though you backed away from the keyhole and (closed) door. Same goes for peeping through a hole in a thick stone wall. At first you can't hear a thing, then after you establish their presence, it's as though they're shouting in the same room with you.
Trying to listen in on a conversation? You get close enough to hear a couple of people having a conversation. Except, one of the two people drop out to a barely audible murmur. But the person they're speaking to has their voice blaring as though speaking through a loudspeaker. This problem lead me to enable subtitles, just so I could read what they were saying. But do this, and you will be constantly bombarded with repetitious background chatter" in the city. There were
recommended:
3 dialogue strings on repeat.

The story is abysmal. There are other reviews that go into detail plenty well enough that I won't repeat the problems here.

But
hoursPlayed: if you want a game that isn't a standard shooter

reviewText: Thief mixes really excellent gameplay with really terrible story telling, and in that sense it's pretty classic. The whole story feels very cobbled together, and none of it comes together very well, however it's a blast to play through for die hard stealth fans. The world is wonderfully put together with a large variety of environment puzzles to sneak through. There are many approaches to almost every situation. There are a few points in the game where you get bottlenecked into a single solution and they feel pretty glaring when you reach them because of how large the variety of options is almost everywhere else, but these moments are few and far between and many players may not even notice them.\n\nOver all, Thief is a solid entry into the series if you value gameplay over story telling. However if you feel that the characterization and story telling of the series to date has been your primary motivation for playing, then you may want to give this one a pass.

reviewText:
(At the time that this review is released, I will have NOT beaten Thief yet. I may change my feelings/opinions on it as I progress the game)

Thief is a good game for any of you stealth gaming enthusiasts.
Although it's story is NOT very interactive, and you don't get the same sort of emotion you would get if you played any games such as, The Walking Dead by Telltale, it is still an overall good game.

In a graphic perspective, the game itself is very nice when it comes down to details, shadows, and lighting, but other than that the gameplay feels at points either too jumpy, or too slow paced. At some areas it feels like you have no idea what is going on, and you just want to 'beat' the chapter.

As of playing this game, I can't help but feel the way I did when I first tried to get into the game, 'Dishonored'. I kept feeling like I couldn't comprehend what was happening no matter how much the story progressed, and in the end I just got tired of it and had to stop playing it. Thief feels relatively similar to Dishonored's gameplay, but are not nearly the same in a matter of combat, or storyline. The stealth in Thief, which is what is made out to be it's core gameplay mechanic"

reviewText:
The Bad.
The writing is kind of rubbish, firstly a lot of the things that made the Thief world interesting seems to have vanished, there's no hammerites, no pagans, I did go to some keeper ruins but have yet to meet one and so far the game have not eluded to what happened to the most important factions in the game series.
The story itself is fairly weak, we never get a feel for Garret's relationship with his apprentice, we never get to see her training or what drove them apart, Garret seems to care a lot more about people than he did in the previous games, the game world seem to have moved 400 years ahead in fashion, no longer is the word in a medieval steampunk style, it now much more resembles the typical victorian steampunk you so often see, though still without the invention of gunpowder

The Good.
The gameplay is solid, it’s fun to sneak around and still everything within arm’s reach, the levels are well designed with tons of hidden loot,  the core gameplay of stealing stuff, then using the money you get from the stuff to by upgrades and gear so you can steal more stuff even more effectively is a good time. Tripping over a bottle on the ground you didn’t notice and alerting a guard is hearthstoppingly tense, and the game is full of small cool details like that.
The extensive difficulty settings are also excellent, not content with just the easy medium hard settings, you can extensively customize the difficulty, feel like the focus ability makes the game to easy, turn it off, long for the days of Thief 1's saving methods, you can turn that on, and so on.


The Ugly.
It’s the small things in this game that drives me up the wall, the silly story I can easily look beyond, but the game is held back by a lot of small bad design decisions.
For example the locations of loading points in the open world will drive you crazy, why the nearest merchant to my hideout is in its own little area with its own loading time in and out is beyond me. Using slow quick time events to open a window to enter into a new area only to realize you already roped that apartment and having to do another slow quick time event to get back out gets old real quick. The map could have used some more work, or at least the ability to place your own notes on it would be nice, for example you can replay old missions by reentering them at their starting point, which is great, if it wasn’t for the fact that their location isn’t shown on the map after you done them, so if don’t remember where it was it can be problematic. The hideout is a nice touch but serves no real purpose (an idea would have been to allow you do redo old missions from your hideout, thereby giving you a reason to return to the bloody thing and saving me the trouble of running around the city trying to find the damn mission entrances, but I digress).

Conclusion.
This is almost the worst kind of game to play, there’s an excellent stealth game in here, but playing it can sometimes fell like death by a thousand tiny cuts, it can be very frustrating to feel hold back by small weird design choices.
Still with all that said, it’s probably the best pure stealth game I played in recent times, a lot of my frustration stems from my love of the Thief series and its world, but if you are a fan of stealth it should still easily be worth your money.

reviewText:
Being an old-school Thief fan, I was ecstatic to get my hands on this game. I wasn't the biggest fan of Deadly Shadows because of the third-person change so I'm glad they kept it first-person and I really like Garrett's modelling. Very cool.

The whole game is very 'Thief-esque' which I'm glad to see and I love the amount of things you can steal, since I'm a human magpie. The graphics are beautiful, the city is dark but when you go inside, there's lots of colour and character in each place you visit. The story is fine, I enjoyed playing it out but the ending felt a little quick and anti-climactic, mostly the last scenes.

There are only a few problems that I found with the game, and unfortunately some affect the game quite drastically - especially if you're playing the second time around to get every shiny you missed. Firstly, the mapping system is quite badly done, there's no names at all for any of the areas which is highly frustrating and would have probably made the fact that to get to most areas, you have to jump through people's windows and go through loading screens each time, a LOT less frustrating. It would be nice to know WHERE you are going. They probably would have been better off keeping a similar mapping system to the old Thief, they had labels and also showed you which parts of the level you've been to and which is undiscovered.

Another problem is that to replay chapters, you have to find the place where you began that chapter - impossible since there's no labelling and quite a lot of chapters!

Also, a minor issue really, but I would have really loved the word 'taffer' to make it back into Thief and maybe make the NPCs say a wider range of lines, they seem to be repeating the same ones over and over and it gets really frustrating.

Despite the flaws, it's defintely a must-play, if you keep in mind that a lot of things are different. Including the lack of dagger/sword and a prompted blackjack instead of real-time. I'm not saying they affect the game much, they're just different.

THe first-time playthrough is very interesting and I was engrossed in it for days, I enjoyed it that much. I just wouldn't replay it, even though I wanted to, because the mapping system made it a lot less fun than it could have been. As you can tell, I'm writing a mixed review here, which is sad for me since I am a huge fan of the Thief games.

reviewText:
Being an old-school Thief fan, I was ecstatic to get my hands on this game. I wasn't the biggest fan of Deadly Shadows because of the third-person change so I'm glad they kept it first-person and I really like Garrett's modelling. Very cool.

The whole game is very 'Thief-esque' which I'm glad to see and I love the amount of things you can steal, since I'm a human magpie. The graphics are beautiful, the city is dark but when you go inside, there's lots of colour and character in each place you visit. The story is fine, I enjoyed playing it out but the ending felt a little quick and anti-climactic, mostly the last scenes.

There are only a few problems that I found with the game, and unfortunately some affect the game quite drastically - especially if you're playing the second time around to get every shiny you missed. Firstly, the mapping system is quite badly done, there's no names at all for any of the areas which is highly frustrating and would have probably made the fact that to get to most areas, you have to jump through people's windows and go through loading screens each time, a LOT less frustrating. It would be nice to know WHERE you are going. They probably would have been better off keeping a similar mapping system to the old Thief, they had labels and also showed you which parts of the level you've been to and which is undiscovered.

Another problem is that to replay chapters, you have to find the place where you began that chapter - impossible since there's no labelling and quite a lot of chapters!

Also, a minor issue really, but I would have really loved the word 'taffer' to make it back into Thief and maybe make the NPCs say a wider range of lines, they seem to be repeating the same ones over and over and it gets really frustrating.

Despite the flaws, it's defintely a must-play, if you keep in mind that a lot of things are different. Including the lack of dagger/sword and a prompted blackjack instead of real-time. I'm not saying they affect the game much, they're just different.

THe first-time playthrough is very interesting and I was engrossed in it for days, I enjoyed it that much. I just wouldn't replay it, even though I wanted to, because the mapping system made it a lot less fun than it could have been. As you can tell, I'm writing a mixed review here, which is sad for me since I am a huge fan of the Thief games.

reviewText:
(At the time that this review is released, I will have NOT beaten Thief yet. I may change my feelings/opinions on it as I progress the game)

Thief is a good game for any of you stealth gaming enthusiasts.
Although it's story is NOT very interactive, and you don't get the same sort of emotion you would get if you played any games such as, The Walking Dead by Telltale, it is still an overall good game.

In a graphic perspective, the game itself is very nice when it comes down to details, shadows, and lighting, but other than that the gameplay feels at points either too jumpy, or too slow paced. At some areas it feels like you have no idea what is going on, and you just want to 'beat' the chapter.

As of playing this game, I can't help but feel the way I did when I first tried to get into the game, 'Dishonored'. I kept feeling like I couldn't comprehend what was happening no matter how much the story progressed, and in the end I just got tired of it and had to stop playing it. Thief feels relatively similar to Dishonored's gameplay, but are not nearly the same in a matter of combat, or storyline. The stealth in Thief, which is what is made out to be it's core gameplay mechanic"

reviewText:
Despite a lot of negative reviews, I gave this game a shot.  I think a lot of the problems people had with the game have to do with focus and their difficulty setting. I did a custom playthrough on master difficulty with focus, knockouts, kills, food, waypoints, and button prompts all turned off. I went through the game with the majority as a ghost and somewhat as an opportunist.  And while some problems still persisted, I think the game was really fun.
Some of the missions in the game were not very fun, and linear. Mission 1, the end of 4, the end of 6, and part of 8 were not very fun, but the rest were pretty great.

Pros:
Extremely fun stealth and gameplay, lots of different routes to take the majority of the game, lots of difficult loot to get, great side missions, majority of missions are fun, guards see you pretty easily (good thing). great atmosphere.  The city (will discuss below)

Cons:
bugs in sound, guard pathfinding, and a few other things.  Awful soundtrack with dubstep when detected.  Pretty bad chase sequences and climbing sequences.  bad story

Other than the gameplay, the best thing in the game, in my opinion, is the city or hub area.  It's huge and open, and with plenty of secret areas to discover.  It has very good atmosphere, with a lot of side missions and mini missions to do.  It has this feeling of despair which really helps the atmosphere out.

Overall I liked the game a lot more than other people did. The last few missions were very tough and fun, and mission 5 is pretty creepy.
Given a score I'd say 7/10 good game (real 10 scale, not ign 9/10 it's garbage)

reviewText:
Depending on how you like to play, Thief is either a quick sprint to the finish that will test your reflexes and make you think on your feet or a grueling marathon that will require all your powers of deduction, observation, and a walkthrough or two to complete. Grabbing all the achievements in Thief took me about 47 hours total over the course of a few playthroughs, even with help finding the seven secret areas I overlooked.

Taking on the role of the eponymous main character you'll have to make your way through the city you call home, old forgotten ruins beneath it, a mental institution on the other side of the river, and even your own mind. Parts of Thief play like something directly out of a horror game and manage to do it better than most games that make horror their focus. Speaking of Garrett, the man's got a great sense of humor. His zippy one-liners never disappoint.

The art direction in Thief is drab, but appropriate. The game is set in an authoritarian citystate on the verge of societal collapse. The colors of any given scene are gray and brown, with a bit of blue and white thrown in for lighting. Interspersed with the dull scenery are carefully placed spots of shadow that you'll need to take advantage of if you want to remain unseen and/or not die, and thousands of shinies you'll need to collect if you want to complete the game.

One final note on appearances: I've never liked the steampunk" aesthetic
date: so watching the grungy patchwork technology in some parts of the game fall to pieces the way it would in the real world brought me no small amount of secret vindictive pleasure.\n\nWhile each chapter is fairly linear there are usually multiple ways of progressing and different ways of approaching each situation. Very rarely does the main game restrict your options- if you want to muscle your way past the guards and take what you're after by force
recommended: you usually can if you're good enough with your blackjack. Just don't try that with the Freaks in the lower levels of the old city; it won't end well. You can also replay each chapter to try something different by revisiting the chapter's starting location. You will need to memorize them or look them up
hoursPlayed: though
voteText: they're not marked on your map.\n\nI was a little disappointed that there were only two boss fights in the game. I know not every chapter of a game should have a final encounter
helpfulPercent: but only two? There's so much you can do with stealth games like this one to build entertaining showdowns so Thief loses a few points here by my reckoning. A word of caution about the final boss... on the hardest difficulty possible (custom settings only
votesHelpful: I think) the final boss is a game of breakneck hide-and-seek where being found means you die. Instantly. I'm never doing that again and if achievements are your cup of tea I wish you luck. Hint: move clockwise.\n\nFlaws notwithstanding
votesTotal: Thief would make a great Christmas gift- nothing says "holiday spirit" like breaking into other people's homes
votesFunny: taking their things
commentsCount: and dispensing wanton vandalism and violence along the way. Deck the halls."

reviewText:
As a die hard fan of Thief series, I refuse to perceive this latest remake as bad. We've been waiting 10 years for another Thief game, and although this is not the direct continuation of trilogy it is still a very good game.

You can adjust the difficulty level to your liking. Don't like focus? Turn it off. As in other Thief games, you are not forced to kill anyone, you can either sneak past them or knock them out. Some loot can be tricky to find, some are in plain sight but are still out of your reach until you pull the right trigger.

Though this is a remake, it's has nice touch about the original Thief's past: Hammerites cathedral, references to Trickster, cog shaped loot (hint toward the Mechanists), Keeper's Library - it is all sentimental in this new instalment.

Very nice music and graphics, steam punk, dark feel about the story. The story though might be one weaker side of this game. It's not as full and reach as it was in previous trilogy games. Nevertheless I like the game and hopefully we will see Garrett again. Or his apprentice from the end of the trilogy.

reviewText:
I would recommend this game, but only to those who did not play the previous games in the series.

First I will discuss the pros of this game.  This game is mostly about sneaking carefully from place to place, stealing everything of value you can lay your hands on, and this game does a good job of ramping up the tension when you risk detection.  The sense of atmosphere this game creates is strong, but very different from its predecessors.  For those more accustomed to action games, there are a few more active scenes in which you must make a hasty escape, but fighting is usually not an option.

The game has an almost movie-like style to it, although this is very common in commercially produced games.  There are plenty of unique, collectible treasures to gather, which you can keep and admire after returning to your hideout, and a lot of secrets to find.  The focus ability is useful, not only enhancing your abilities for a time, but also making it easier to navigate and spot important objects, such as traps, switches and ropes.

Now we come to the cons.  For fans of the previous games, Thief is likely to be something of a disapointment.  Many of the fantasy elements of the game have been removed.  Hammerites and Pagans are nowhere to be seen, although some signs of their former presence can be seen here and there.  Elemental crystals are no longer used on Garret's arrows and have been replaced with mechanical or alchemical alternatives.  Rope arrows can now only be used in very specific locations, as they can no longer lodge in the scenery.  Even the word taffer" has fallen out of common use among the city people
date: replaced with more familiar swear words.  Although this is probably meant to give the game a more mature style
recommended: it actually has the opposite effect and makes the characters seem somewhat juvenile.\n\nThe cinematic style of the game
hoursPlayed: as I have already noted
voteText: is very similar to most other modern games and doesn't really seem to fit.  The hand-drawn animations of the previous games are gone.  Even the upgrade system is somewhat generic and seems like a half-hearted attempt to imitate other games.  The storyline is also very different in style to the previous games.  While not exactly bad
helpfulPercent: it often attempts to depict Garret as vulnerable and insecure
votesHelpful: as if to draw attention to his softer side.  Although some may find this intriguing
votesTotal: I thought it seemed somewhat contrived.  The game's ending is abrupt and leaves a lot of loose ends
votesFunny: giving the impression that the final cinematic was abandoned half-finished.\n\nAll in all
commentsCount: this is a decent stealth game in its own right
column16: but for fans of the previous instalments
column17: like myself
column18: Thief marks the death of the series and the beginning of a long line of dull
column19: generic
column20: mass-produced sequels.  If you love stealth games
column21: treasure hunting and a strong dark atmosphere
column22: this game is for you.  However
column23: if you liked the previous games
column24: avoid it.  Unless you are prepared for the drastic change in style
column25: this game will leave you feeling empty and unfulfilled."

reviewText: First impression: Not total garbage. I'm surprised! You and I both expected me to flat-out dislike this game because I'm a long-time fan of the franchise, didn't we? But it really is not total crap.\n\nAs far as I'm concerned, all references to classic Thief" elements such as the Hammerite symbol
hoursPlayed: guards mentioning the word "taffer
voteText: etc.
helpfulPercent: they are all just nods and easter eggs paying homage to the original trilogy. There's some clumsy attempts to dovetail the rebooted universe with the old but it's too nonsensical to take seriously. And why use the name Basso for new-Garrett's fence? Why not use Cutty? Old-Basso was just a boxman (expert lockpicker).\n\nThe city hub makes a return in Thief 4. I know some people who didn't mind it in Thief 3
votesHelpful: but I know *nobody* who LIKED it. Its reuse here only served to pad gameplay time with tedious walking back and forth. Thief 2's "Life Of the Party" mission had Garrett traversing the city rooftops from his home all the way to Angelwatch. In that single mission alone
votesTotal: the world-building achieved by the things you witness and the conversations you overhear on the way to the actual mission area gave that Thief-universe more heart and soul than this entire game did for its own universe. I'll never forget the pejorative 'taffer' or the battle between the guards of Lady van Vernon's house and Master Willey's castle. A few weeks from now all I'll remember about Thief 4 is "sloop" and "Garrett
votesFunny: I'm slipping!"\n\nAnalogy time: This game is about as classic Thief as the movie "World War Z" was a faithful adaptation of the book
commentsCount: i.e. not even a little bit. Now
column16: now
column17: this is a reboot
column18: sure
column19: sure. I'm already accounting for that and I'm still making this statement! The thing they've created here does not inherit enough Thief-y essence to rightfully call itself a reimagination of the original intellectual property. This game and that movie should have no right to affiliate themselves with those respective IPs. The only reason they have each done so is because their creators did not have faith in their products to stand alone on their own merits."

reviewText:
Thief, a stealth based composed of multiple settings and scenes that conflict in the point of interest for the player. Thief's time is set to be in both medieval / modern century with electricity and fire with alot of sword play. This game will keep you on your toes most of the time and has an interest in horror.

Characters and AI: You are Garret, the master thief, king of rats. Master of stealth and loves to steal things. Yet you have a heart for the city in which you live in, making your actions duable in the sence that you are the good guy.

Eren: A young woman who partners up with Garret and ♥♥♥♥s everything up in the begining.

AI: The AI are ok and someare scary, never the less they have a specific pattern in which they move and can't seem to see ♥♥♥♥ in the dark unless they are really close.

The game is very detailed to the biggest of buildings to the finest crack in a piece of wood. It looks beautiful. But it's always dark. This game also likes to jump around in the story, linking things from the past to the future, which is really cool and all, but lacks interest and a sence of excitement. Only a few scenes in the game were actually really good, but other than that it's a very slow game. After a few missions, instead of sneaking passed the gaurd, you start to kill them in glorious fashions, reducing the amount of time, but killing the experience and atmousphere.

Combat and movement: The moevment is fine the there are issues with the combat and climbing. When it comes to seriously climbing stough, the character can't seem to do what you want him to do even though the objective is right infront of you. It's frustrating. And the combat sucks, whenever you dodge, you get hit, making it even more frustrating. So for those who want to play this game, make sure you have a good computer! reviewText:
It's okay.

I haven't played the originals so as a newcomer I enjoyed it for what it is. It's quite atmospheric and has cool moments.

The stealth is pretty basic and simple, nothing to go crazy about. The story also isn't great, the characters aren't well written and fairly forgettable. The Thief-Taker general had potential but never really got much character development.

Has technical problems such as well known audio problems. The framerate drops sharply during cutscenes too, thankfully I didn't get any drops during gameplay but still, it breaks the immersion.

Overall, pick it up on sale if you're a fan of atmospheric games. Don't have huge expectations and you'll enjoy it.

reviewText:
I personally found this game brilliant. I'd recommend it to most people, because of the variety of methods of going about the game. It doesn't matter if you're a sneaky thief who doesn't even knock anyone out, who is never even known to be there. Or if you're the more violent thief who kills everything in sight and is feared by the contending factions.

Gameplay - 8/10 Well, this can be a bit of a controversial subject, I thought the story was fairly good (about a 6/10) but the other gameplay (I.E sidemissions) also offer a chance for a different type of fun).

Graphics - 8/10 The graphics are pretty good. sometimes you get a slight drop in frame rate (I did, but all the settings were set to absolute max, and I'm playing on a laptop.

Sound - 7/10 The sound is pretty good, better in combat scenarios, however you have a good ambiance created through everything combined, which results in a decent atmosphere to coincide with the game play.

Overall - 7.5/10. I enjoyed this game, there are several options to make the game harder, including in mission challenges and other fun things. Should take about 13 hours to complete everything on medium difficulty, and 15 on the hardest. Recommended.

10/10 would steal everything from a person and then knock them out again.

reviewText:
This game wanted to be Thief. Its developers wanted it to be Thief. I wanted it to be Thief. Unfortunately, it is not Thief. It is a game that wishes it could hang out with Thief's friends. To those that loved the original game it is not like the original in all the wrong ways, except in the thieving. If you want something more modern that is closer to Thief then play Dishonored otherwise, just play the original Thief

The good about the game is that the stealing is fun and challenging. The building designs are pretty.
The meh about the game is the story. It is truly meh. It didn't really make me want to finish the main story or learn any of the lore that was created for this new game.

The bad was first and foremost Garrett. He was a dumb character and looked really stupid when he had his mask pulled down to the edge of his chin. Who does that? In the game it made him look like he had extra chins. I don't mind that they wanted to make him different than the original Garrett, but at least make him interesting. He could have been any character and it wouldn't have changed the story at all.

The other bad is that because the story was meh I didn't care about any of the characters that I was supposed to. They could have all died and I would have just looted the corpes and moved on. And that is what I feel they should do with this title.

reviewText:
I never played the original Thief (even though I own it) so this review is about this version alone.

- It's in England - so why are all the main v/o characters American?

reviewText:
As a die hard fan of Thief series, I refuse to perceive this latest remake as bad. We've been waiting 10 years for another Thief game, and although this is not the direct continuation of trilogy it is still a very good game.

You can adjust the difficulty level to your liking. Don't like focus? Turn it off. As in other Thief games, you are not forced to kill anyone, you can either sneak past them or knock them out. Some loot can be tricky to find, some are in plain sight but are still out of your reach until you pull the right trigger.

Though this is a remake, it's has nice touch about the original Thief's past: Hammerites cathedral, references to Trickster, cog shaped loot (hint toward the Mechanists), Keeper's Library - it is all sentimental in this new instalment.

Very nice music and graphics, steam punk, dark feel about the story. The story though might be one weaker side of this game. It's not as full and reach as it was in previous trilogy games. Nevertheless I like the game and hopefully we will see Garrett again. Or his apprentice from the end of the trilogy.

reviewText:
Beautiful, this game is just beautiful, the PC Port is fonominal, the lighting effects were better then real life. This may be the only game other then octodad where i have practically fell in love with the storyline. You really feel like your inside of the game, stealing, hiding from guards, knocking random people out with aerial takedowns. This is my favourite game to ever be released on the steam store. Also I only had it since last night (9th March) and I already played more then 12 and a half hours. You can tell i like this game.

The only negative I have is the texutre of windows, they look a bit, how you would say, smudgy and it kind of looks like something you would make in nursery.
Other then that brilliant game! 9.5/10

reviewText:
EDIT: After playing through the game, in its entierty, I think that playing as Erin (in a scenario where Garret dies, and you're left to play as Erin), would be much more interesting, rewarding, and with a character that is much more fleshed out than Garret. I did not change my key points, nor my opinion of the game, during the playthrough.

Thief is not about thieving.
There, I said it.
After playing the same mission time and time again because the game wasn't made for the mode I wish for it to be, I decided to do this review about Thief, the new one.
I've played the old Theifs. When I preordered back in September something I saw the gameplay videos, it was going to be extravagant, something new, something exciting! I had already preordered, I could cancel, sure, but that would make the action I made moot. I saw with some distaste in my mouth how the game was going to be linear, unlike the original. I figured it was fine, the experience could still be swell. Then I saw how the adventure itself was going to become very short. And I figured that was just casuals breezing through, I would have fun, lots of it, at least triple of what an average playthrough would be. And I was correct, it will be at least triple of an average playthrough, because I haven't finished the Second Map yet, after 17 h. (Which can be seen in my achievements tab)
Back to the old Theif. This game is not the same experience as the old Thief is. In Thief: Gold had you explore an area, every inch and nut and bolt and screw, and you still wouldn't find every lootable item. Every map was a pleasure to explore, and so long you didn't kill anyone, you could reign free in your merry little map, without anything stopping you. (Well, just keep a spare Flashbomb, and you won't have any issues with guards that do detect you.)
The new Thief, so far, and I don't expect much more from it, has such a linear mapstyle, that I find it even hard to miss the damn loot. Apart from the loot that is hidden away in someones brightly lit room, and heavily guarded door, that is. Every part of the maps, even if they in themselves are quite large, are very predictable, and does not offer much choices of approach for the pathing you wish to perform. Most oftenly so are you placed at the entrance of a room, enabled a large view of the situation at hand, and then roughly three parthways to accompany it:
The the-way-you-will-probably-take-every-time-you-replay-the-map-from-the-start.
The inadequate path.
The worse-than-above path.
Whilst I do like the freedom of choice, it feels somewhat lacking. Due to the fact that the maps are so linear, the point of using any other entrance, or exit, than the first one stated, is dubious.
However, the idea of the city, not that I have looked that much into it, seems pretty good. A hub for going from mission to mission, where you can spend some past time between missions, or just fool around, I guess.(Not that I would know, I can't knock anyone unconsious, get detected, and on top of that, I have chapter saves.)

Now that you know some of the game, I will go back to my first statement.
Thief is not based around thieving.
You might ask yourself why.
Well:

-You can finish the game without stealing a single dime of non-quest items.

This in itself, for a Thief game, is one thing that actually might make you reconsider not getting this for old time's sake".
One of the most noticable challenges of Thief Gold is that if you don't have the required loot

reviewText:
This review is in progress and will be publicly uploaded when Ive finished. Finished review below.

I can't play the game - after trying and trying I had to give up due to the non-mappable controls and my physical limitatrions. It seems a good game, so I'm going to give it a recommended. But my original review still stands. Its a console port, and it shows. If you (like me) absolutely need mappable controls for whatever reason, you won't like this - and I cant recommend it in that case.

DEVS- MAKE THE CONTROLLER MAPPABLE. THIS IS NOT A FREAKING CONSOLE.
_______________________________________________________________________________
Note: I am ♥♥♥♥♥♥ as hell whenever a dev (especially an AAA dev) is too lazy to include controller mapping in their PC games. Ive posted and wrote about this many times before. I hate to have to beat the dead horse again, but - TO ALL DEVS: For people with limited use of some of their fingers or hand(s) mappable controllers can be the difference between being able to enjoy a game and walking away in frustration.

Thats the reason why a lot of people with physical issues play PC instead of consoles, the extreme customizability of inputs. For you to not take the extra time to make the controller maps customizable is just stupid. Now I have to go spend time screwing with JoytoKey/all the other key-to-controller progs and that never works as well as native controller support and is a pain in the ♥♥♥. I'm not going to let it influence my review because for most people its a minor issue, but if you are like me and need the customizability of a fully mappable controller, you might take this into consideration.

reviewText:
This is a flawed gem of a game, but in my own opinion one with more positives than negatives.

Tight controls, detailed environments, and atmosphere you could cut with a knife, sadly held back by a rather weak story.

It also sadly but understandably, buckles a bit under the shear weight of the legacy it is trying to uphold, but as a fan of the old series I enjoyed this one.

Ones experience aside with the old Thief series, this is one of those real 'love it, or hate it' type deals, and although I recommend this game for any fans of stealth, I would still argue you to if possible, try the game first before investing in your own copy.

I personally found it interesting and neat in a way that reinforces that Garath (the main character) is actually a physical presence in the world... but for the record I’ve heard a lot of people that find the frequent, if short, animations were he opens and picks up things, to be utterly infuriating. Just to name one example on the ‘love, hate’ thing.

In short, I would recommend this for stealth fans, and fans of the Thief series; the later if with the caveat and warning of the game being quite different from the rest of the series.

For all others:

For good or ill, this really feels like a larceny simulator with a fantasy twist. If that sounds interesting to you, you might enjoy it, but Gareth is very, very weak, and even a single guard may kill you if you are unprepared
.
Unlike this studious previous outing, Deus Ex: Human Revolution, combat is usually not an equal option unless you are really good at it, or spend a lot of money, time and upgrades on making it so; something that will eat up resources that could have been much better spent elsewhere.

So if you have some patience this can be a very rewarding game you will lose dozen if not hundreds of hours to... but gamers aimed more at the action side of things need not apply.

reviewText:
So here's the issue with Thief. (Or as some people call it, Thief 4)

If you treat the game as a faithful sequel to the original three games, you are going to disappointed. If you treat the game as a new reboot, you're going to like it. The game itself plays between a mixture of Thief 3 and Dishonoured. (Which isn't really a bad combination, though this game is quite linear)

The graphics, animations and audio are great, which does a great deal for immersion. Not to mention the voice acting is pretty good.

Bad points: The story writing is poor, and it is not as slow paced/tactical as the previous games in the series.

Does this mean the game is bad? No way, it's actually pretty good. A bit buggy, but it's a solid game in its own right.

Should you buy it? Yes,  but make sure you buy it cheap. It's always on offer because of the mixed reception it's getting.

reviewText: Given what I've played thus far, Thief is a game right up my alley. I jumped into this game on the hardest difficulty available, and am loving it. The emphasis on stealth and trickery as opposed to brute force is a delight not often experienced in modern gaming. This is a game I'd like to see further delved into, as there is tons of potential. While I am aware that it is a remake, I still hope for the addition of traps, misdirection (besides throwing a bottle) and subterfuge. Adding cinematic stealth kills (or takedowns) would've been nice as well.\nThe enemies aren't cheap or stupid like in most stealth games, forcing you to perform recon and planning around the situation. And believe me, planning is imperative, as you are not an indestructible force of death. Getting surrounded is usually a one-way trip to the reload screen. The Focus mechanic doesn't wreck the game by making it stupidly easy and performs well enough to make it a useful tool as opposed to either a liability or a dependancy.\nAll in all, a great experience for stealth game fans, both new and old. There are a few things I would chage with the platforming (Sometimes your character will happily jump to his doom, but refuse to step over a two inch ledge). Other than that, this game is a stellar example of the ingenuity that was so common before modern gaming.

reviewText: As someone who's never played the old Thief games, this viewpoint is coming from a fresh start to the game. I enjoy stealth action games, and have played several of them, and in terms of gameplay/stealth mechanics, this game isn't exactly spectacular, but it's acceptable. I enjoyed this game more because of the mood/setting (dark/gothic), as well as the story and characters.\n\nThe game - including all side quests and the Bank Heist DLC mission - took me about 20 hours. So if you're looking for a decent stealth game to play and you have the cash to buy this on sale ($15), it's not a bad idea. But don't place your expectations too high. On a side note, the Asylum chapter midway through the game is a lot like a jumpy horror movie - beware. Not something I expected in a game in this genre.

reviewText:
Let's get this out of the way from the start: Thief 2014 is not as good as the original Thief trilogy.

The story isn't anything special, nor is the writing, but I felt the voice acting for Garrett was decent, though it's no where near as good as Stephen Russells performance as the original Garrett.

That said, I still found it to be an overall enjoyable game. The sneaking works well, with it being fairly easy to know how visible you are at any given time thanks to the light gem. A specifc noise plays if an guard has detected you which gives you a chance to get out of sight before being spotted, as well.

The difficulty of the game is also highly customizable, and you can turn off practically every element of the HUD to up the challenge, as well.

There's a Focus mode that can be upgraded to allow you to perform other abilities, but I found the most useful function it had was highlighting interactable objects and locations for collectibles.

WHile not a perfect game, and not as good as the original games, I would recommend Thief 2014 to fans of the stealth genre.

reviewText: Thief hasn't gotten very good reviews: mediocre at best.  However, I'm enjoying it quite a bit.  There are some major bugs throughout the game, as well as some story plot-holes. Immediate comparisons are to Dishonored but I would say that, while this (so far) falls short, it's definitely worth your time if you enjoy those games.  There's room enough for both series in the covert-FPS, RPG genre.  Yey for Thief.

reviewText:
You know that dark days are ahead when Stephen Russell, the original voice actor for Garrett, is not voicing him in this game, but that is only one of the many problems the reboot to my favorite game series of all time has.

I have been a die hard Thief fan for 15 years now. Looking Glass created the most amazing game that never really took off, but had developed a huge cult following. The first two were masterpieces. Sneak, infiltrate in numerous ways, hide, blackjack, steal loot, hide bodies, fight the undead, watch your step, you name it. Reading what goes on during the day in each place that had things to read made it feel like you were immersed in the world. No other game has EVER left me hungry and literally shaking in excitement for more.

Thief 3 was a bit of a step down, but it wrapped things up in quite a decent and surprising way. Warren Spector supervised it and many from the Looking Glass staff came to create it. Alas, it wasn't the same as the first two, but it had a charm to it...minus the load zones of course.

Then comes in the Thief reboot....where to begin...although graphically decent and polished in the skills of surprise, combat, ingenuity in gadgets, a progression system to help improve yourself as a thief, and a decent city to explore, it cannot make up for the severe woes that plague this game. The plot is fairly decent, as is the voice acting (outside of the lack of Stephen Russell) and the atmosphere is there, dark, foggy, gritty at points, you get the idea. The lockpicking is pretty cool and they added finding switches and levers in bookcases and behind paintings. So, the game actually makes you feel more like a professional. Back to my previous comment about the woes, with all the positives I have said so far, you'd think it was the Thief game we fans were waiting for. The woes, which can be summed up in one word: Scripted.

The whole game feels like a forced script. Where the originals had many ways to tackle entering, solving, exploring an area, and completing a mission, this game feels like it runs on a linear rail. You'd be lucky sometimes to find more than one path to finish a mission where the others let you go at it and figure it out on your own. I felt like I was being forced to go on one path alone and then get done with it. Sure, it branches off to different rooms sometimes, but not many. Loot is so easy to snag and the AI is easy to fool. The game seems to just want you to get into conflicts to save yourself from the bordeom. In the originals, knowing whether or not a guard is going to catch you was thrilling, in this, getting caught is so easily unavoidable that it's childs play. Even turning off the assistance the game gives you like the notice eyes for the guards and civilians still can't make up for the lack of challenge this game presents. The explorative factors are gone and replaced with one path, a scripted sequence which could be a cutscene to a daring escape Assassins Creed style, and then stupid simple puzzles or platform jumps that are so predictable.

This game could have been a masterpiece, but I get the feeling Eidos M catered to the classic simplicity" I see with many games nowadays

recommended: but recent patches and the expansion at least have made it enjoyable) with the removal of the skill tree replaced with simply combining different spells

reviewText: I have only started playing, so my review will be updated when finish the game. I never played previous Thief games, but even if some fans of the series felt disappointed with this installation, I believe the review must be about the game itself, and not its heritage. After all, it's a reboot. So far I'm enjoying it; it doesn't blow my mind, but it doesn't annoy me. It's against murder, which is nice, and even if thieving is immoral, well, frankly it feels much less criminal than those endless cash registers in Bioshock. The graphics are well made, character movements do not cause dizziness, it's a well made game. Worth getting with a discount, for sure. I'll write more when I finish it.\n\nUpdate: I'm still playing the game, now after a GPU upgrade it became evident that it is much more enjoyable with a higher frame rate. However, two flaws are also evident: controls and sound bugs. During a chase scene I had a considerable difficulty getting hero to run and jump when needed. The sound system is buggy - phrases are either not heard, or heard too loud, or cut off, etc. But on balance, the game is enjoyable and different enough to be a memorable experience. I still recommend it.

reviewText:
-not near the original still entertaining steampunk thieving simulator 7/10-

As I already read several (bad) reviews before buying at a large discount I could keep my disappointment in check. Yes it's not really a successor to the original and acclaimed thief series.
The product is a console-player-streamlined dishonored-like without superpowers.
Movement is restricted: jumping/climbing only where possible and also rope arrows can't be fired in any wood but assigned places (to not make it too difficult for kids). You can't place crates to create shortcuts, reach ledges or hide. You can't throw stuff to distract only the bottles designed for that purpose.
Gareth the cynical thief we loved becomes Gareth the emo dude with a mean GF but it's not that bad as I made it sound. (in fact in reviews the Erin character was usually reviled - she casually murders a guard in the beginning - but I think given her history and everything the character works and as you discover in the game the guards are a bunch of fascists anyway)

Now why the recommendation?
On it's own without the mighty thief series as comparison the game is a quiet good simulation of sneaking, stealing stuff and parcour. Aside from game design, bugs and handling problems the game shows AAA production values. For 10 bucks it's good entertainment.
For all the reasons outlined Dishonored feels like a much better production and was dubbed the spiritual thief successor (has Trickster, more steampunk and style) but Corvo is an overpowered killing machine who always has several ways to easily dispatch stuff while Gareth remains a fragile dude who has to strike from the shadows and he's a much better sneak at it. It's a different approach and also very satisfying to play.
Approaching the last mission now and the game hits the sweet spot between being the badass takedown sneaker and the close combat wimp.
You'll have a lot of exciting moments where you escape detection by a hair.
It's fun to nail an arrow through a guard's eye from the shadows.
Good lot of content with large main missions and several smaller 15 minute side missions.
Bunch of rare collectables and secret treasure hidden in every corner.


Other unsorted impressions and rants

Atmosphere is dark and gothic. I like the visual style and the game characters actually. Voice-acting ranges from poor to good. New Gareth is not old Gareth of legend but an ok dude for a hero.
Mission 5 is the thief-obligatory horror mission.
While the story is usual an excuse to steal stuff and go see places it's especially illogical and obscure here and the ending is just dumb and unrewarding.
There are no hammerites or pagans anymore.
Ambient conversations are projected on your position without any speaker existing - making it appear like you hear ghost voices in your head as noises and conversations from guards are correctly coming from their position.
Oh and often you're supposed to mash some button like to pry a  window. Completely useless feature in a game - should be patched out from ANY game (Batman games come to mind). Ruins your gear so you buy another overpriced controller.
Clumsy context sensitive controls" - you probably lean on a chest more often than loot it or fumble with controls while avoiding guards in pursuit."

The explorative factors are gone and replaced with one path, a scripted sequence which could be a cutscene to a daring escape Assassins Creed style, and then stupid simple puzzles or platform jumps that are so predictable.

This game could have been a masterpiece, but I get the feeling Eidos M catered to the classic simplicity" I see with many games nowadays

reviewText:
This was a tough one for me. As a long running fan of the Thief series I was very excited for this game, and it left me feeling a little mixed. The game seems to take place several years after Deadly Shadows and while that isn't a bad thing, they seem to use it as an excuse to discard a LOT of the Thief series staples...pagans, keepers, hammerites only got the subtlest of nods, nobody uses Taffer anymore, though it is mentioned oddly, elemental crystals are gone for seemingly no reason and Garret isn't quite the cynical anti-hero he originally was; he openly elects to be the hero this time around which is stupid; all to save his new spunky girl sidekick!....it actually hurt me to type that. The plot is ehhh.. at best and they forgot Garret's mechanical eye. Just as weird they went about bringing up a lot of other things..Basso from Thief 2 returns, they even recall his marriage, you actually stumble into Keeper ruins once or twice they even give a nod to insane widow Moira in the form of a chapter Moira's Asylym. In short from a Lore standpoint, they wrecked this game in the most puzzling of manners.

Gameplay is another issue however. Disregarding the mauled lore, the game is actually a lot of fun to play. The levels are of good size, not nearly as sprawling as classic Thief levels but certainly a dramatic improvement over Deadly Shadows small spaces, with multiple points of entry and progression such as the game demands. The downside is this game actually features points of no return; which is baffling. A game that is heavily about exploration actually has points where you can't backtrack from....really at a loss for words there other the quick-save is your friend. The City itself is open to exploration again like in Deadly Shadows, but unlike Deadly Shadows it's actually awesome! The City is large, gloomy, tightly-knit with a plethora of doors and windows you can break into, rooftops to explore, and all sorts of hidden nooks and crannies. Inbetween chapters you can pick up simple thief missions that take you around the city to find and steal various trinkets as well as whole, albeit small, individual chapters in the form of client jobs. A nice touch as well is you're able to go back and replay any chapter you just played without needing to load an old save to do so in case you want to try again or missed some loot. They did this aspect at least very well.

In the end if you're new to the Thief series and looking to try your hand at stealth games, I imagine you'll find this one a lot of fun. If you're a Thief veteran you'll be very disappointed in the butchering of the lore, almost as if they basically said they don't care, but you'll still find a lot of enjoyment in the gameplay despite it's few hiccups in that regard. It's fun but it's no Metal Age.

reviewText:
6/10

I got this game at Media Markt for 4,00 EUR which was a great find. This game has a storyline very similar to Dishonored (sneaking, plague in the city) however, unlike Dishonored, the plot lacks in consistency and the game play is very linear.
At one point I just got sick of opening and closing drawers and basically steal everything because it felt like it was the only point of the game.  The first part is very similar to Dishonored but then it's like the writers decided to change course halfway and instead of a plague infected city you have a thing called primal that got into a girl's body and made her create the gloom and blind faceless naked monster (wtf?). Then there was a scene at an asylum totally out of character for this game and that aspect could have been better explored because it was the most interesting part for me (phantoms, loonies, hidden cashes, and an overral good story). But then it was over and back we go to stealling all the things.  I also have to complain about the map, it's horrid, takes 20m to get to a place. Honestly there were parts I enjoyed like the client jobs but it was a bother to go an get them because of the stupid map.

I could have given this game a higher rating if it wasn't for the ending - absurd as it was not to mention rushed as hell.
Anyway, wasn't expecting more from a 4,00 EUR game. Good Buy,

reviewText:
My feelings towards the new Thief are complicated. I'm probably going to post an unpopular opinion.

And that opinion is: Thief 2014, on its own, is a good game.

I'm saying 'on its own', because if you bought it expecting to relive the memories of Thief games of old, you'll be sorely disappointed. Exploration, while interesting, doesn't offer nearly as much choices as the classic games. Levels are not as sprawling and intricately designed. The ambient music is just a shadow of Eric Brosius' masterpieces. No Stephen Russell. Also, you can't jump non-contextually. You can only shoot rope arrows at designated spots. Which sucks.

However, please hear me here: you need to look at Thief 2014 as a game completely of its own. It is a reboot, after all, not a sequel. (Even though it's filled to the brim with nice shout-outs to the classics + I'm pretty sure it is actually set in the same continuity). And the truth is, when seen without the prism of its predecessors, it's a very decent game. Graphics are very good and pleasingly gritty - even though they take a while to load - and The City feels deliciously grimdarky. And I actually liked the new Garrett very much; he's just as witty and darkly humorous as the Garrett we knew. Plus, let's not forget what the main source of fun in Thief has always been: stealing! This game managed to appease my inner cleptomaniac completely; looting feels fun and satisfying.

So, all in all, give Thief 2014 a shot, especially if you haven't played the classic ones (maybe you'll come to appreciate them afterwards). Think of it as Dishonored without Blink. It's a very fun bit of obsessive-compulsive stealing that should keep you occupied until we get a new, better stealth game. Until then, I give Thief a solid 7/10.

PS. By the way, if you feel that this game has been 'dumbed down' and made 'too easy' in comparison to the classic Thief... There is an option to play with a completely custom difficulty setting. You can make the game literally harder than hard. Like, Super Meat Thief level hard.

reviewText:
Thief is a very solid stealth game, dripping with atmosphere.
You are Garrett, the master thief and immediately from the beginning of the game you can be as invisible as a ghost for your adversaries. Stealth is the key to all of your actions, as you are a very weak combatant when exposed. The game focuses on what a thief does, stealing items of worth for his own gain. So if you like looting and looking for loot, especially the well hidden sort, Thief offers plenty of this.
The main story is supported by nicely animated cutscenes and very good voice acting, even in the german version. Like Deus Ex this is clearly one of Square Enix' strengths. Levels are well designed and you usually have more than two ways to deal with obstacles.
My only real problem with the actual gameplay is that you don't have many options to deal with actual enemies. Garrett has a form of magic" which is called focus
date: but it is barely any more than passive buffs which enhance your abilities
recommended: like slowing the time or extending shadows. In most cases you are limited to a hide and seek gameplay with the options of distracting
